questions.text: What does a red octagonal sign indicate?

options.text: Yield
Stop
No Entry
Speed Limit

questions.explanation: A red octagonal sign universally indicates a mandatory Stop.

questions.text: In most countries, what is the legal blood alcohol concentration (BAC) limit for fully licensed drivers?
questions.explanation: Limits vary, but 0.05% or 0.08% is common (UK/USA/Australia). Always aim for zero.

questions.text: What do flashing amber/yellow lights at a school zone indicate?

options.text: Speed up to clear the area
School zone active, reduce speed and watch for children
Parking allowed
Road closed ahead

questions.explanation: Flashing amber/yellow warning lights mean the school zone speed limit is active.

questions.text: When are you allowed to cross a double solid white/yellow line in the center of the road?

options.text: To overtake a slow vehicle
Never, except to turn into a property or when directed by police
When the road is empty
At night only

questions.explanation: Double solid lines prohibit overtaking. You may usually cross them only to turn or avoid an obstruction if safe.

questions.text: Who has the right of way at a pedestrian crossing with no traffic lights?

options.text: The vehicle
The pedestrian
Whoever arrives first
Cyclists only

questions.explanation: Pedestrians have priority at marked crossings without lights.

questions.text: What is the 'two-second rule' used for?

options.text: Checking tire pressure
Measuring stopping distance (how close you follow)
Duration of a turn signal
Time to shift gears

questions.explanation: Maintain at least a two-second gap from the vehicle in front in dry conditions.

questions.text: What should you do if an emergency vehicle approaches with sirens and lights flashing?

options.text: Stop immediately in your lane
Speed up to outrun it
Pull over safely to the side and stop
Ignore it if it's in the other lane

questions.explanation: Always yield to emergency vehicles by pulling over safely.

questions.text: When driving in fog, which lights should you use?

options.text: High beam headlights
Low beam (dipped) headlights and fog lights
Parking lights only
Hazard lights only

questions.explanation: High beams reflect off fog, worsening visibility. Use low beams.

questions.text: What does a blue circle sign containing a white arrow typically mean?

options.text: One way street
Mandatory direction of travel
Dead end
Recommended route

questions.explanation: Blue circles give mandatory instructions, such as 'turn left' or 'keep left'.

questions.text: You encounter a cyclist on a narrow road. What should you do?

options.text: Sound your horn to warn them
Wait for a safe place to pass with ample clearance
Squeeze past them quickly
Drive close to them

questions.explanation: Cyclists are vulnerable. Wait until it is safe to give them plenty of room.

questions.text: If you are involved in a collision with damage or injury, what must you do immediately?

options.text: Drive to the nearest mechanic
Stop at the scene
Call your insurance company before stopping
Leave if no one saw you

questions.explanation: It is a legal requirement to stop at the scene of an accident you are involved in.

questions.text: What is the primary effect of alcohol on driving ability?

options.text: Increases concentration
Slows reaction time and impairs judgment
Improves night vision
Makes you a more careful driver

questions.explanation: Alcohol significantly impairs cognitive and motor functions needed for driving.

questions.text: What does a triangular sign with a red border mean?

options.text: Information
Stop
Warning of a hazard
Speed limit

questions.explanation: Red-bordered triangles are standard for warning signs (e.g., sharp bend, slippery road).

questions.text: When merging onto a highway or motorway, you should:

options.text: Stop and wait for a gap
Accelerate to match the speed of traffic
Drive slowly on the shoulder
Use your hazard lights

questions.explanation: Use the slip road/on-ramp to build speed and merge safely into a gap.

questions.text: What is 'hydroplaning' (aquaplaning)?

options.text: Driving through a car wash
Tires losing contact with the road due to water
Using water instead of coolant
Skidding on ice

questions.explanation: Hydroplaning occurs when a layer of water builds up between tires and the road surface.

questions.text: When exiting a roundabout, which signal should you use?

options.text: No signal is needed
Signal left (in RHT countries) or right (in LHT countries) just before your exit
Signal towards the center
Hazard lights

questions.explanation: Signal your intent to exit to warn other drivers.

questions.text: What should you check regularly to ensure your vehicle is safe?

options.text: Radio presets
Tire pressure, lights, and fluid levels
Cup holders
Seat fabric

questions.explanation: Routine checks of tires, lights, oil, and coolant are essential for safety.

questions.text: Why is fatigue dangerous while driving?

options.text: It makes the journey feel longer
It can cause micro-sleeps and slower reactions
It saves fuel
It has no effect

questions.explanation: Tiredness significantly increases the risk of crashing due to poor concentration.

questions.text: A flashing red traffic light usually treats the intersection as a:

options.text: Stop sign
Yield sign
Go signal
Parking zone

questions.explanation: In many jurisdictions (like the US/Canada), flashing red means stop and proceed when safe.

questions.text: You are driving on a road with three lanes. The center lane is for:

options.text: Parking
Overtaking or smoother traffic flow
Driving slowly
Heavy trucks only

questions.explanation: In multi-lane driving, outer lanes are for overtaking; the 'slow' lane is for normal driving.

questions.text: If a school bus has stopped with red lights flashing, you must:

options.text: Slow down and pass carefully
Stop in both directions (unless separated by a median)
Sound your horn
Continue at normal speed

questions.explanation: To protect children, traffic in both directions usually must stop for a school bus.

questions.text: What does a broken white line in the center of the road mean?

options.text: No overtaking
You may change lanes or overtake if safe
Pedestrian crossing
Stop line

questions.explanation: Broken lines indicate that lane changing or passing is permitted.

questions.text: When turning into a side road, who should you yield to?

options.text: No one
Pedestrians crossing that side road
Cars behind you
You have priority

questions.explanation: If pedestrians are crossing the road you are turning into, you must yield to them.

questions.text: What is the intended use of a car horn?

options.text: Greeting friends
Expressing anger
Warning of immediate danger
Hurring up the driver in front

questions.explanation: The horn is a safety warning device, not a communication tool for frustration.

questions.text: Using a handheld mobile phone while driving is:

options.text: Safe if you are careful
Illegal and dangerous in most jurisdictions
Required for navigation
Allowed at red lights only

questions.explanation: Handheld phone use is a distracton and is widely prohibited.

questions.text: What is 'defensive driving'?

options.text: Driving aggressively to hold your position
Anticipating hazards and driving proactively to avoid accidents
Driving very slowly
Staying in the left lane always

questions.explanation: Defensive driving involves awareness and anticipation of other road users' errors.

questions.text: If a traffic light is green, but the intersection is blocked by traffic, what should you do?

options.text: Enter the intersection and wait
Stop before the intersection and wait for it to clear
Honk to clear traffic
Drive around the blockage

questions.explanation: Never block an intersection ('box junction'). Wait until your exit is clear.

questions.text: Blind spots are:

options.text: Areas of the road with no streetlights
Zones not visible in your mirrors
Tinted windows
Foggy areas

questions.explanation: You must check these areas by looking over your shoulder before changing lanes.

questions.text: What should you do if your brakes fail?

options.text: Jump out
Accelerate
Pump the brakes and use the parking brake gently
Turn off the engine immediately

questions.explanation: Pumping may restore pressure; using lower gears and handbrake helps slow down.

questions.text: Drivers under the age of 21 (or novice drivers) often have:

options.text: Higher insurance premiums
Stricter alcohol limits (often zero tolerance)
Higher accident risk
All of the above

questions.explanation: Young/novice drivers face stricter rules and higher risks.

questions.text: What does a sign with a maximum number (e.g., '3.5m') in a red circle meant?

options.text: Speed limit
Maximum vehicle height or width permitted
Distance to next town
Recommended gear

questions.explanation: Red circles with dimensions indicate restrictions on vehicle size (height/width).

questions.text: At a four-way stop, who goes first?

options.text: The vehicle turning left
The vehicle that arrived first
The largest vehicle
The fastest vehicle

questions.explanation: First to stop is first to go. If arriving simultaneously, yield to the right (in RHT countries).

questions.text: When parked downhill with a curb, which way should you turn your wheels?

options.text: Away from the curb
Towards the curb
Straight
It doesn't matter

questions.explanation: Turning wheels towards the curb prevents the car from rolling into traffic if brakes fail.

questions.text: The 'Give Way' or 'Yield' sign is what shape?

options.text: Inverted triangle (point down)
Circle
Octagon
Square

questions.explanation: The inverted triangle is the universal shape for Yield/Give Way.

questions.text: If you are taking medication that causes drowsiness, you should:

options.text: Drive slowly
Drink coffee
Not drive
Drive with windows open

questions.explanation: Never drive if impaired by medication.

questions.text: When towing a trailer, what happens to your braking distance?

options.text: It decreases
It stays the same
It increases significantly
It depends on the wind

questions.explanation: The extra weight creates more momentum, requiring longer to stop.

questions.text: Which of these is a sign of aggressive driving?

options.text: Using signals for every turn
Tailgating and frequent lane changes
Checking mirrors often
Stopping at yellow lights

questions.explanation: Tailgating and weaving are dangerous aggressive behaviors.

questions.text: In a skid, the most important rule is:

options.text: Slam on the brakes
Look where you want to go and steer there
Accelerate hard
Close your eyes

questions.explanation: Do not brake hard. Steer into the direction you want the vehicle to travel.

questions.text: Seat belts are required for:

options.text: The driver only
Front seat passengers only
All passengers
Children only

questions.explanation: In most modern jurisdictions, every person in the vehicle must wear a seat belt.

questions.text: What is 'rubbernecking'?

options.text: Stretching before driving
Slowing down to look at an accident/incident
Checking blind spots
Looking at street signs

questions.explanation: Rubbernecking causes congestion and can lead to secondary accidents.

questions.text: On a wet road, stopping distance is:

options.text: The same as dry
Double that of a dry road
Triple
Ten times longer

questions.explanation: Wet roads significantly reduce grip, often doubling stopping distance.

questions.text: Before opening your car door onto the street, you should:

options.text: Check for cyclists and traffic (Dutch Reach)
Open it quickly
Sound your horn
Unlock all doors

questions.explanation: Always check for approaching cyclists or cars to avoid 'dooring'.

questions.text: If a pedestrian enters the crosswalk while the light is green for you:

options.text: Drive around them
Yield and let them cross
Honk
Shout at them

questions.explanation: You must yield to pedestrians even if they are crossing against the light, to ensure safety.

questions.text: ABS stands for:

options.text: Automatic Brake System
Anti-lock Braking System
Advanced Braking Stability
Auto Boost Steering

questions.explanation: Anti-lock Braking System prevents wheels from locking during emergency braking.

questions.text: When driving at night, you should dim your high beams when:

options.text: You are tired
Within 150m (500ft) of an approaching vehicle
Entering a tunnel
Never

questions.explanation: Dim high beams to avoid blinding other drivers.

questions.text: The speed limit in a residential area, unless otherwise posted, is typically:

options.text: 80 km/h (50 mph)
50 km/h (30 mph) or lower
100 km/h (60 mph)
20 km/h

questions.explanation: Urban/residential default limits are usually 50 km/h or 30 mph.

questions.text: If you miss your highway exit, you should:

options.text: Reverse on the shoulder
Make a U-turn across the median
Continue to the next exit
Stop and check your GPS

questions.explanation: Never reverse on a highway. Go to the next exit and turn back safely.

questions.text: Green road markings or boxes (Bike Boxes) at intersections are for:

options.text: Trucks
Bicycles
Taxis
Pedestrians

questions.explanation: These areas are reserved for cyclists to be visible at traffic lights.

questions.text: Distracted driving incidents are most often caused by:

options.text: Billboards
Mobile phones and texting
Passengers
Eating

questions.explanation: Smartphones are the leading cause of driver distraction today.

questions.text: The left lane (in RHT countries) on a highway is primarily for:

options.text: Cruising
Passing/Overtaking
Entering the highway
Trucks

questions.explanation: Keep right (or left in UK/Aus) except to pass. The 'fast' lane is for passing.

questions.text: When approaching a horse and rider, you should:

options.text: Rev your engine
Slow down and pass wide and slow
Honk
Drive close

questions.explanation: Horses can be easily spooked. Drive very slowly and give wide clearance.

questions.text: What is the meaning of a yellow diamond sign?

options.text: Stop
Warning / Caution
Speed limit
Hospital ahead

questions.explanation: Yellow diamonds are standard warning signs in North America and other regions.

questions.text: You are involved in a minor crash with no injuries. You should:

options.text: Leave vehicles where they are
Move vehicles out of traffic if possible
Argue with the other driver
Wait for police before moving anything

questions.explanation: Clear the road to prevent traffic jams or secondary accidents if vehicles are movable.

questions.text: When turning right on a red light (where permitted), you must first:

options.text: Check mirrors only
Come to a complete stop
Slow down but don't stop
Flash your beams

questions.explanation: You must stop completely and check for safety before turning Right on Red.

questions.text: What effect does speed have on your field of vision?

options.text: It widens it
It has no effect
It narrows it (tunnel vision)
It improves clarity

questions.explanation: As speed increases, peripheral vision decreases, leading to 'tunnel vision'.

questions.text: Loose objects in the car can:

options.text: Improve balance
Become dangerous projectiles in a crash
Help sound insulation
None of the above

questions.explanation: Secure all items; they can cause injury during sudden stops.

questions.text: If an oncoming vehicle crosses into your lane, you should:

options.text: Swerve to the left (into their lane)
Brake and steer to the right (away from traffic)
Maintain course
accelerate

questions.explanation: Always try to escape to the shoulder/right rather than into opposing traffic.

questions.text: What does a solid yellow line on your side of the center line mean?

options.text: Pass with caution
No passing
Speed limit 50
School zone

questions.explanation: A solid line on your side indicates that passing is prohibited.

questions.text: You are approaching a bridge that is narrow. You should:

options.text: Speed up
Take the center
Slow down and give way if another vehicle is already on it
Close your eyes

questions.explanation: Yield to traffic already committed to the narrow section.

questions.text: When carrying a heavy load, you may need to:

options.text: Adjust your headlights aiming
Inflate tires to a higher pressure
Allow more stopping distance
All of the above

questions.explanation: Loads affect handling, braking, and headlight angle.

questions.text: Winter tires are designed to:

options.text: Be used in summer
Provide better grip in cold, snow, and ice
Look better
Save fuel

questions.explanation: Winter rubber compounds remain flexible below 7°C (45°F).

questions.text: Road rage incidents can be avoided by:

options.text: Retaliating
Apologizing if you make a mistake and not engaging with aggressors
Staring at the other driver
Blocking the lane

questions.explanation: De-escalation is key. Don't engage.

questions.text: What is the 'blind spot' in relation to trucks?

options.text: The windshield
Large areas on sides, front, and rear where the driver cannot see you
Under the truck
The roof

questions.explanation: Trucks have massive blind spots ('No Zones'). If you can't see the driver's mirrors, they can't see you.

questions.text: Cruise control should NOT be used in:

options.text: Heavy traffic
Rain or snow
Winding roads
All of the above

questions.explanation: Cruise control reduces control in changing conditions.

questions.text: Ideally, your hands should be positioned on the steering wheel at:

options.text: 10 and 2
9 and 3 or 8 and 4
12 and 6
One hand only

questions.explanation: 9 and 3 is the modern recommendation to avoid airbag injuries.

questions.text: When may you sound your horn in a built-up area at night (e.g., 11:30 PM - 7:00 AM)?

options.text: Any time
Only in an emergency to avoid an accident
To say goodbye
If someone is blocking your driveway

questions.explanation: Noise statutes usually restrict horn use at night unless it's an emergency.

questions.text: If a police officer directs you through a red light, you should:

options.text: Stop anyway
Obey the officer
Wait for green
Ask them why

questions.explanation: Police instructions override traffic signals.

questions.text: A 'Merge' sign implies:

options.text: Two lanes are becoming one; prepare to blend
Stop immediately
Sharp turn ahead
End of road

questions.explanation: Merge means traffic flows are joining; cooperation is required.

questions.text: When passing a stopped streetcar/tram where passengers are boarding, you should:

options.text: Pass quickly
Stop behind the rear doors and wait
Sound horn
Drive on the sidewalk

questions.explanation: Yield to passengers boarding or alighting trams/streetcars.

questions.text: What is the penalty for refusing a police breathalyzer test?

options.text: None
Usually the same or worse as a high-range drink driving offense
A small fine
A verbal warning

questions.explanation: Refusing a test is a serious offense leading to license suspension.

questions.text: What is the primary danger of driving with under-inflated tires?

options.text: Reduced fuel consumption
Overheating and potential blowout
Better grip
Decreased road noise

questions.explanation: Under-inflated tires flex more, causing heat buildup and increasing blowout risk.

questions.text: When parked parallel to the curb, how close should your wheels be?

options.text: Within 50 cm (18 inches)
Touching the curb
At least 1 meter away
On the curb

questions.explanation: Generally, you should be within 30-50 cm of the curb to not obstruct traffic.

questions.text: If you see a pedestrian with a white cane, this indicates:

options.text: They are elderly
They are visually impaired
They are traffic wardens
They are lost

questions.explanation: A white cane identifies a blind or visually impaired person; exercise superior caution.

questions.text: What should you do if your accelerator pedal gets stuck?

options.text: Panic
Shift to neutral and steer to a safe stop
Turn off the ignition and lock the steering
Pull the handbrake abruptly

questions.explanation: Shifting to neutral disconnects the engine power, allowing you to stop safely.

questions.text: Is it legal to pass a vehicle on the right (in RHT countries)?

options.text: Never
Yes, if they are turning left and there is room
Yes, on the shoulder
Only in school zones

questions.explanation: Passing on the right is restricted but allowed if the vehicle ahead is turning left.

questions.text: Start-Stop technology in cars helps to:

options.text: Increase speed
Reduce fuel consumption and emissions while idling
Cool the engine
Make the car louder

questions.explanation: It automatically shuts off the engine when stopped to save fuel.

questions.text: In heavy rain, if your steering feels light, you are likely:

options.text: Running out of fuel
Aquaplaning (Hydroplaning)
Driving too slowly
Turning sharply

questions.explanation: Light steering indicates tires have lost contact with the road.

questions.text: Tailgating is dangerous because:

options.text: It annoys the driver ahead
It reduces visibility and reaction time
It is illegal
All of the above

questions.explanation: Tailgating is aggressive, unsafe, and illegal.

questions.text: When exiting a parking spot, you must:

options.text: Honk your horn
Signal and check blind spots
Drive out quickly
Expect others to stop

questions.explanation: Always signal and check for traffic before rejoining the road.

questions.text: Driving with headphones on is:

options.text: Recommended for focus
Dangerous as it blocks auditory cues (sirens/horns)
Illegal only at night
Safe

questions.explanation: Blocking outside sounds prevents you from hearing emergency sirens or horns.

questions.text: What do double yellow lines (usually) mean?

options.text: Parking allowed
No parking at any time
Loading zone
Bus stop

questions.explanation: In many regions (e.g., UK), double yellow lines at the curb mean no parking.

questions.text: If a traffic signal is out of order, treat the intersection as:

options.text: A free-for-all
An all-way stop
A yield sign
A roundabout

questions.explanation: If lights fail, all vehicles must stop and proceed by right-of-way rules.

questions.text: Use your low beams when following within ___ of another vehicle.

options.text: 300 meters
60 meters (200 ft)
1 km
10 meters

questions.explanation: Exact distance varies by law (often 60m-100m), but generally dim lights when close behind.

questions.text: When turning left at an intersection (RHT), you should position your vehicle:

options.text: Near the right curb
In the left-most lane available for your direction
In the center of two lanes
On the shoulder

questions.explanation: Turn from the lane closest to the direction you are turning.

questions.text: If you hit a parked car and the owner is absent, you must:

options.text: Leave immediately
Leave a note with your details
Wait for 5 minutes then leave
Do nothing if no damage is visible

questions.explanation: You are legally required to leave your contact and insurance details.

questions.text: Electronic Stability Control (ESC) helps prevent:

options.text: Speeding
Skidding and loss of control
Tire wear
Fuel loss

questions.explanation: ESC detects and reduces loss of traction to keep the car on course.

questions.text: The safest place for a child car seat is:

options.text: Front passenger seat
Rear seat, middle or side
Drivers lap
Trunk

questions.explanation: The rear seat is safest; rear-facing seats must never be in front of an active airbag.

questions.text: What does a green arrow traffic light mean?

options.text: Stop
Protected turn in direction of arrow
Go straight only
Yield

questions.explanation: A green arrow indicates a protected turn; opposing traffic is stopped.

questions.text: Most accidents are caused by:

options.text: Vehicle malfunction
Road conditions
Human error
Weather

questions.explanation: Human error (distraction, speed, impairment) causes over 90% of crashes.

questions.text: When approaching a railway crossing with flashing red lights:

options.text: Cross quickly
Stop at least 5m away and wait
Cross if no train is visible
Slow down only

questions.explanation: Stop and wait. Trains cannot stop quickly.

questions.text: Lane splitting (motorcycles riding between lanes) is:

options.text: Always legal
Legal in some regions, illegal in others
Impossible
Required

questions.explanation: Laws vary globally (e.g., legal in California/UK, illegal in most of US/Canada).

questions.text: Overdriving your headlights means:

options.text: Using them during the day
Driving so fast you cannot stop within the distance lit by them
Using high beams in the city
Flashing them repeatedly

questions.explanation: You must be able to stop within the distance you can see clearly.

questions.text: If you are emotionally upset, you should:

options.text: Take a drive to calm down
Avoid driving until you are calm
Drive faster
Listen to loud music

questions.explanation: Strong emotions impair judgment and focus.

questions.text: A white diamond painted on a lane indicates:

options.text: Speed bump
HOV (High Occupancy Vehicle) / Carpool lane
No stopping
Pedestrian zone

questions.explanation: White diamonds mark lanes reserved for buses or carpools.

questions.text: Reaction time is defined as:

options.text: Time to stop the car completely
Time between seeing a hazard and applying the brakes
Time to accelerate to 100km/h
Time to change a tire

questions.explanation: Reaction time occurs before braking begins.

questions.text: When driving in snow, you should accelerate:

options.text: Aggressively
Gently and gradually
Normally
In neutral

questions.explanation: Gentle inputs prevent wheel spin on low-grip surfaces.

questions.text: If a tire blows out:

options.text: Brake hard immediately
Hold wheel firmly and keep vehicle straight, slowing gradually
Accelerate
Turn quickly

questions.explanation: Avoid braking harshly, which can cause a spin. Stabilize first.

questions.text: You must report a change of address to the licensing authority within:

options.text: Any time
A specific period (e.g., 1-2 weeks)
1 year
Never

questions.explanation: Licenses must be kept up to date; timelines vary by region.

questions.text: Road bumps (speed humps) are meant to:

options.text: Test suspension
Slow down traffic in sensitive areas
Be jumped
Mark parking spots

questions.explanation: Traffic calming measures reduce speed in residential zones.

questions.text: When parallel parking, you should park within ___ of the vehicle in front or behind?

options.text: Touching distance
A safe distance to allow maneuvering
5 meters
It doesn't matter

questions.explanation: Leave space for both cars to exit.

questions.text: If your car breaks down on a highway:

options.text: Stay in the car with seatbelt on
Get out and stand on the road
Try to fix it in the lane
Push it while driving

questions.explanation: If you can't exit the vehicle safely away from traffic, stay belted inside.

questions.text: A solid white line at an intersection means:

options.text: Stop line
Start line
Parking line
Pedestrian zone

questions.explanation: You must stop behind the solid white stop line.

questions.text: To save fuel:

options.text: Drive aggressively
Accelerate smoothly and anticipate stops
Carry heavy items
Idle for long periods

questions.explanation: Eco-driving involves smooth inputs and maintaining momentum.

questions.text: When carrying a load on a roof rack, you must ensure:

options.text: It is securely fastened
It is loose
It blocks your view
It is heavier than the car

questions.explanation: Loose loads are a major hazard.

questions.text: In a manual car, 'riding the clutch' means:

options.text: Not releasing the clutch pedal fully while driving
Sitting on the clutch
Cornering fast
Stalling

questions.explanation: This wears out the clutch mechanism prematurely.

questions.text: Blind people may carry white canes with red bands, indicating:

options.text: They are deaf and blind
They are angry
They are instructors
Nothing specific

questions.explanation: Red bands on a white cane signify dual sensory impairment (deaf-blind).

questions.text: What is 'brake fade'?

options.text: Brakes becoming less effective due to overheating
Brake lights fading
Running out of brake fluid
Old brakes

questions.explanation: Overheating brakes (e.g., on long descents) lose stopping power.

questions.text: If you see an accident ahead, use your hazard lights to:

options.text: Warn traffic behind you to slow down
Illuminate the scene
Signal a turn
Ask for help

questions.explanation: Hazards warn following drivers of obstruction/slowing ahead.

questions.text: When turning left from a one-way street onto another one-way street, use:

options.text: The far left lane
The far right lane
Any lane
The center

questions.explanation: Turn from the lane nearest the curb into the lane nearest the curb.

questions.text: Aggressive driving includes:

options.text: Yelling at others
Honking excessively
Cutting off other vehicles
All of the above

questions.explanation: All are forms of road rage/aggression.

questions.text: What does a sign with a car and 'winding tracks' mean?

options.text: Race track
Slippery road ahead
Drunk drivers
Scenic route

questions.explanation: Usually depicts a car skidding; warns of low grip surfaces.

questions.text: Catalytic converters reduce:

options.text: Noise
Toxic exhaust emissions
Fuel use
Speed

questions.explanation: They convert harmful pollutants into less harmful gases.

questions.text: When approaching a curve, you should:

options.text: Brake while in the curve
Slow down before entering the curve
Accelerate into it
Close your eyes

questions.explanation: Brake before the turn to maintain balance and control.

questions.text: A 'Zipper Merge' means:

options.text: Using both lanes until the merge point, then alternating
Merging as early as possible
Pushing in
Stopping

questions.explanation: Late merging (zipper) utilizes road capacity best in slow traffic.

questions.text: Refusal to take a field sobriety test can result in:

options.text: Arrest or license suspension
A Warning
Nothing
A prize

questions.explanation: Implied consent laws penalize refusal.

questions.text: Which mirrors eliminate blind spots completely?

options.text: Convex mirrors
None
Wide angle mirrors
Internal mirror

questions.explanation: No mirror eliminates blind spots; you must check over your shoulder.

questions.text: If you are being passed, you should:

options.text: Speed up
Maintain speed or slow slightly/keep right
Swerve
Brake hard

questions.explanation: Allow the other driver to pass safely.

questions.text: Driving over a fire hose is:

options.text: Allowed
Prohibited without permission
Fun
Recommended

questions.explanation: Never drive over fire hoses; it damages equipment.

questions.text: If you hit a deer:

options.text: Keep driving
Move it off the road if safe and report if required
Take it home
Ignore it

questions.explanation: Report animal strikes if they cause obstruction or damage.

questions.text: The safest way to use a GPS is:

options.text: Set it before leaving
Program it while driving
Hold it in your hand
Put it on the steering wheel

questions.explanation: Program navigation while parked to avoid distraction.

questions.text: A rectangular orange sign indicates:

options.text: Construction / Road work
School
Stop
Hospital

questions.explanation: Orange is the standard color for work zones.

questions.text: When turning into a driveway, you must yielding to:

options.text: Pedestrians and cyclists on the sidewalk
Nobody
Only cars
Pets

questions.explanation: Sidewalk users have priority when you cross their path.

questions.text: Hydroplaning can happen at speeds as low as:

options.text: 50 km/h (30 mph)
100 km/h
20 km/h
0 km/h

questions.explanation: With worn tires or deep water, it can occur at city speeds.

questions.text: If you drive past your exit on a roundabout:

options.text: Reverse
Continue around and try again
Stop
Turn left

questions.explanation: Simply circle around again safely.

questions.text: A flashing yellow arrow means:

options.text: Turn allowed but must yield
Protected turn
Stop
No turn

questions.explanation: You may turn but must yield to oncoming traffic.

questions.text: What is the legal minimum tread depth for tires in many places?

options.text: 1.6 mm
5 mm
0 mm (bald)
10 mm

questions.explanation: 1.6mm is a common legal minimum standard (e.g., UK/EU/USA).

questions.text: If you are colorblind, how do you read traffic lights?

options.text: By position (Top/Left is usually Red)
Guess
Ask passenger
Stop at all

questions.explanation: Positions are standardized: Red is Top (vertical) or Left (horizontal).

questions.text: Can you park in front of a fire hydrant?

options.text: Yes
No
Only for 5 minutes
On Sundays

questions.explanation: You must keep hydrants clear for emergency use.

questions.text: High beams normally let you see about:

options.text: 50 meters
100-150 meters
1 km
10 meters

questions.explanation: High beams illuminate ~100-150m ahead.

questions.text: If a vehicle cuts in front of you too closely, you should:

options.text: Lift your foot off the gas
Flash lights
Tailgate them
Honk

questions.explanation: Re-establish the safe following distance immediately.

questions.text: What usually designates a disabled parking spot?

options.text: Blue markings/sign with wheelchair symbol
Green paint
Red paint
A star symbol

questions.explanation: The International Symbol of Access (wheelchair) marks these spots.

questions.text: Before backing up, you should:

options.text: Honk
Walk around the vehicle if unsure, check mirrors, look back
Rely only on camera
Close eyes

questions.explanation: Cameras can miss blind spots; physical checks are safest.

questions.text: If your car hood flies up while driving:

options.text: Stop immediately on the road
Look through the gap or out the window, pull over safely
Speed up
Scream

questions.explanation: Maintain control, find a view, and exit the traffic flow.

questions.text: Children under a certain age/height must use:

options.text: Seat belts only
Approved child restraints/booster seats
Anything soft
Lap

questions.explanation: Booster seats ensure the seat belt fits correctly.

questions.text: A pentagon-shaped sign usually marks:

options.text: School zone / School crossing
Stop
No parking
Yield

questions.explanation: Pentagons are unique to school zones (in North America).

questions.text: If driving in strong winds:

options.text: Speed up
Keep a firm grip on the wheel
Open windows
Drive close to trucks

questions.explanation: Gusts can push the car; be ready to correct steering.

questions.text: The dashboard light resembling a battery means:

options.text: Battery is fully charged
Charging system failure (alternator issue)
Electric car mode
Radio on

questions.explanation: It indicates the battery is not charging and may go flat soon.

questions.text: If you cannot see clearly 100m ahead due to fog:

options.text: Stop on the road
Slow down, use lights/fog lights
Speed up
Use high beams

questions.explanation: Visibility is critical; slow down.

questions.text: Who is responsible for all passengers wearing seatbelts (depending on age)?

options.text: The driver
The passengers
The police
The car manufacturer

questions.explanation: Drivers are usually responsible for occupants under 16/18.

questions.text: Crosshatch markings (yellow box) usually mean:

options.text: Park here
Do not enter unless your exit is clear
Taxi stand
Loading zone

questions.explanation: Prevent gridlock by keeping the box clear.

questions.text: What does a sign with a 'P' crossed out in a red circle mean?

options.text: Parking allowed
No parking
Police station
Pay here

questions.explanation: Standard prohibitory sign for parking.

questions.text: You are towing a trailer that starts to swerve/snake. You should:

options.text: Accelerate to pull it straight
Ease off the accelerator and slow down gently
Brake hard
Steer sharply

questions.explanation: Slowing down gently reduces the instability.

questions.text: When driving in a tunnel, you should:

options.text: Turn off lights
Turn on low beam headlights and remove sunglasses
Speed up
Wear sunglasses

questions.explanation: Ensure visibility and allow eyes to adjust to lower light.

questions.text: If you are involved in a collision, you must exchange details with:

options.text: No one
The other driver(s)
Your passenger only
The media

questions.explanation: You must provide name, address, and insurance info to anyone with reasonable grounds to ask.

questions.text: A 'yield' line on the road usually consists of:

options.text: Solid red line
Row of triangles or dashed line
Blue dots
Yellow circle

questions.explanation: Road markings for yielding often mirror the triangle sign shape.

questions.text: What is 'defensive driving'?

options.text: Driving aggressively
Observation, anticipation, and planning
Driving slowly
Always honking

questions.explanation: Being prepared for others' mistakes makes you a safer driver.

questions.text: If you lose your way in a busy city, you should:

options.text: Stop in the middle of the road to check map
Turn into a side road or parking spot to checking map/GPS
Panic
Reverse

questions.explanation: Never obstruct traffic to navigate.

questions.text: The most fuel-efficient way to drive is:

options.text: Stop-start quickly
Maintain a steady speed in the highest possible gear
Drive in low gear at high revs
Brake late

questions.explanation: Higher gears at lower revs consume less fuel.

questions.text: When approaching a STOP sign with a white line:

options.text: Stop after the line
Stop before the line
Slow down
Stop only if cars are coming

questions.explanation: The stop must be made before your vehicle crosses the line.

questions.text: Heavy rain can cause:

options.text: Better visibility
Reduced visibility and longer stopping distances
Increased traction
None of the above

questions.explanation: Wipers may struggle, and grip is reduced.

questions.text: When parked on a hill without a curb, turn wheels:

options.text: Towards the edge of the road (right in RHT)
Towards the center
Keep straight
Left

questions.explanation: If the car rolls, it should roll off the road, not into traffic.

questions.text: What does an amber traffic light mean?

options.text: Stop if safe to do so
Speed up
Go
Parking allowed

questions.explanation: It warns the signal is changing to red; stop unless you are too close to do so safely.

questions.text: You can identify a one-way street by:

options.text: Blue signs with white arrows
Cars parked facing the same direction on both sides
'One Way' signs
All of the above

questions.explanation: Multiple cues indicate one-way traffic.

questions.text: If you drive while tired, you are:

options.text: A better driver
A danger to yourself and others
Saving time
Using less fuel

questions.explanation: Fatigue causes thousands of accidents annually.

questions.text: When driving in designated bus lanes:

options.text: Always allowed
Never allowed during operation hours
Allowed if in a hurry
Only in sports cars

questions.explanation: Bus lanes are restricted during posted hours to improve public transit flow.

questions.text: You should check your tire pressure:

options.text: When tires are cold
After a long drive (hot)
Only when flat
Yearly

questions.explanation: Pressure readings are accurate only when tires are cold.

questions.text: An octagonal sign is exclusively for:

options.text: Stop
Yield
Parking
School

questions.explanation: No other sign uses the 8-sided shape.

questions.text: Why should you not wave pedestrians across a street?

options.text: It is impolite
Another vehicle may not see them and hit them
They might fall
It delays you

questions.explanation: You cannot guarantee safety in other lanes. Let them decide when to cross.

questions.text: If a vehicle is following too closely, you should:

options.text: Slow down gradually to increase space in front
Brake check them
Sped up
Stop

questions.explanation: Increasing the gap in front gives you more room to brake gently if needed.

questions.text: What does a broken yellow line alongside a solid yellow line mean?

options.text: Passing permitted from the broken side only
Passing allowed both sides
No passing
Parking

questions.explanation: You may pass if the broken line is on your side.

questions.text: If your vehicle catches fire:

options.text: Drive faster
Pull over safely, get all passengers out and away
Open the hood immediately
Pour water on it

questions.explanation: Safety of life is priority. Opening the hood may fuel the fire with oxygen.

questions.text: The 2-second rule applies to:

options.text: Good, dry conditions
Snow
Ice
Rain

questions.explanation: In bad weather, increase this gap (4 seconds for rain, 10 for ice).

questions.text: Headrests are mainly for:

options.text: Comfort
Preventing whiplash in rear-end collisions
Style
Holding hats

questions.explanation: They restrict head movement during impact.

questions.text: If you fail to stop for a school bus with flashing red lights:

options.text: Only a warning
Heavy fines and demerit points
Nothing
Small fine

questions.explanation: This is a severe offense due to the risk to children.

questions.text: A 'don't walk' signal for pedestrians means you (the driver):

options.text: Have priority (but watch for stragglers)
Must stop
Should honk
Can speed up

questions.explanation: If pedestrians are told not to walk, your light is usually green or about to turn green.

questions.text: When changing a tire, ensure:

options.text: The car is on soft ground
The car is on a flat, hard surface and handbrake is on
Engine is running
Passengers are inside

questions.explanation: Stability is crucial to prevent the jack slipping.

questions.text: Passing near the crest of a hill is:

options.text: Safe
Dangerous and usually illegal
Recommended
Allowed if fast

questions.explanation: You cannot see oncoming traffic over the hill.

questions.text: The blind spots for a truck driver are known as:

options.text: Dark zones
No-Zones
Safe zones
Free zones

questions.explanation: Stay out of the No-Zones.

questions.text: If you drive into fog, you should:

options.text: Stop immediately in the lane
Slow down and turn on low beams
Use high beams
Follow closely

questions.explanation: Reduce speed and use appropriate lighting.

questions.text: A triangular sign pointing sideways (Pennant) usually means:

options.text: No Passing Zone
School
Stop
Yield

questions.explanation: Used on the left side of the road (in North America) to indicate start of no passing zone.

questions.text: Drugs taken for colds or allergies can:

options.text: Make you drowsy
Make you a better driver
Have no effect
Improve vision

questions.explanation: Many over-the-counter medicines cause drowsiness.

questions.text: At a roundabout, you give way to:

options.text: Traffic entering
Traffic already circulating
Traffic on your left (in RHT)
Nobody

questions.explanation: Yield to vehicles already on the roundabout.

questions.text: Braking distance increases with:

options.text: Speed
Vehicle weight
Road wetness
All of the above

questions.explanation: Higher energy, mass, and lower friction all increase distance.

questions.text: If the temperature gauge rises into the red zone:

options.text: Drive faster to cool it with air
Pull over safely and stop the engine
Ignore it
Turn on heater

questions.explanation: The engine is overheating and may seize if not stopped.

questions.text: What is the 'move over' law?

options.text: Move over for speeding cars
Change lanes or slow down for stopped emergency/service vehicles
Move to left lane to turn
Move seats

questions.explanation: Protects workers on the roadside.

questions.text: You should signal your turn at least ___ before turning.

options.text: 30 meters (100 feet)
1 meter
1 km
After turning

questions.explanation: Give ample warning to other road users.

questions.text: In a funeral procession, cars usually have:

options.text: Headlights on / Hazard lights on
Sirens
Flags
A

questions.explanation: Respect the procession; do not cut in.

questions.text: If a tire is bald (no tread):

options.text: It is fine for dry roads
It is illegal and dangerous
It improves fuel econ
It is quiet

questions.explanation: Without tread, there is no grip in wet conditions and high risk of puncture.

questions.text: When turning right, look:

options.text: Left-Right-Left
Right only
At the floor
Straight

questions.explanation: Scanning helps clear traffic coming from the left and re-checking obstacles.

questions.text: Carbon Monoxide is:

options.text: Smelled easily
Colorless, odorless, and deadly
Harmless
Visible

questions.explanation: Never run the engine in a closed garage.

questions.text: Before taking a long trip, check:

options.text: Fluids, tires, brakes, lights
Radio
Seat covers
Paint

questions.explanation: Prevent breakdowns by inspecting critical systems.

questions.text: You must yield to a public transit bus:

options.text: When it is signaling to re-enter traffic
Always
Never
Only if big

questions.explanation: Many jurisdictions require yielding to buses re-entering the stream.

questions.text: It is widely illegal to:

options.text: Drink water while driving
Text while driving
Talk to passenger
Sing

questions.explanation: Texting is a major distraction banned almost everywhere.

questions.text: When parked on a roadway at night:

options.text: Leave parking lights on if required/poorly lit
Turn off all lights
Use high beams
Hide

questions.explanation: Ensure your vehicle is visible to others.

questions.text: If a police car is behind you with lights on:

options.text: Speed up
Pull over to the right and stop
Stop immediately in lane
Ignore

questions.explanation: Clear the way safely.

questions.text: If you miss a turn:

options.text: Reverse
Take the next one
Make a U-turn illegally
Stop

questions.explanation: Safest option is to reroute.

questions.text: You should dim your dashboard lights at night to:

options.text: Save battery
Improve night vision (reduce glare)
Look cool
Hide speed

questions.explanation: Bright interior lights hinder your ability to see outside in the dark.

questions.text: If you are convicted of driving while impaired:

options.text: Insurance costs increase drastically
You may lose your license
You could face jail time
All of the above

questions.explanation: DUI carries severe penalties personally and financially.

questions.text: When stopping behind a vehicle, you should see:

options.text: Their roof
Their rear tires touching the ground
Their bumper only
Their driver

questions.explanation: This ensures you have space to pull out if they break down.

questions.text: Skids are often caused by:

options.text: Driving too fast for conditions
Harsh braking
Harsh acceleration
All of the above

questions.explanation: Smooth inputs prevent loss of traction.

questions.text: You should check mirrors:

options.text: Every 5-8 seconds
Never
Once a trip
Only when stopped

questions.explanation: Constant situational awareness is required.

questions.text: A 'soft shoulder' sign means:

options.text: Comfortable place to stop
Dirt/grass on side is soft; vehicle may sink/lose control
No trucks
Playground

questions.explanation: Avoid driving off the pavement.

questions.text: If an animal runs in front of you:

options.text: Brake firmly but do not swerve blindly
Swerve into oncoming traffic
Accelerate
Close eyes

questions.explanation: Swerving can cause a more serious crash (e.g., head-on or rollover).

questions.text: High speed increases:

options.text: Stopping distance
Severity of crash
Likelihood of losing control
All of the above

questions.explanation: Physics dictates that speed exponentially increases energy and risk.

questions.text: Motorcycles often appear:

options.text: Further away/faster than they are
Closer/Slower
Invisible
Large

questions.explanation: Small size makes judging speed/distance difficult. Double check!

questions.text: When getting gas/fuel:

options.text: Turn off engine and no smoking
Leave engine running
Talk on phone
Use lighter

questions.explanation: Prevent ignition of fumes.

questions.text: The engine oil light means:

options.text: Oil pressure is low; stop engine immediately
Oil is full
Change oil next month
Car is slippery

questions.explanation: Assuming it means 'low level' is dangerous; low pressure kills engines in seconds.

questions.text: You should not rely solely on backup cameras because:

options.text: Lens may be dirty
They don't show the whole picture
Looking around is safer
All of the above

questions.explanation: Use all tools available: eyes, mirrors, and cameras.

questions.text: If you see a 'Road Closed' sign:

options.text: Drive around it
Find another route
Move it
Proceed slowly

questions.explanation: The road is unsafe or impassable.

questions.text: Effective braking on slippery roads (without ABS) involves:

options.text: Threshold braking (squeeze until just before lockup)
Stomping
No braking
Handbrake

questions.explanation: Max braking efficiency is at the limit just before wheels skid.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Stop, for school crossing ahead.
Stop your vehicle.
Other traffic must give way to you.
Give way to traffic coming from your right.

questions.explanation: This sign appears at junctions where a minor road joins a major road. You must stop your vehicle completely at a STOP sign.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Turn right ahead.
Diversion to the right ahead.
One-way traffic to the right ahead.
Sharp bend ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you that you must turn right. It is usually displayed on the approach to a one-way system.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Trams may block cyclists from your view.
Cyclists and tram only ahead.
Tram track, cyclists beware.
Cycle track ahead.

questions.explanation: This is an advance warning sign for cyclists to be aware that they are approaching a tram track and that the surface may be slippery.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: End to motorway.
Low bridge ahead.
Entry to motorway.
Toll-bridge ahead.

questions.explanation: This is a motorway information sign telling you that you are entering a motorway.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Motorway ends 500 meters ahead.
No overtaking for 500 meters.
Bridge repair 500 meters ahead.
Low bridge 500 meters ahead.

questions.explanation: This is a motorway information sign that tells you that the motorway will end in 500 meters.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: End of motorway.
Crossing onto the opposite carriageway is not allowed.
No overtaking.
Stopping under bridge is not allowed.

questions.explanation: This sign indicates the end of the motorway.You are now leaving the motorway and its restrictions no longer apply.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Crossing traffic ahead.
Steep climb up ahead for 3 kilometers.
Three hundred meters to the next exit.
Three lanes ahead.

questions.explanation: This is a motorway information sign that tells you that the next exit off the motorway is 300 meters ahead.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Two hundred meters to the next exit.
Sharp corner to left.
Steep climb ahead for 2 kilometers.
Dual-carriageway crossing ahead.

questions.explanation: This is a motorway information sign that tells you that the next exit off the motorway is 200 meters ahead.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: One hundred meters to the next exit.
Low bridge ahead.
Single carriageway ahead.
Steep climb ahead for 1 kilometer.

questions.explanation: This is a motorway information sign that tells you that the next exit off the motorway is 100 meters ahead.

questions.text: What does this sign mean when displayed on the approach to a motorway?

options.text: Coin basket in this lane.
Leisure area on the left.
Cashier in this lane.
Ticket dispenser in this lane.

questions.explanation: This sign is used at motorway tool plazas to direct traffic into a lane where toll charge may be paid directly to a cashier. This lane would normally be used by motorists who have neither the exact change nor an electronic tag on their vehicles.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Building site ahead.
Tree planting ahead.
Mud slide ahead.
Roadworks ahead.

questions.explanation: This warning sign tells you that there are road works ahead.You should approach with caution and be alert for a change in road surface,and for the presence of machinery and road workers.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Pipe laying ahead.
Series of steep hills ahead.
Industrial estate ahead.
Uneven surface ahead.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the surface ahead is uneven and you should approach with caution.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Sharp bend to the left ahead.
Steep decline ahead to the left.
Keep Left.
Roundabout ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you that you must keep left. It is usually displayed at a traffic island in the centre of the road.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Steep hill ahead.
Slippery road .
Series of bends ahead.
Crosswinds ahead.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the surface ahead is slippery and that there is increaseed risk of skidding.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Road narrows from left.
Left-hand lane has an uneven surface.
Slow lane ends ahead.
You must overtake on the right only.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the road narrows suddenly from the left creating a potential hazard.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Overtaking lane ends ahead.
Right-hand lane has an uneven surface.
You must overtake on the right only.
Road narrows from right.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the road narrows suddenly from the right creating a potential hazard.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Road narrows on both sides.
Tunnel ahead.
Railway crossing ahead.
Dual-carriageway ahead.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the road narrows on both sides creating a potential hazard. Drive with extra care.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Football stadium ahead.
Hitch-hiking permitted.
Flagman ahead.
Litter is not allowed.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the traffic sequence ahead is controlled manually or by an automatic system.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Temporary traffic signals ahead.
Roundabout with traffic lights ahead.
School children crossing ahead.
Railway crossing ahead.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that temporary traffic signals are in use ahead.You hould approach with caution and signal displayed.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Traffic may not stop.
Two-way traffic.
One-way street.
Dual-carriageway ahead.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that there is two-way-traffic in operation.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Nearside lane of two closed .
No overtaking.
Stop sign ahead.
Overtaking permitted on right only.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the lane on the left ahead is closed.If you are in the left lane you will need to move to the right when it is safe to do so.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: No left turn ahead.
Nearside lane of three closed .
Overtaking permitted, except in the left lane.
Do not drive on the hard shoulder.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the lane left-hand lane of three is closed ahead.If you are in the left lane you will need to move to the right when it is safe to do so.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Loose chippings on road.
Vehicle broken down ahead on right.
Flooding up ahead on left.
Uneven surface on left.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the road ahead has been resurfaced and there may be loose chippings. You should reduce speed while driving through this area as the loose chippings could affect your vehicle's road holding and braking.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Turn back.
Steep decline ahead to the right.
Keep right.
Traffic crossing from the left.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you that you must keep right. It is usually found in a one way system where the traffic is required to keep to the right.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: End of dual carriageway ahead.
Offside lane closed ahead.
No stopping, except in the right-hand lane.
Corner ahead on the right-hand lane.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the extreme right-hand lane is closed ahead.If you are in this lane,you will need to move to the left when it is safe to do so.The offside lane is the lane closest to the centre of the road.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Steep incline ahead.
Parking for works vehicles on left.
Three vehicles may queue ahead.
Traffic queses likely ahead.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that there may be traffic queues ahead, possibly due to temporary traffic lights at the works. Proceed with caution.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Keep left.
Slippery surface.
Uneven surface.
Parking on left only.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the road surface may be uneven, possible due to the resurfacing of part of a lane. Proceed with caution.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Dual-carriageway ahead.
Heavy vehicles have priority.
Lay-by ahead.
Obstruction between lanes ahead.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that there is an obstruction in the centre of the road ahead, and that two-way traffic will separate to avoid it.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Pedestrians cross to the right.
Do not drive on the footpath.
Shopping mall on the right.
Pedestrianised street to the right.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells pedestrians to cross to the right as the footpath may be closed at this point.

questions.text: At roadworks, what does this sign mean?

options.text: Proceed with caution.
Proceed with hazard warning lights on.
Only proceed when flagman beckons you on.
Proceed using hand signals only.

questions.explanation: This is the sign telling you to proceed with caution through road works.It may be displayed by a flagman or by an automated system.

questions.text: At roadworks, what does this sign mean?

options.text: Stop before or at the sign.
Stop only if faced by oncoming traffic.
Only proceed if road is clear ahead.
Make a detour.

questions.explanation: This is a roadworks warning sign telling you to stop.It may be displayed by a flagman or by an automated system.

questions.text: What do these signs together mean?

options.text: End of speed limit.
End of detour.
End of road.
End of road works.

questions.explanation: These roadworks warning signs indicate that a detour has ended and that you are back on the original route.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Traffic must cross over to left-hand lane.
Bend in the road to the left ahead.
Slow lane ahead for heavy traffic.
Lay-by ahead.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the course of the road will return to the left ahead.This usually appears after a stretch where traffic was diverted to a right-hand lane.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Traffic calming measures ahead.
Bend in the road to the right ahead.
End of 'no overtaking' zone.
Traffic must cross over to the right-hand lane.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the course of the road will temporarily cross the central reserve to the right.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: One-way street.
Two way traffic ahead.
Pass either side.
Dual-carriageway ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you that traffic must pass on either side of the traffic island.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Lay-by ahead.
Start of central reserve or obstruction.
Heavy vehicles have priority.
Dual-carriageway ahead.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that two-way traffic will separate to avoid an obstruction.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Dual-carriageway ends ahead.
Lighter vehicles should use the middle lane.
End of central reserve or obstruction.
Beware of vehicles with a wide load.

questions.explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that traffic that was separated will revert to two-way road.

questions.text: What does this hand signal mean?

options.text: The cyclist intends to stop.
The cyclist intends to turn left.
The cyclist intends to slow down.
The cyclist intends to move out or to turn right.

questions.explanation: This hand signal tells other road users that the cyclist intends to either move out or make a right turn.

questions.text: What does this hand signal mean?

options.text: The cyclist intends to turn left.
The cyclist is signaling following traffic to overtake.
The cyclist intends to move out or to turn right.
The cyclist intends to slow down or stop.

questions.explanation: This hand signal tells other road users that the cyclist intends to slow down or stop. This may indicate that the cyclist is aware of some hazard ahead, so drive with extra care.

questions.text: What does this hand signal mean?

options.text: The cyclist intends to go straight on.
The cyclist is turning to her left.
The cyclist is yielding right of way to you.
The cyclist is preparing to stop.

questions.explanation: This hand signal tells other road users that the cyclist intends to proceed straight ahead at a junction and drivers should show caution.

questions.text: What does this hand signal mean?

options.text: The cyclist intends to stop.
The cyclist intends to dismount.
The cyclist intends to overtake.
The cyclist intends to turn left.

questions.explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the cyclist intends to make a left-hand turn.

questions.text: What does this hand signal mean?

options.text: The cyclist intends to slow down.
The cyclist intends to stop for pedestrians.
The cyclist intends to turn to her left.
The cyclist intends to turn right.

questions.explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the cyclist intends to make a right-hand turn.

questions.text: What does this hand signal mean?

options.text: The cyclist intends to stop.
The cyclist intends to turn left.
The cyclist is signaling you to stop.
The cyclist intends to cross the road.

questions.explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the cyclist intends to turn left.

questions.text: What does this hand signal mean?

options.text: The driver intends to yield to oncoming traffic.
The driver intends to slow down or stop.
The driver intends to turn left.
The driver intends to turn right.

questions.explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the driver intends to turn left and the vehicle will change direction.

questions.text: What does this hand signal mean?

options.text: The driver intends to turn left.
The driver intends to move out or turn right.
The driver intends to do a 'U'-turn.
The driver intends to stop.

questions.explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the driver intends to move out or turn right and the vehicle will change direction.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Cul-de-sac ahead.
No hard shoulder ahead.
No entry.
Parking not allowed ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you that you must not proceed in the direction of the arrow. This is displayed to prevent traffic going in the wrong direction - for example, the wrong way up a one-way street.

questions.text: What does this hand signal mean?

options.text: The driver intends to turn left.
The driver intends to turn right.
The driver intends to begin a 'U'-turn.
The driver intends to slow down or stop.

questions.explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the driver intends to slow down or stop and following traffic should be prepared to slow down also.

questions.text: What does this hand signal mean?

options.text: The driver intends to perform a reverse maneuver.
The driver intends to turn left.
The driver intends to telling you to turn right.
The driver is indicating an emergency situation.

questions.explanation: This hand signal informs other road users or a garda directing traffic (facing this vehicle), that the driver intends to make a left hand turn.

questions.text: What does this hand signal mean?

options.text: The driver intends to perform a reverse maneuver.
The driver intends to turn right.
The driver intends to slow down or stop.
The driver is telling other drivers to slow down.

questions.explanation: This hand signal informs other road users or a garda directing traffic (facing this vehicle), that the driver intends to turn right.

questions.text: What does this hand signal mean?

options.text: The driver is signaling you to proceed.
The driver intends to reverse.
The driver intends to move straight ahead.
The driver intends to stop.

questions.explanation: This hand signal informs other road users or a garda directing traffic that the driver intends to proceed straight ahead.

questions.text: What does this Garda signal mean?

options.text: Stop if approaching from the front.
Proceed if approaching from the front.
Stop if approaching from behind.
Proceed if approaching from behind.

questions.explanation: When approaching a garda giving this signal you must stop.

questions.text: What does this Garda signal mean?

options.text: Stop if approaching from behind.
Turn right.
Turn left.
Stop if approaching from front.

questions.explanation: When approaching a garda giving this signal you must stop.

questions.text: What does this Garda signal mean?

options.text: Proceed if approaching from the front.
Turn right.
Turn left.
Stop if approaching from either the front or behind.

questions.explanation: When approaching a garda giving this signal you must stop.

questions.text: What does this Garda signal mean?

options.text: The Garda is beckoning on traffic approaching from the front.
You must not proceed to the right.
The Garda is beckoning on traffic approaching from either side.
You must not proceed to the left.

questions.explanation: When approaching a garda giving this signal you may proceed.

questions.text: What does this Garda signal mean?

options.text: Traffic approaching from the front may proceed.
Traffic approaching from behind may proceed.
Traffic approaching from the left may proceed.
Traffic approaching from the right may proceed.

questions.explanation: When approaching a garda giving this signal you may proceed.

questions.text: What does this road marking indicate?

options.text: Pedestrian island ahead.
Cycle lane ahead.
Zebra crossing.
Traffic-calming ahead.

questions.explanation: A zebra crossing is a designated area for pedrestrians to cross the road. As a driver you must always yield to pedestrians on a zebra crossing.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: No right turn.
Yield to other traffic when turning right.
Turn right if there is no oncoming traffic.
No hard shoulder to the right.

questions.explanation: This sign is displayed at a junction where you may not turn right.

questions.text: What does this road marking mean?

options.text: No parking in this area.
Road surface is uneven.
You may park for a maximum of one hour only.
You may overtake if the road is clear ahead.

questions.explanation: White zig zag lines indicate that you are approaching a pedrestrian crossing. You must not park or overtake within this area.

questions.text: What does this road marking mean?

options.text: You have right-of-way over traffic from both right and left.
Traffic from right and left have the right-of-way.
Taxi pick-up area.
A driver must not enter unless turning right or the exit is clear.

questions.explanation: You must not enter the yellow box junction unless you can clear it without stopping or unless you are turning and are prevented from doing so by oncoming traffic.

questions.text: What does this road marking mean?

options.text: You may overtake.
A driver must not cross the line.
You are approaching a stop sign.
Road narrows ahead.

questions.explanation: Where there is a continuous white line in the centre of the road, you are not permitted to: 1. Straddle or cross the white line; 2. Overtake another vehicle; 3. Perform a U-turn; 4. Park on the road at this point.

questions.text: What do white arrows painted on the road indicate?

options.text: The lane drivers should use for the direction they intent to take.
Left and right-hand lanes are for buses only.
Heavy vehicles should separate from lighter traffic.
Traffic flow divides at roadworks ahead.

questions.explanation: When approaching a junction you must select the appropriate lane for the direction you want to go.The appropriate lane may be marked by directional arrows. Make sure you cahange lane only when its safe to do so.

questions.text: What does this road marking and information plate together mean?

options.text: Parking not allowed at the times shown.
Parking only at times shown.
Taxi parking only outside the times shown.
Taxi parking only at the times shown.

questions.explanation: A single yellow line along the edge of a road means that you must not park there during the times shown on the accompanying information plate.

questions.text: What does this road marking mean?

options.text: A driver must not cross the broken white line unless it is safe to do so.
You may not overtake.
You may overtake provided you do not cross the broken white line.
You may not perform a reverse maneuver.

questions.explanation: A broken white line along the centre of the road means you must not cross the line unless it is safe to do so when overtaking or passing.

questions.text: What could this road marking mean?

options.text: All traffic must keep to the left of the broken white lines.
Dual-carriageway ahead.
Continuous white line lies ahead.
You are approaching a stop sign.

questions.explanation: Double broken white lines along the centre of the road alert you to continuous white lines ahead.Do not cross them unless it is safe to do so.

questions.text: If driving from A to B, what do these road markings mean?

options.text: A driver may cross the continuous white line only when performing a 'U'-turn.
A driver may not overtake, only motorcyclists may cross the continuous white line.
A driver may not overtake by crossing the continuous white line.
A driver may overtake if it is safe to do so.

questions.explanation: Where there is broken white line and a continuous white line along the centre of the road, you must obey the line that is nearest to you. In this case you may cross the lines as long as it is safe to do so.

questions.text: If driving from A to B, what do these road markings mean?

options.text: A driver may overtake by crossing the continuous white line.
A driver may not cross the lines to overtake.
A driver may not overtake.
Only motorcyclists may overtake crossing the continuous white line.

questions.explanation: Where there is a broken white line and a continuous white line along the centre of the road, you must obey the line that is nearest to you. In this case you may not cross the lines.

questions.text: What does this road marking mean?

options.text: No entry.
The road ahead is a cul-de-sac.
Pedestrian crossing.
Private vehicles not allowed.

questions.explanation: This road marking indicates the 'wrong' end of a one-way street. You may enter this street.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Roundabout ahead with no left exit.
Cul-de-sac to the left.
No hard shoulder to the left.
No left turn.

questions.explanation: This sign is displayed at a junction where you may not turn left.

questions.text: What does this road marking mean?

options.text: Parking prohibited at all times.
Parking prohibited during business hours.
Tax parking only.
Keep outside the yellow lines.

questions.explanation: A double yellow line along the edge of the road means parking is not allowed at any time.

questions.text: What does the broken yellow line road marking mean?

options.text: Lay-by ahead.
No stopping for any reason except in an emergency.
Slow lane for heavy vehicles only.
The edge of the carriageway or hard shoulder.

questions.explanation: A single broken yellow line along the side of the road marks the edge of the carriageway/hard shoulder. This is normally for the use of pedestrians and cyclists. As a driver, however, you may use it briefly to allow faster traffic to overtake, but only where it is safe to do so.

questions.text: What does this traffic light mean?

options.text: Stop, unless it would be unsafe to do so.
Stop.
Proceed if the way is clear.
Prepare to move off.

questions.explanation: When the traffic light is showing amber you must not go beyond the stop line unless your so close to the traffic lights that stopping would be dangerous.

questions.text: What does this traffic light mean?

options.text: Traffic is not allowed to turn right.
The driver may proceed in the direction of the green arrow if the way is clear.
All traffic must turn right.
You must stop and wait until the full green light appears.

questions.explanation: A green arrow (filter light) means that traffic may proceed in the direction of the arrow if it is safe to do so.

questions.text: What does this traffic light mean?

options.text: Traffic is not allowed to turn left.
All traffic must turn left only.
Left turning traffic may proceed if the way is clear.
Traffic turning left should prepare for full green to move off.

questions.explanation: A green arrow (filter light) means that traffic may proceed in the direction of the arrow if it is safe to do so.

questions.text: What does this traffic light mean?

options.text: You may proceed.
Traffic must stop at the traffic light.
You may proceed if you can do so safely.
You may stop if you can do so safely.

questions.explanation: A red light means STOP. You must not go beyond the stop line or (if there is no stop line) beyond the light.

questions.text: What does this traffic light mean?

options.text: You must give way to any oncoming traffic turning right.
You must stop.
Traffic may proceed if the way is clear.
You may proceed but not turn right.

questions.explanation: You may proceed on a green traffic light if it is safe to do so.

questions.text: What colour traffic light comes on after the green?

options.text: Flashing amber.
Green arrow.
Amber only.
Red only.

questions.explanation: The normal sequence of traffic lights is red-green-amber.

questions.text: When traffic lights are green, when should a driver not proceed?

options.text: Buses are stopped waiting to turn from the road on you right.
When by doing so, your vehicle blocks the junction.
Buses are stopped waiting to turn from the road on your left.
Oncoming traffic is waiting to make a left turn.

questions.explanation: Although a green traffic light means proceed with caution, you should not enter a junction if the way is not clear or by doing so you would cause an obstruction to other road users.

questions.text: What does a flashing left amber arrow at a traffic light mean?

options.text: A driver may turn left but yield to traffic on the other road.
A driver may turn left if the green light is also shown.
A driver may turn left.
A driver may proceed straight ahead.

questions.explanation: A flashing amber arrow at a junction means you may proceed left but must give way to pedestrians and traffic already coming through the junction on the other road.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: U-turn not permitted.
Reversing not permitted.
Slippery road ahead.
Two-way traffic prohibited.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you that you are not permitted to make a U-turn. It is displayed at junctions on dual carriageways. U-turns are also not permitted anywhere there is a continuous white line along the centre of the road or on a one-way street.

questions.text: What colour traffic light comes on after a non-flashing amber light?

options.text: Green only.
Flashing blue light.
Red or Green.
Red only.

questions.explanation: The normal sequence of traffic lights is red-green-amber.

questions.text: What do flashing amber lights at a pelican crossing mean?

options.text: Stop and give way to pedestrians - proceed if the way is clear.
You are entering a special speed limit area.
Danger ahead - you must stop and wait until they stop flashing.
Drivers have right-of-way.

questions.explanation: A flashing amber light at a pelican crossing means you must yield to pedestrians. You may proceed, however, if the crossing is clear.

questions.text: What is the maximum permissible speed for cars or motorcycles on motorways?

options.text: 60 km/h.
80 km/h.

questions.explanation: It is illegal to exceed 120km/h when driving on a motorway.

questions.text: What is the maximum permissible speed for cars or motorcycles on single carriageway national roads?

options.text: 60 km/h.
80 km/h.

questions.explanation: It is illegal to exceed 100km/h when driving on a single carriage way on national road.

questions.text: What is the maximum permissible speed of a car towing a caravan on national roads?

options.text: 80 km/h.
60 km/h.

questions.explanation: When towing a caravan on a national road,it is illegal to exceed 80km/kh - excessive speed will make such a vehicle unstable.

questions.text: What is the maximum permissible speed of a car towing a caravan on a motorway?

options.text: 90 km/h.
80 km/h.

questions.explanation: When towing a caravan on a motorway,it is illegal to exceed 80km/kh - excessive speed will make such a vehicle unstable.

questions.text: Where must a driver not park?

options.text: Where there is a continuous white along the centre of the road.
Where there is a broken white line along the centre of the road.
Where there are two broken white lines along the centre of the road.
On a single yellow line outside the times indicated.

questions.explanation: It is offence to park at the side of road that has a single or double continuous white line along its centre. Parking on such a road could create an obstruction and may cause inconvenience or danger to other road users.

questions.text: What distance before a zebra crossing is parking prohibited?

options.text: 5 meters.
15 meters.
10 meters.
20 meters.
