questions.text: What is the minimum safe distance to leave between vehicles travelling at 100 km/h on a dry road?

options.text: 92 metres.
72 metres.
62 metres.
82 metres.

questions.explanation: The figure of 62 metres is based on the two-second rule. If you follow the two-second rule, you will leave approximately 1 metre between you and the vehicle in front for every 1.6 km/h of your speed.

questions.text: What is a likely consequence of sudden braking?

options.text: The vehicle's braking system could overheat.
The vehicle's braking system could lose a lot of air.
The vehicle's braking system could lose a lot of fluid.
The vehicle could be hit from behind.

questions.explanation: As well as reading the road ahead, you should also be aware of traffic coming behind you. This will help you react correctly in a situation where you need to brake suddenly.

questions.text: Which of the following affects the braking distance of a vehicle?

options.text: The power of the vehicle.
The speed and weight of the vehicle.
Road conditions and the tyres on the vehicle.
The number of passengers carried.

questions.explanation: The overall stopping distance of your vehicle depends on its speed and weight — faster and heavier vehicles require greater stopping distances.

questions.text: In dry weather how might a driver judge what is a safe following distance to vehicle in front?

options.text: By driving at the same speed as the vehicle in front.
By allowing at least two seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and the drivers own vehicle passing a fixed point.
By allowing at least 2 vehicle lengths for each kilometer per hour.
By allowing at least 2 vehicle lengths between the vehicles.

questions.explanation: You should maintain a gap of at least two seconds from the vehicle in front — that's the two-second rule.

questions.text: In wet weather how might a driver judge what is a safe following distance from the vehicle in front?

options.text: By allowing at least four seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and the drivers own vehicle passing a fixed point.
By driving at the same speed as the vehicle in front.
By allowing 4 vehicle lengths between the vehicles.
By allowing 2 seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and your vehicle passing a fixed point.

questions.explanation: In wet conditions you should maintain a gap of at least four seconds from the vehicle in front — twice as long as in dry conditions.

questions.text: What phrase is recommended for drivers to help them determine a ‘safe headway’ distance from the vehicle in front on a dry road?

options.text: Only a fool breaks the one second rule.
Only a fool breaks the four second rule.
Only a fool breaks the two second rule.
Only a fool breaks the ten second rule.

questions.explanation: You should maintain a gap of least two seconds from the vehicle in front — that's the two-second rule.

questions.text: What effect does carrying a load have on a vehicle’s braking ability?

options.text: It increases the efficiency of the brakes.
It increases the distance required to stop.
It has no effect provided the brakes are in good condition.
It reduces the distance required to stop.

questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle which is carrying a load, the driver should be aware that the forces acting on the load under braking will increase the distance required to stop.

questions.text: What effect does towing a loaded trailer have on stopping ability?

options.text: It significantly increases stopping distance.
It has no effect.
It significantly reduces stopping distance.
It increases the efficiency of the brakes.

questions.explanation: If you are towing a loaded trailer, you need to be aware that your braking distance could be considerably greater. depending on the weight and size of the trailer.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Double parking not allowed.
No stopping/parking on the right.
No overtaking.
End of dual carriageway.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you that overtaking is prohibited in this area because it is dangerous to do so.

questions.text: What should a driver do when overtaking a large vehicle that is throwing up spray?

options.text: Speed up and drive faster.
Nothing is has no effect.
Move out earlier than normal and give extra clearance.
Drive on high beam headlights only.

questions.explanation: In wet weather vehicles throw up spray and muck from the road. If you are overtaking a large vehicle in wet conditions, you need to move out earlier than normal and give yourself some extra clearance room. This will help reduce the amount of spray on your windscreen.

questions.text: What should a driver do when driving in dense fog?

options.text: Drive with dipped headlights and fog lights.
Drive on sidelights only.
Drive on high beam headlights only.
Drive on sidelights and hazard warning lights.

questions.explanation: In dense fog you should use dipped headlights and fog lights (where fitted). Sidelights are not strong enough in fog. and full headlights can reflect off the fog and make it harder to see where you are going.

questions.text: What should a driver do when driving in dense fog?

options.text: Drive along the shoulder and watch for reflective markers.
Reduce speed and use dipped headlights.
Switch on you full headlights and drive slowly.
Drive along the central dividing line and watch for the reflective studs.

questions.explanation: In dense fog you should reduce your speed and use dipped headlights and fog lights (where fitted). Sidelights are not strong enough in fog, and full headlights can reflect off the fog and make it harder to see where you are going.

questions.text: When driving at night the full headlights should enable the driver to see for a distance of how many metres?

options.text: 100 metres.
150 metres.
200 metres.
250 metres.

questions.explanation: At night in good driving conditions the full headlights of a car will typically let you see 100 metres ahead. So, you should travel at a speed that allows you to stop within that distance.

questions.text: When driving at night the dipped headlights should enable the driver to see for a distance of how many metres?

options.text: 60 metres.
20 metres.
10 metres.
30 metres.

questions.explanation: When driving at night in good driving conditions the dipped headlights of a car will typically let you see 30 metres ahead. So, you should travel at a speed that allows you to stop in that distance.

questions.text: What effect could incorrectly adjusted headlights have?

options.text: Increase the stopping distance.
Reduces the wattage of the headlights.
Oncoming road users could be dazzled.
Causes the headlights to overheat.

questions.explanation: You are responsible for making sure that your vehicle is roadworthy and that its headlights are adjusted correctly. If the headlights are out of line they are less effective and may dazzle oncoming traffic, even when dipped.

questions.text: When driving at night, when must a driver dip the vehicle’s full headlights?

options.text: When meeting or driving behind other traffic.
Approaching a bend or the brow of a hill.
Driving at less than 50 km/h.
Entering a motorway.

questions.explanation: When driving at night you should dip your headlights when you meet oncoming vehicles so that you do not dazzle them. You should also dip your headlights when you are driving behind another vehicle so the driver is not dazzled by your lights in their mirror.

questions.text: When driving at night and blinded by the lights of an oncoming vehicle, what should a driver do?

options.text: Repeatedly flash their headlights until the oncoming vehicle's lights are dipped.
Look away and slow down and stop if necessary.
Drive well to the left and maintain their speed.
Reduce speed and switch on their full headlights.

questions.explanation: If you are dazzled by the lights of an oncoming vehicle, look towards the verge until the vehicle has passed. Slow down and stop if necessary.

questions.text: A driver has been driving regularly in daylight and must now undertake a journey at night. What should the driver do?

options.text: Drive at a higher speed than during the day as traffic is lighter at night.
Drive at a higher speed than during the day to minimize chances of falling asleep.
Drive at a slower speed than in the day as visibility is reduced at night.
Drive at the same speed as during the day.

questions.explanation: If you are not very used to driving at nighttime, it can take quite a while to adjust to conditions at night For that reason, you might need to drive slower until you get used to the reduced visibility at night.

questions.text: What should a driver do when driving at night?

options.text: Drive at a speed that enables the driver to stop within the distance ahead that they can see to be clear.
Increase their speed as traffic is lighter at night.
Turn up the radio volume to help maintain their concentration.
Drive at a higher speed than during the day to minimize chances of falling asleep.

questions.explanation: When driving at night in good driving conditions the full headlights of a car will typically let you see 100 metres ahead. So, you should travel at a speed that allows you to stop in that distance.

questions.text: What does these signs together mean?

options.text: Only buses, cyclists and taxis are allowed to use the lane during the hours indicated.
Outside the times indicated, only buses and, cyclist may use this lane.
Only cyclists and buses are allowed to use the lane during the hours indicated.
Only buses and cyclists may park during the times indicated.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you there is a with-flow bus lane ahead - that is, one where the buses move in the same direction as the traffic to their right. The information plate tells the times when the bus lane in operation. Only buses, taxis and cyclists may use the bus lane during those hours.

questions.text: When driving at night, what is the safest approach for a driver to adopt?

options.text: Drive at a speed that enables the driver to stop within the distance ahead that they can see to be clear.
Drive with dipped headlights at all times.
Drive with full headlights at all times.
Drive with full headlights and spotlights.

questions.explanation: When driving at night in good driving conditions the dipped headlights of a car will typically let you see 30 metres ahead. So, you should travel at a speed that allows you to stop in that distance.

questions.text: When meeting an oncoming vehicle at night, what should a driver do?

options.text: Focus their eyes directly on its lights.
Not look directly at the oncoming vehicle's lights.
Look down at the dash until it has passed so as not to be dazzled by its lights.
Focus their eyes toward the passenger's window.

questions.explanation: If you are dazzled by the lights of an oncoming vehicle, look towards the verge until the vehicle has passed and /or slow down and stop if necessary.

questions.text: When may a driver use full headlights when driving at night?

options.text: Between the hours of 1.00 a.m. and 6.00 a.m.
When there is no oncoming traffic.
Between the hours of 11:30 p.m. and 7.00 a.m.
Only on main roads.

questions.explanation: You should use full headlights when driving at night in unlit rural areas — this will enable you to see as far ahead as possible. Make sure, however, that your lights do not dazzle or inconvenience other road users in any way.

questions.text: What lights should a driver have on when driving close behind other traffic at night?

options.text: Dipped headlights.
Full headlights.
Fog lights.
Sidelights.

questions.explanation: When driving at night you should dip your headlights when you meet oncoming vehicles so that you do not dazzle them. You should also dip your headlights when you are driving behind another vehicle so the driver is not dazzled by your lights in their mirror.

questions.text: When must a driver use dipped headlights?

options.text: When approaching roadworks.
When driving at less than 50 km/h.
When approaching a bend or the brow of a hill.
When meeting or driving behind other traffic.

questions.explanation: When driving at night you should dip your headlights when meeting or following traffic so as not to dazzle or blind other drivers.

questions.text: When driving late at night what should a driver be aware of?

options.text: That reflectorised studs will warn you of bends ahead.
That there is a danger of falling asleep.
Trucks may drive in the outer lane of a motorway.
That speed limits do not apply between midnight and 6 a.m.

questions.explanation: Driving when you are tired can be very dangerous, and tiredness is one of the main causes of serious road collisions. If you become drowsy while driving, stop in a safe place and take a short nap. Then get some fresh air and stretch your legs for a few minutes before setting off again. Taking a caffeine-based drink such as coffee may also help.

questions.text: What should a driver do if dazzled by the lights of an oncoming vehicle at night?

options.text: Look directly at the lights of the oncoming vehicle.
Turn your head to one side.
Shield your eyes with your hand.
Do not look directly at the lights.

questions.explanation: If you are dazzled by the lights of an oncoming vehicle, look towards the verge until the vehicle has passed and /or slow down and stop if necessary.

questions.text: When driving at night, a single headlight approaches from ahead. What should a driver do?

options.text: Carry on because it can only be a motorcycle.
Be aware it may be a four-wheeled vehicle.
Switch on your high beams as a warning.
Move to the centre of the road to improve your visibility of the oncoming vehicle.

questions.explanation: When you see a single oncoming headlight at night, you need to be aware that it might not be a motorcycle — it could be a car or a van with a broken headlight.

questions.text: How might a driver know if there is black ice on the road?

options.text: Tyre pressure will seem heavier.
Steering will be heavy.
There will be louder tyre noise on the road.
There will be a decrease in road noise in the vehicle.

questions.explanation: One of the signs that you might be driving on black ice is a sudden decrease in the level of the road noise. This is due to the lack of grip of between the tyres and the road. Another sign is that the steering will seem lighter than normal. If you suspect you are driving on black ice, you should avoid harsh braking, steering and acceleration. This will reduce the risk of skidding.

questions.text: How might a driver know if there is black ice on the road?

options.text: Use a low gear.
Drive with the choke on until you have cleared the area.
Steering will seem lighter.
Increase tyre pressure to improve stability.

questions.explanation: One of the signs that you might be driving on black ice is a sudden decrease in the level of the road noise. This is due to the lack of grip of between the tyres and the road. Another sign is that the steering will seem lighter than normal. If you suspect you are driving on black ice, you should avoid harsh braking, steering and acceleration. This will reduce the risk of skidding.

questions.text: What does this sign mean at a junction?

options.text: Yield to all heavy goods vehicles.
Slow down and stop for pedestrians.
Yield to traffic on the major road.
Yield to traffic coming from your right.

questions.explanation: At a junction, the YIELD sign tells you that you must give way to traffic on a major road ahead. This means that you must slow down and be prepared to stop.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: With-flow' bus lane ahead on your left.
Cyclist and buses must turn left.
Only buses and cyclist may park.
Only buses and cyclists may use the lane.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you there is a with-flow bus lane ahead to your left. Only buses, taxis and cyclists may use the bus lane during the stated operational hours.

questions.text: What should a driver do if there is black ice on the road?

options.text: Drive after rain in darkness.
Avoid harsh braking. steering and acceleration.
Drive in mild weather after rain.
Drive after wet and windy weather.

questions.explanation: One of the signs that you might be driving on black ice is a sudden decrease in the level of the road noise. This is due to the lack of grip of between the tyres and the road. Another sign is that the steering will seem lighter than normal. If you suspect you are driving on black ice, you should avoid harsh braking, steering and acceleration. This will reduce the risk of skidding.

questions.text: When is black ice likely to occur on the road?

options.text: In cold weather after rain.
In cold weather.
During winter.
Just before dawn.

questions.explanation: Black ice occurs when moisture freezes on a very cold surface. Exposed roads and bridges can have black ice when other sections of the same road may be clear. Black ice is virtually invisible, and so presents a particular hazard for motorcyclists and drivers. In wintry conditions, if you notice a reduction in tyre noise or if the steering becomes lighter, you should suspect that there may be black ice on the road.

questions.text: What is the safest practice when driving on icy roads?

options.text: Apply the brakes regularly in order to improve tyre grip.
Drive at a slower speed than usual using gentle acceleration and braking.
Accelerate harder using the lower gears.
Drive slower than normal and do not use the brakes.

questions.explanation: When driving on icy roads you should avoid harsh braking, steering and acceleration. This will help reduce the risk of skidding.

questions.text: When driving a vehicle, what effect could icy roads have?

options.text: Front tyre treads could wear out more rapidly.
Tyre grip could improve.
Rear tyre treads could wear out more rapidly.
The vehicle could skid more easily than normal.

questions.explanation: Icy roads can have a dramatic effect on the way a vehicle handles, and there can be an increased risk of skidding. When driving on icy roads you should avoid harsh braking, steering and acceleration. This will help reduce the risk of skidding.

questions.text: What should a driver do when driving in slippery road conditions?

options.text: Press the clutch only.
Press the clutch and brake together.
Engage neutral gear position.
Use gentle acceleration and braking.

questions.explanation: Your tyres have less grip on the road when it is wet or icy. Slow down in slippery' conditions, and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

questions.text: How should a driver negotiate a bend when the road is slippery?

options.text: Press the clutch and brake together.
Drive slowly and smoothly.
Engage neutral gear position.
Press the clutch only.

questions.explanation: Be extra careful when negotiating bends in slippery conditions. Slow down gently on the approach, select the appropriate gear for the speed of the vehicle and use gentle steering and acceleration to drive around the bend. Avoid braking in the bend as this may cause the vehicle to become unstable and cause a skid.

questions.text: Apart from the risk of skidding, what danger may arise when driving in snow?

options.text: Road signs and road markings may become obscured.
It maybe colder.
The travelling distance may seem shorter.
Apart from the risk of skidding no other dangers arise.

questions.explanation: Road signs and road markings may become obscured by snow. If this happens you may have difficulty reading regulatory, warning and information signs. This is the main reason why these signs are different shapes. Drivers should pay particular attention in these conditions.

questions.text: What should a driver do when driving in heavy rain?

options.text: Speed up so that the vehicle will glide over any standing water.
Be in the alert for skidding or aquaplaning .
Weave the vehicle slightly from side to side in order to improve tyre grip.
Maintain normal speeds as on dry road.

questions.explanation: On a wet road, a film of water can build up between the tyres and the road surface. This is called 'aquaplaning and it has the effect of reducing the grip of the tyres on the road, and this affects your steering and braking. For these reasons you should  slow down during and after rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

questions.text: What is the danger in driving with badly worn tyres at high speed on wet roads?

options.text: Control of the vehicle is reduced because it is gliding on a film of water.
Air pressure in the tyres is reduced.
There is no danger provided the tyres are at the correct pressure.
There is no danger provided the tyre pressure had been reduced to account for the worn tread.

questions.explanation: Worn tyres will reduce a vehicle's grip on the road. This becomes more noticeable on wet roads. As tyres become worn their ability to channel away the water between the tyre and the road diminishes. The minimum legal tread depth for motorcycles is 1mm and 1.6mm for other vehicles.  However tyres should be replaced before they become this worn.

questions.text: What should a driver do when they encounter mud on the road?

options.text: Apply the brakes immediately.
Change to a lower gear and carry on.
Reduce speed and be aware of the farm or works vehicles on the road.
Gently increase speed to prevent mud from sticking to tyres.

questions.explanation: Where there is mud on the road you should slow down and be aware that there is a danger of skidding. Your stopping distance will also be greater where there is mud on the road.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: With 'flow' bus and cycle lane on the left
Parking for buses and cyclists on the left.
Cycle-track ahead may be crossed by buses only.
Cyclists and buses not allowed ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign indicates a with flow bus lane ahead. Only buses, taxis and cyclists may use the bus lane during the stated operational hours.

questions.text: What should a driver be aware of when crossing tram lines at an angle?

options.text: Be aware that tyre grip is reduced on the lines.
Depress the clutch pedal and 'coast' across.
Be aware that the wheels could get caught in the lines.
Be aware that tyre grip is improved on the lines.

questions.explanation: Tyre grip may be reduced when you cross tram lines, especially in icy or wet conditions. As you approach tram lines, you should slow down, avoid harsh acceleration or sudden braking, and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front Be extra careful when there are vulnerable road users such as pedestrians and cyclists using the crossing.

questions.text: What should a driver be aware of when crossing road markings such as lines or arrows?

options.text: Steering control is improved.
Tyre grip is improved.
A.B.S will prevent the vehicle from skidding.
Tyre grip is reduced.

questions.explanation: Tyre grip is reduced when you are crossing road markings such as arrows and lines, and you should be extra careful when driving over these in wet conditions.

questions.text: What should a driver do after passing through a flooded section of road?

options.text: Apply the brake pedal lightly at slow speed for a short distance to dry the brakes.
Do nothing.
Apply the brakes firmly to check if they are still effective.
Drive faster for a time in order to dry out your brakes.

questions.explanation: When you drive through a flooded section of road, your brakes may become less effective. If this happens, test your brakes to ensure that they have not been affected by the water — check in your mirrors before you do this. If they have been affected (and this is more than likely just temporary), press gently on the brake pedal as you are driving until they dry out and return to normal.

questions.text: What should a driver do when they approach roadworks warning signs?

options.text: Reduce speed and be prepared to stop for works vehicles or a flagman.
Increase speed in order to avoid getting stuck in soft ground.
Maintain your speed until signalled to do otherwise by flagman.
Engage a lower gear to improve grip and maintain your speed.

questions.explanation: You should always approach roadworks with caution as there are many possible hazards to deal with — including road workers, works vehicles, uneven road surfaces and temporary traffic controls.

questions.text: What should a driver be aware of when driving through a section of road where roadworks are ongoing?

options.text: Traffic is likely to travel much faster.
The driver has right of way over earthmoving machinery.
That the area will be cleared for you and you should not delay.
That the surface may be slippery due to mud or loose chippings.

questions.explanation: When you are travelling through a section of roadworks, you need to be extra careful, as the road surface may be uneven or slippery or there may be loose chippings. all of which can affect road holding.

questions.text: When driving on a one-way street and wishing to turn right, what should a driver do?

options.text: Drive close to the centre line of the road while indicating right.
Drive close to the left-hand-side of the road.
Drive close to the right-hand side of the road.
Drive close to the centre line of the road.

questions.explanation: When driving on a one-way street, you should normally keep to the left. When you want to turn right you should check your mirrors, signal right and manoeuvre into the right-hand side when it is safe to do so. Then complete the turn into the appropriate lane of the street you are entering.

questions.text: When driving on a one-way street and wishing to turn right up ahead, what should a driver do?

options.text: Move to the right-hand side in good time.
Drive on the left until you are close to the turn before taking up position on the right.
Drive close to the centre of the road.
Continue in the lane you are in.

questions.explanation: When driving on a one-way street you should normally keep to the left. When you want to turn right you should check your mirrors, signal right and manoeuvre into the right-hand side when it is safe to do so. Then complete the turn into the appropriate lane of the street you are entering.

questions.text: When a driver wants to turn left into a property and there is a bus lane on the left, what should the driver do?

options.text: Watch out for buses only.
Watch out for cyclists, taxis and buses which may be using the bus lane.
Use a 'slowing down' hand signal in addition to your left turn indicator.
Not turn left across a bus lane.

questions.explanation: If you need to cross a bus lane on your left in order to enter a property, you should take extra care that there are no buses, taxis or cyclists in the bus lane. Check your mirrors, signal and turn into the property when it is safe to do so.

questions.text: What traffic may use a contra-flow bus lane?

options.text: Buses, taxis and motorcycles.
Buses on a scheduled service.
Buses, taxis and cyclists.
Buses and taxis.

questions.explanation: A bus lane is a special lane for the use of buses. A with flow bus lane is one that runs in the same direction as the traffic. A contra-flow bus lane is one that runs in the opposite direction to traffic beside it. Only buses on a scheduled service may use a contra-flow bus lane.

questions.text: What traffic may use a with-flow bus lane during the specified times?

options.text: Buses, taxis and cyclists.
Buses only.
All traffic.
Vehicles with more than one passenger.

questions.explanation: A bus lane is a special lane for the use of buses. A 'with-flow' bus lane is one that runs in the same direction as the traffic beside it. Taxis and cyclists may also use with-flow bus lanes. Other traffic may use them outside the hours posted on the accompanying plate.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Cyclist must give way to buses ahead.
Bus and cycle lane ahead on the right.
Buses must give way to cyclists ahead.
Buses must give way to other traffic ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you that there is a bus lane ahead to the right. Only buses, taxis and cyclists may use the bus lane during the stated operational hours.

questions.text: When may a driver drive (other than a bus or taxi driver) in a with-flow bus lane?

options.text: During the hours specified on the bus lane information plate.
After a bus has gone through on it.
After 9 p.m.
Outside the hours specified on the bus lane information plate.

questions.explanation: A bus lane is a special lane for the use of buses. A 'with-flow bus lane is one that runs in the same direction as the traffic beside it. Taxis and cyclists may also use with-flow bus lanes. Other traffic may use them outside the hours posted on the accompanying plate.

questions.text: When driving along a dual carriageway, what lane position should a driver be in?

options.text: On the right-hand lane, except when driving a tractor or works vehicle.
On either lane of their choice.
In the left-hand lane unless the driver wishes to overtake or turn right .
On the right-hand lane.

questions.explanation: You must normally drive in the left-hand lane of a dual carriageway, except when overtaking or turning right a short distance ahead.

questions.text: When turning right from a minor road onto a dual carriageway with a wide median strip, what should a driver do?

options.text: When clear on the right, proceed to the central median and then wait until it is clear on the left before proceeding.
Not drive onto the dual-carriageway until there is a suitable gap in the traffic from both directions.
Not turn right onto a dual-carriageway.
Not halt on the median strip.

questions.explanation: If you wish to turn right onto a dual carriageway from a minor road and the central median is big enough, you may complete the manoeuvre in two stages: 1. Wait until it is clear on the right, and proceed to the central median: 2. Wait in the central median until it is clear from the left, and then complete the turn.

questions.text: When turning right from a minor road onto a dual carriageway with a narrow median strip, what should a driver do?

options.text: When the nearest carriageway is clear, drive on to the median strip and wait.
Stop on the narrow median strip before proceeding.
The driver should not turn right onto a dual-carriageway.
Wait on the minor road until there is a suitable gap in the traffic from both directions.

questions.explanation: If you wish to turn right onto a dual carriageway from a minor road and the central median is not big enough to accommodate your vehicle, you should wait on the minor road until it is clear from both sides of the road before completing the turn.

questions.text: What does a 2-plus-1 road have?

options.text: Two non-motorway lanes in one direction and one non-motorway lane in the opposite direction.
Two motorway lanes and one non-motorway lane, in two directions.
Two non-motorway lanes and one motorway lane, in two directions.
Two motorway lanes in one direction and one non-motorway lane in the opposite direction.

questions.explanation: A '2-plus-1' road consists of two lanes in one direction of travel and one lane in the other direction. The two-lane section allows for safe overtaking and alternates with a one-lane section roughly every 2 kilometres.

questions.text: On a 2-plus-1 road, where must a driver only turn right?

options.text: When in the one-lane stretch.
At controlled junctions.
When in the two-lane stretch.
When directed by a pointsman.

questions.explanation: A '2-plus-1' road consists of two lanes in one direction of travel and one lane in the other direction. The two-lane section allows for safe overtaking and alternates with a one-lane section roughly every 2 kilometres. Where there are safety barriers separating the two direction of traffic, you may turn right only at controlled junctions.

questions.text: What does a 2-plus-1 road have?

options.text: Barriers between lanes of traffic going in the same direction.
Barriers between the hard shoulder and the verge.
Two lanes for cars and one lane for trucks and buses.
Two lanes of traffic in one direction and one in the opposite direction.

questions.explanation: A '2—plus-1' road consists of two lanes in one direction of travel and one lane in the other direction. The two-lane section allows for safe overtaking and alternates with a one-lane section roughly every 2 kilometres.

questions.text: Where may a driver overtake on a 2-plus-1 road?

options.text: In the one-lane stretch if there is no oncoming traffic, and in the two-lane stretch.
In either the one-lane stretch or the two-lane stretch.
In the two-lane stretch.
In the one-lane stretch.

questions.explanation: A '2-plus-1' road consists of two lanes in one direction of travel and one lane in the other direction. When you need to overtake, you should wait until you reach the 2-lane section which occurs approximately every 2 kilometres.

questions.text: What should a driver do when travelling on a motorway or dual carriageway?

options.text: Be alert for other drivers who may suddenly change lanes or reduce speed.
Match your speed to that of the vehicle in front.
Match your speed to that of the vehicle in the adjoining lane.
Relax because there will be no oncoming or crossing traffic.

questions.explanation: Motorways and dual carriageways are designed to help traffic travel faster and more safely between destinations. Traffic conditions can change very quickly because of the speed and increased volumes of traffic and lanes, and you need to be particular alert to other drivers changing lanes to other drivers changing lanes or reducing speed.

questions.text: When driving on a motorway, what should a driver do?

options.text: Drive on whichever lane has the least volume of traffic.
Drive in the right-hand lane unless you intend to take a left exit.
Drive in the left-hand lane unless intending to overtake.
Not drive on the left-hand lane as it is reserved for heavy goods vehicles and coaches.

questions.explanation: The normal 'keep left rules apply when you are driving on a motorway — stay in the left lane unless you are overtaking.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: With-flow bus lane on the right.
Contra flow bus lane ahead.
Bus and cycle parking ahead.
Buses may block cyclists from your view.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you there is a with-flow bus lane ahead to the right. Only buses, taxis and cyclists may use the bus lane during the stated operational hours.

questions.text: When driving on a motorway, what should a driver do?

options.text: Be alert for other drivers who may suddenly change lane or reduce speed.
Drive at the maximum permitted speed.
Match your speed to that of the vehicle in front.
Relax because there will be no oncoming or crossing traffic.

questions.explanation: The normal 'keep left rules apply when you are driving on a motorway— stay in the left lane unless you are overtaking.

questions.text: In preparation for driving on a motorway. what changes should a driver make to tyre pressure?

options.text: The driver should increase tyre pressure in order to cope with sustained high speeds.
The driver should ensure that tyre pressure is normal.
The driver should reduce tyre pressure because high speeds will cause them to heat up.
The driver should increase the front tyre pressure.

questions.explanation: You should ensure that the tyre pressure of your vehicle is correct at all times. Correct tyre pressure is especially important when travelling long distances, on motorways and at speed.

questions.text: What should a driver do when joining a motorway from a slip road?

options.text: Always stop and give a hand signal.
Drive along the hard shoulder if necessary until a suitable gap appears in the motorway traffic to allow you to merge with it.
Try to match the vehicle speed to that of traffic already on the motorway and merge into it in a suitable gap.
Drive directly onto the motorway.

questions.explanation: When joining a motorway you should try to match your speed to that of the motorway traffic and merge into it when a suitable gap appears, while yielding to traffic already on the motorway.

questions.text: Is a driver permitted to pick up or set down a passenger on a motorway?

options.text: Only when you stop on the hard-shoulder.
Only during daylight hours.
Only when you are within 200 meters of a slip-road.
No. this is not permitted.

questions.explanation: Motorways are designed so that traffic can move faster and more freely. It is illegal and dangerous to stop a vehicle on any part of a motorway except in an emergency or when signalled to do so by a garda.

questions.text: When driving on a motorway and wishing to turn back, what should a driver do?

options.text: Wait on the right-hand side shoulder until a suitable gap appears in oncoming traffic.
Leave the motorway at the next exit and cross to the other side using the fly-over (or underpass).
Cross to the opposite side of the motorway when there is a suitable gap in the oncoming traffic.
Wait on the hard shoulder until a suitable gap appears in traffic from both directions and then cross to the opposite side of the motorway.

questions.explanation: If you miss your intended exit when driving on a motorway, you should proceed to the next junction exit where you can leave the motorway and then rejoin it in the opposite direction.

questions.text: What should a driver do when driving on a motorway and wishing to take a break?

options.text: Pull well in on the left of the hard shoulder and switch on the hazard warning lights.
Only stop for 15 minutes or less.
Leave by the next exit and find a lay-by or suitable place to stop.
Stop on the hard shoulder and use the roadside phone to inform the authorities.

questions.explanation: if you feel fired when you are driving on a motorway, stop at a motorway service area or leave at the next exit and find a suitable place to stop to take a break.

questions.text: What should a driver do when leaving a motorway?

options.text: Maintain your speed until traffic conditions oblige you to slow down.
Comply with the speed limit on the road the driver is joining.
Reduce speed gradually for a few kilometers.
Maintain the speed of the vehicle in front of you.

questions.explanation: When you are leaving a motorway, enter the deceleration lane and reduce your speed. Comply with the speed limit of the road you are entering — most likely you will be in a 2-way traffic system where you will encounter vulnerable road users.

questions.text: What should a driver do if they drive past their intended exit by mistake?

options.text: Stop on the hard shoulder and reverse back to the exit.
Use the emergency telephone to ask for advice.
Drive on and leave at the next exit.
Carefully complete a 'U'-turn.

questions.explanation: If you miss your intended exit when driving on a motorway, you should proceed to the next junction exit where you can leave the motorway and then rejoin it the opposite direction.

questions.text: What is the difference between driving on a motorway and driving on other types of road?

options.text: Traffic usually travels at a higher speed on a motorway.
Traffic usually travels at lower speeds on a motorway than on a dual-carriageway.
Hand-signals may not be used on a motorway.
Speed limits are the same for all vehicles on a motorway.

questions.explanation: Motorways are designed so that traffic can move faster and more freely, without traffic lights, crossroads, level crossings and other road features that might slow down traffic. There are also restrictions on who may use a motorway—for example L-drivers and motorcycles under 50cc are prohibited.

questions.text: On a motorway, a driver wants to overtake another vehicle - what should the driver do?

options.text: Use their mirrors, signal and overtake in the right-hand lane.
Use the mirror, signal and overtake in the left-hand lane if necessary.
Check for following and oncoming traffic and overtake in either lane.
Check for following traffic and overtake in either lane.

questions.explanation: When you want to overtake on a motorway, use the Mirror—Signal—Mirror (blind spots)—Manoeuvre routine. Check your mirrors, signal your intention, check your mirrors again (and your blind spots), and complete the manoeuvre when it is safe to do so. Pay particular attention to the speed of the traffic behind you before you move out. When you are finished overtaking, move back into the left-hand lane smoothly.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: 'With-flow' bus lane on the right.
Bus and cycle parking ahead.
'Contra-flow' bus lane ahead.
Cycle track may be crossed by buses.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you that you must drive on the left and not use the contra-flow bus lane ahead day or night. A contraflow bus lane is one where the buses are going in the opposite direction to the traffic on their right.

questions.text: What may the hard shoulder of a motorway be used for?

options.text: Exiting the motorway.
Stopping to receive a call on a mobile phone.
Stopping the vehicle so the driver can have a rest.
Stopping in an emergency.

questions.explanation: There are extra dangers when driving on a motorway because of the increased volume of traffic and higher speed. For safety reasons you must not drive or stop on the hard shoulder of a motorway except in an emergency.

questions.text: On exiting the motorway what should a driver do?

options.text: Be alert for oncoming and crossing traffic.
Not overtake for a few kilometers.
Watch for oncoming traffic on the slip road.
Maintain motorway speeds for a few kilometers.

questions.explanation: When leaving a motorway, enter the deceleration lane and reduce speed. Comply with the speed limits of the road you are entering. Be mindful that you are now driving in a 2-way traffic system where you will encounter vulnerable road users such as cyclists and pedestrians.

questions.text: What should a driver do when leaving a motorway?

options.text: Drive up to 110 km/h.
Reduce speed gradually for a few kilometers.
Obey the posted speed limit.
Drive up to 120 km/h.

questions.explanation: When leaving a motorway, enter the deceleration lane and reduce speed. Comply with the speed limits of the road you are entering. Be mindful that you are now driving in a 2-way traffic system where you will encounter vulnerable road users such as cyclists and pedestrians.

questions.text: A driver wishes to go straight ahead at a cross junction of equal importance - what should the driver do?

options.text: Give way to traffic approaching from the right.
Give way to traffic approaching both left and right.
Give way to traffic approaching from your left.
Carry on as normal because you have the right of way.

questions.explanation: At a cross junction of equal importance traffic approaching from the right has the right of way. It is important to understand that the right of way is not an absolute right. In such a situation, you should proceed with caution while showing due regard for other users of the road.

questions.text: What is a clearway?

options.text: A road which is reserved for buses only.
An area where stopping and parking is not allowed during certain times.
A road which is reserved for pedestrians only.
A road without road markings.

questions.explanation: You must not stop or park in a clearway area except outside the times stated on the information plate under the sign.

questions.text: What should a driver consider doing when parking a vehicle facing down a hill?

options.text: Wheel angle does not matter.
Angle your wheels in the straight ahead position.
Angling the wheels towards the kerb.
Angle your wheels towards the road.

questions.explanation: When you are parking facing downhill, it is a good idea to angle the wheels towards the kerb. This will help to hold the vehicle in place and ease the pressure on the handbrake.

questions.text: What should a driver consider doing when parking on a two-way street facing downhill?

options.text: Turn the steering wheel towards the kerb.
Put the gears in forward.
Ensure the steering wheel is facing straight.
Turn the steering wheel to the right.

questions.explanation: When you are parking on a two-way street facing downhill, it is a good idea to turn the steering wheel towards the kerb. This will assist the handbrake by easing the pressure needed to hold the vehicle. Where possible, park with the flow of traffic.

questions.text: What should a driver consider doing when parking a vehicle on a two-way street and facing uphill?

options.text: Turning the steering wheel to the left.
Putting the gears into neutral.
Putting the gears into reverse.
Turning the steering wheel to the right.

questions.explanation: If you are parking on a two-way street facing uphill, it is a good idea to turn the steering to the right. (away from the kerb) This means the kerb will help to hold the vehicle in place and reduce the pressure on the handbrake. Where possible, you should park with the flow of traffic.

questions.text: While driving on a primary road that is not divided by a central dividing line, what should a driver do?

options.text: Imagine there is one there and drive on the right-hand side.
Position your vehicle midway on the left-hand side.
Drive on the middle of the road.
Imagine there is a central line and drive on the left-hand side.

questions.explanation: In the absence of road markings, you should take up a position far enough to the left to allow traffic to safely pass or overtake on the right but not so far to the left that you could endanger cyclists or pedestrians.

questions.text: What should a driver do when approaching a sharp right-hand bend on a narrow road?

options.text: Maintain your speed and flash your lights as a warning.
Move to the centre of the road to improve braking.
Reduce speed. keep well to the left and watch for oncoming traffic.
Wait until you are close to the bend before braking.

questions.explanation: When approaching a bend, you should assess the severity of the bend and reduce speed in good time. On a right-hand bend the correct position is well to the left, so that you can have a better view of the road ahead. You should always be able to stop safely on your own side of the road within the distance you can see to be clear.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Access for buses only.
Tram lane on left.
Bus lane ahead offside.
With-flow bus lane ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you there is a tram lane on the left. Be aware that there might be pedestrians in the area and crossing the road.

questions.text: What should a driver do when approaching a roundabout?

options.text: Drive onto it as the traffic on it must give way to you.
Give way only to heavy goods vehicles on the roundabout.
Give way only if taking the second or third exit.
Give way to traffic already on the roundabout.

questions.explanation: You should always approach roundabouts with caution. Be prepared to give way to traffic already on the roundabout and to stop if necessary.

questions.text: In what direction should a driver turn when entering a roundabout?

options.text: To the Right.
To the Right, only when controlled by a traffic light.
To the left or right.
To the left.

questions.explanation: By law you must enter a roundabout by turning to the left and giving way to traffic already on the roundabout.

questions.text: Where two lanes are provided on the approach to a roundabout, which lane should a driver select when they intend taking an exit to the right of the roundabout?

options.text: The left-hand lane.
Right lane, only when controlled by a traffic light.
The right-hand lane.
Either lane.

questions.explanation: When you approach a roundabout where two lanes are provided, you should choose the most suitable one based on the exit you intend to take off the roundabout The left lane is usually used for vehicles exiting to the left (9 o'clock) or straight ahead (12 o'clock) and the right is for vehicles exiting at any exit after 12 o'clock.

questions.text: What position should a driver approach a roundabout when intending to take the first exit to the left?

options.text: Approach in any lane and give a clear signal.
Approach in the left-hand lane and give way to traffic already on the roundabout.
Approach in the right-hand lane and give way to traffic which is already on the roundabout.
Approach in any lane, traffic on the roundabout must give way to you.

questions.explanation: When you intend to take an exit to the left off a roundabout, you should always approach the roundabout in the left lane. Approach with caution and yield to traffic already on the roundabout.

questions.text: Where should a vehicle be positioned before turning right?

options.text: The left-hand side of the road.
Just left of the centre of the road.
Either side of the centre of the road.
The right-hand side of the road.

questions.explanation: The correct position to be in before turning right is just left of the centre of the road. Where the road is wide enough, this position allows traffic coming behind you and going straight ahead to pass you safely on the left.

questions.text: What should a driver do before turning right from a major road into a minor road?

options.text: Yield right of way to oncoming traffic and to pedestrians crossing at the junction.
Turn in front of oncoming traffic as it must give right-of-way to you.
Stop and signal traffic to exit right from the minor road.
Stop and signal traffic to exit left from the minor road.

questions.explanation: You must yield to oncoming traffic when turning right from a major road to a minor road.

questions.text: What should a driver do when entering a tunnel?

options.text: Switch on dipped headlights.
Switch on your headlights.
Listen to the local radio.
Switch on your hazard warning lights.

questions.explanation: Switch on your dipped headlights as you enter a tunnel.

questions.text: What should a driver do when entering a tunnel?

options.text: Drive compact to the vehicle in front.
Register at the first tunnel station.
Wear sunglasses, if available, to prevent glare from the lights.
Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front.

questions.explanation: Tailgating can be particularly dangerous in a tunnel. The minimum recommended safe distance for a car or motorcycle is 50 metres and is 100 metres for all other vehicles.

questions.text: What should a driver do when entering a tunnel?

options.text: Listen to the local radio.
Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front and remove sunglasses, if you are wearing them.
Switch on your hazard warning lights.
Switch on your full headlights.

questions.explanation: As you enter the tunnel, turn on your dipped headlights and if you are wearing sunglasses, take them off. Pay attention for information signs displayed. While you are in the tunnel, keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front — the minimum safe distance for a car or motorcycle is 50 metres and for all other vehicles it's 100 metres.

questions.text: When driving through a tunnel what should a driver do?

options.text: Register at the first tunnel station.
Keep further back than normal from the vehicle in front.
Drive compact to the vehicle in front.
Wear sunglasses, if available, to prevent glare from the lights.

questions.explanation: While you are driving in the tunnel, keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front — the minimum safe distance for a car or motorcycle is 50 metres and for all other vehicles its 100 metres.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Parking only inside the white line.
'With-flow' bus lane ahead.
Fire station ahead.
Tram lane on right.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you there is a tram lane ahead to the right. Be aware that there might be pedestrians in the area and crossing the road.

questions.text: What should a driver do if there is traffic congestion in a tunnel?

options.text: Leave the vehicle.
Switch on hazard warning lights.
Stop at the nearest emergency exit.
Keep close to the vehicle in front.

questions.explanation: If there is traffic congestion in a tunnel, you should switch on hazard lights and remain patient. Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front even in slow-moving traffic. Listen for traffic messages on the tunnel radio station, if available.

questions.text: What should a driver do if traffic comes to a halt in a tunnel?

options.text: Select a low gear, and keep the engine ticking over.
Only give hand signals.
Switch on your fog lights.
Switch off the engine.

questions.explanation: If traffic comes to a halt in a tunnel, switch off your engine to prevent a build up of fumes in the tunnel. Stay patient and follow the instructions of the tunnel operators.

questions.text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down or they are involved in a collision in a tunnel?

options.text: Beckon other traffic to overtake.
Switch on hazard warning lights and walk to emergency station to call for help.
Switch on your hazard warning lights - ONLY.
Call for help from an emergency station - ONLY.

questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down or is involved in a collision in a tunnel, switch on your hazard warning lights, switch off your engine, go to an emergency station and use the emergency: phone to alert the tunnel operator.

questions.text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down in a tunnel?

options.text: Wait in the vehicle until help arrives.
Flag down a passing motorist and ask for help.
Walk to the end of the tunnel and call the police.
Use the emergency telephone to call for help.

questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down or is involved in a collision in a tunnel, switch on your hazard warning lights, switch off your engine, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

questions.text: What should a driver do in the event of a breakdown or incident in a tunnel?

options.text: Switch on hazard lights and stop as close to the left-hand side as possible.
Reverse the vehicle, if necessary, to make room from over taking traffic.
Beckon other traffic to overtake.
Hitch a lift to the nearest service area and get help.

questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down or is involved in a collision in a tunnel, switch on your hazard warning lights, switch off your engine, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

questions.text: What should a driver do if their vehicle goes on fire in a tunnel?

options.text: Wait for the tunnel traffic radio to announce procedure.
Drive to nearest tunnel lay-by.
Drive to the nearest emergency exit.
Leave the vehicle and follow the emergency escape route.

questions.explanation: If your vehicle goes on fire in a tunnel, you should stop the vehicle as soon as possible, evacuate any passengers to a safe place, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

questions.text: When approaching a junction where a pedestrian is crossing the road what should a driver do?

options.text: Wave the pedestrian on.
Yield right of way to the pedestrian.
Carry on because the pedestrian only has right-of-way at a pedestrian crossing.
Sound the horn as a warning of your appoach.

questions.explanation: You should never put a pedestrian at risk, and you must always yield to pedestrians crossing who have started to cross at Junctions.

questions.text: What should a driver do if their progress is hindered by a cyclist ahead?

options.text: Drive close behind to encourage the cyclist to pull in.
Stay well back until there is an opportunity to overtake safely.
Sound the horn to encourage the cyclist to move over.
Try to squeeze past the cyclist despite oncoming traffic.

questions.explanation: You should always be aware of the vulnerability of cyclists and other road users. Give cyclists extra space, especially when are overtaking them — as they may swerve, wobble or change direction.

questions.text: When stopped at traffic lights and the green light comes on but pedestrians are still crossing the road, what should a driver do?

options.text: Signal the pedestrains to warn them of the light's changing and move out when it changes.
Sound the horn as a warning to them that the lights are about to change.
Inch forward in your vehicle to encourage them to complete the crossing quickly.
Wait as long as necessary to enable them to complete the crossing.

questions.explanation: A green traffic light means you should go if the way is clear. If pedestrians are crossing, give way to them and let them finish crossing before proceeding.

questions.text: What should a driver do when they see a slow moving vehicle up ahead being driven by a learner driver?

options.text: Quickly overtake the vehicle to avoid being delayed.
Be patient and allow extra time to the driver if necessary.
Sound the horn to encourage the driver to speed up.
Drive close behind the vehicle to encourage the driver to speed up.

questions.explanation: You should be patient when driving behind a learner driver. Learners are not as experienced as other road users and may drive erratically.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Series of dangerous corners ahead.
Junction ahead with roads of lesser importance.
Junction ahead with roads or equal importance.
Junction ahead with roads of greater importance.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a junction ahead with minor roads on either side. Be aware that vehicles may be emerging from the minor roads.

questions.text: What should a driver do when they see a slow moving vehicle up ahead being driven by a learner driver?

options.text: Stay back until the driver can overtake safely.
Drive close behind the vehicle in front and flash your headlights.
Overtake the vehicle as quickly as possible.
Sound the horn to encourage the driver to pull in.

questions.explanation: You should be patient when driving behind a learner driver. Learners are not as experienced as other road users and may drive erratically.

questions.text: What way is an inexperienced learner driver likely to react in traffic situations?

options.text: The same as an experienced driver.
Slower then an experienced driver.
More correctly then an experienced driver.
More quickly then an experienced driver.

questions.explanation: You should be patient when driving behind a learner driver. Learners may not anticipate and react to situations as well as an experienced driver would.

questions.text: A driver sees a cyclist Just ahead who is about to overtake a parked vehicle There is no oncoming traffic, what should a driver do?

options.text: Allow the cyclist to overtake the parked vehicle and then proceed.
Overtake the cyclist before the cyclist has a chance to overtake the parked vehicle.
Allow enough clearance to overtake both the parked vehicle and the cyclist together.
Expect the cyclist to go on the inside of the vehicle.

questions.explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations — in this case you should allow the cyclist ahead to overtake the parked car first.

questions.text: In slow-moving traffic in a built-up area, what should a driver do when approaching a pedestrian crossing?

options.text: Drive close up behind the vehicle in front and move forward when it moves.
Avoid obstructing the pedestrian crossing only if there are pedestrians on the crossing.
Time their stop/start movements to avoid obstructing the pedestrian crossing.
Stop your vehicle on the pedestrian crossing if necessary.

questions.explanation: When you are in slow moving traffic and approaching a pedestrian crossing, you should not proceed onto the crossing unless you can clear it completely without stopping. Blocking a crossing could inconvenience pedestrians wishing to cross at that point.

questions.text: At road junctions, what type of road users are particularly vulnerable?

options.text: Minibus or van drivers.
Tractor drivers.
Car drivers.
Motorcyclists.

questions.explanation: Vehicles do not have an automatic right of way at Junctions. As a driver you should pay particular attention to vulnerable road users such as pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists and be aware that they are entitled to use the road in safety.

questions.text: At road junctions, what type of road users are particularly vulnerable?

options.text: Minibus or van drivers.
Tractor drivers.
Pedestrians.
Car drivers.

questions.explanation: Vehicles do not have an automatic right of way at junctions. As a driver you should pay particular attention to vulnerable road users such as pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists and be aware that they are entitled to use the road in safety.

questions.text: At road junctions, what type of road users are particularly vulnerable?

options.text: Minibus or van drivers.
Cyclists.
Tractor drivers.
Car drivers.

questions.explanation: Vehicles do not have an automatic right of way at junctions. As a driver you should pay particular attention to vulnerable road users such as pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists and be aware that they are entitled to use the road in safety.

questions.text: At traffic lights, a driver should take particular care for which road users coming up on the left?

options.text: Buses or vans.
Cars.
Cyclists.
Tractors.

questions.explanation: Before moving off at traffic lights you should be aware of cyclists and motorcyclists coming up on the left in general — in particular where there is an advanced stop line for cyclists ahead of that for other road users.

questions.text: At traffic lights, a driver should take particular care for which road users coming up on the left?

options.text: Buses or vans.
Motorcyclists.
Cars.
Tractors.

questions.explanation: Before moving off at traffic lights you should be aware of cyclists and motorcyclists coming up on the left — in particular where there is an advanced stop line for cyclists ahead of that for other road users.

questions.text: What should a driver do if the traffic light changes to green while pedestrians are still crossing at traffic lights or at a pelican crossing?

options.text: Wait patiently and let them cross at ease.
Rev your engine to encourage them to hurry along.
Beckon them along as quickly as possible.
Move off slowly.

questions.explanation: You must always yield to pedestrians already crossing at a pedestrian crossing or junction, and you must not hurry them off the crossing by aggressive actions. Vehicles do not have a greater right of way over other road users.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: You must stop at the junction ahead.
Main road bears to the right.
Main roads bears to the left.
Heavy vehicles must go left.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a junction ahead with a minor road ahead. The wider arm of the Y indicates the course of the main road.

questions.text: When a driver intends to make a left-hand turn on a busy city street junction and there are pedestrians and cyclists around, what should a driver do?

options.text: Signal left, watch the right-hand mirror and make the turn when it is clear.
Watch for cyclists or pedestrians who may try to cross the road in front of the vehicle.
Stay tight on the left so as to prevent cyclists or pedestrians coming up your left side.
Honk your horn.

questions.explanation: The vehicle does not have a greater right-of-way than any other road user. As a driver you should pay particular attention to vulnerable road users such as pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists and be aware that they are entitled to use the road in safety.

questions.text: When a driver intends to make a left-hand turn on a busy city street junction and there are pedestrians and cyclists around, what should a driver do?

options.text: Stay tight on the left so as to prevent cyclists or pedestrians coming up your left side.
Watch for cyclists or pedestrians on the left.
Signal left, watch the right-hand mirror and make the turn when it is clear.
Honk your horn.

questions.explanation: The vehicle does not have a greater right-of-way than any other road user. As a driver you should pay particular attention to vulnerable road users such as pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists and be aware that they are entitled to use the road in safety.

questions.text: When a driver intends to make a left-hand turn on a busy city street junction and there are pedestrians and cyclists around, what should a driver do?

options.text: Allow comfort space for any pedestrian on the left.
Stay tight on the left so as to prevent cyclists or pedestrians coming up your left side.
Signal left, watch the right-hand mirror and make the turn when it is clear.
Honk your horn.

questions.explanation: The vehicle does not have a greater right-of-way than any other road user. As a driver you should pay particular attention to vulnerable road users such as pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists and be aware that they are entitled to use the road in safety.

questions.text: In slow-moving city traffic, a driver should occasionally check their blind spots for which road users in particular?

options.text: Cyclists.
Other large vehicles.
Horse drawn carriages.
Taxis.

questions.explanation: In slow-moving city traffic, you should be aware of and check your blind spots before any manoeuvre. Cyclists can easily become 'hidden' in a blind spot, and in slow-moving traffic, they might be moving faster than you are.

questions.text: In slow-moving city traffic, a driver should occasionally check their blind spots for which road users in particular?

options.text: Other large vehicles.
Motorcyclists.
Parking bays.
Taxis.

questions.explanation: In slow-moving city traffic, you should be aware of and check your blind spots before any manoeuvre. Cyclists can easily become 'hidden' in a blind spot, and in slow-moving traffic, they might be moving faster than you are.

questions.text: In slow-moving city traffic a driver should occasionally check their blind spots for which road users in particular?

options.text: Proceed if you can edge your way through.
Tell them to be careful and wave them across.
Beckon them to return to the side.
Pedestrians.

questions.explanation: In slow-moving city traffic, you should be aware of and check your blind spots before any manoeuvre. Pedestrians can easily become 'hidden' in a blind spot, and in slow-moving traffic, they might be moving faster than you are.

questions.text: What should a driver do when approaching a junction with green traffic lights where there are elderly people crossing?

options.text: Sound the horn to warn them that you are approaching and maintain your speed.
Increase speed to pass quickly.
Allow them to cross in their own time.
Increase engine noise to warn the person of your approach.

questions.explanation: When approaching a junction with green traffic lights, you should never assume that you have an automatic right of way. You should be aware that some road users (such as elderly pedestrians) may need extra time to clear the junction.

questions.text: If the traffic lights change while pedestrians are still crossing at pelican crossings or traffic lights, what should a driver do?

options.text: Increase speed to pass quickly.
Wait patiently and let them cross with ease.
Sound the horn to warn them that you are approaching and maintain your speed.
Increase engine noise to warn the person of your approach.

questions.explanation: You must always yield to pedestrians already crossing at a pedestrian crossing or junction, and you must not hurry them off the crossing by aggressive actions. Vehicles do not have a greater right of way over other road users.

questions.text: What should a driver do if they see an elderly person crossing the road up ahead?

options.text: Increase engine noise to warn the person of your approach.
Sound the horn to warn them that you are approaching and maintain your speed.
Reduce speed and let the person to complete the crossing safely.
Increase speed to pass quickly.

questions.explanation: You must not put pedestrians at risk, and you must give way to them while they are crossing. Be cautious and patient with pedestrians, particularly if they are elderly or infirm.

questions.text: What should a driver do if while driving at 80 km/h they see children on the road ahead?

options.text: Maintain your speed.
Sound the horn to warn them of your approach and maintain your speed.
Turn on your headlights.
Reduce speed and prepare to stop if necessary.

questions.explanation: You should be aware that children can be unpredictable, and you should slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Cul-de-sacs to both left and right.
Staggered crossroads ahead with roads of equal importance.
Roads closed ahead to both left and right.
Traffic-calming ramps ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a staggered junction ahead with roads to the left and right. Be aware that vehicles may be emerging from these roads.

questions.text: What should a driver do when they see children just ahead on the road?

options.text: Give them a wide clearance and be prepared to slow down if necessary.
Keep your course as the noise of the engine will make them keep in.
Flash your lights and sound your horn to warn them of your approach.
Flash your lights to warn them of your presence and maintain your present speed.

questions.explanation: You should be aware that children can be unpredictable, and you should be prepared to slow down and give extra clearance to them if necessary.

questions.text: When driving on a windy day and a cyclist is up ahead, what should a driver do?

options.text: Allow extra clearance in case the cyclist is blown off course.
Expect the cyclist to be alert and to keep in ot the left.
Maintain your course but sound the horn as a warning.
Maintain your course but prepare to swerve around the cyclist if necessary.

questions.explanation: You should never cut in front of cyclists when overtaking them. Give cyclists plenty of space especially in windy weather as they can easily be blown off course.

questions.text: What should a driver do when overtaking a cyclist?

options.text: Allow extra clearance in case the cyclist swerves suddenly.
Sound the horn as a warning and overtake the cyclist as quickly as possible.
Drive close to the cyclist and overtake promptly.
Sound the horn as a warning.

questions.explanation: You should never cut in front of cyclists when overtaking them. Give them plenty of space especially as they may change direction suddenly — for example, to avoid a pothole, or because they are blown off course by a strong gust of wind.

questions.text: What should a driver do when they see joggers ahead on the left?

options.text: The driver should sound the horn and flash it's lights to warn them of their presence.
Expect them to move in so the driver can pass them by.
Indicate, use the mirrors and overtake allowing sufficient clearance.
Check the mirrors, indicate and overtake the joggers allowing them sufficient clearance.

questions.explanation: People on the road are more vulnerable than vehicles so you should treat them with care. If you see people jogging ahead, use the mirror—signal—mirror (blind spots)—manoeuvre routine and give sufficient clearance to the joggers when you are overtaking them.

questions.text: When driving on a road that has a potholed surface and there is a cyclist ahead, what should a driver do?

options.text: Allow extra clearance in case the cyclist swerves out to avoid a pothole.
Change to a lower gear and overtake quickly.
Expect the cyclist to keep to the left and maintain your speed.
Maintain your course and sound your horn to alert the cyclist of your approach.

questions.explanation: You should always be aware of how vulnerable cyclists are. When you are driving on a road with potholes or bad surfaces, take into account that they may have to swerve suddenly to avoid potholes.

questions.text: What precautions should a driver take in relation to pedestrians when driving in slow-moving traffic?

options.text: Watch for pedestrians who may cross the road in front of your vehicle.
Allow them to cross the road only at pedestrian crossings.
Rev your engine occasionally as a warning.
Do not leave a gap between your vehicle and the vehicle in front.

questions.explanation: In slow-moving city traffic, you should be aware of and check your blind spots before any manoeuvre. Pedestrians can easily become 'hidden' in a blind spot and in slow-moving traffic, they might be moving faster than you are.

questions.text: What should a driver be aware of when making a left-hand turn?

options.text: Check for pedestrians or cyclists who may have come up on the inside.
Following traffic must have room to overtake.
Cyclists might come up on the 'outside'.
You should approach with the nearside wheels brushing against the kerb.

questions.explanation: When you are turning left, you should be aware that cyclists and pedestrians may come up on your inside. Always check to your left before you make a left turn.

questions.text: When driving through a residential area, what particular hazards should a driver be aware of?

options.text: Vehicles may drive or reverse onto the road.
Minimum loading limits may apply.
All the traffic may be slow moving.
Parking fees may apply.

questions.explanation: When driving through a built up area, you should drive with care and always be ready for the unexpected - such as other vehicles driving or reversing out onto the road unexpectedly.

questions.text: When driving through a residential area, what particular hazards should a driver be aware of?

options.text: Obey the speed limit and maintain their course.
Switch on the hazard warning lights.
Children or residents may come out suddenly.
Parking fees may apply.

questions.explanation: When driving through a built-up area, you should drive with care and always be ready for the unexpected — such as children running out onto the road.

questions.text: When driving on a country road without footpaths, what should a driver look out for coming towards them on their side of the road?

options.text: Pedestrians.
Motorcycles.
Cyclists.
Tractors.

questions.explanation: Pedestrian deaths account for one in five fatalities on our roads, so you should always be on the look-out for pedestrians, especially on country roads where there is no footpath.

questions.text: What does this sign mean at a roundabout?

options.text: Yield to traffic on the major road.
Yield to traffic coming from the right.
Yield to trucks and buses only.
All vehicles, except motorcycles, must yield.

questions.explanation: At a roundabout, the YIELD sign tells you that you must slow down and be prepared to stop. You must yield (give way) to traffic already on the roundabout.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: T-junction ahead with roads of equal importance.
No entry.
Overhead electric cables ahead.
Flyover ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a T-junction ahead with a roads of equal importance. You must give way to traffic already on the road you are joining.

questions.text: What should a driver do when driving at night on an unlit road?

options.text: Drive as close as possible to the line of reflective studs.
Watch out for pedestrians wearing dark clothing.
Drive on the centre of the road.
Maintain their speed when meeting oncoming traffic.

questions.explanation: While driving at night and even with the best headlights, it can be very difficult to see all the hazards that you might come across — for example, pedestrians wearing dark clothing. At night you should drive at a speed that will enable you to stop safely within the distance you can see to be clear ahead.

questions.text: What should a driver do when driving at night on an unlit road?

options.text: Drive on the centre of the road.
Watch out for cars parked on the left.
Maintain their speed when meeting oncoming traffic.
Drive as close as possible to the line of reflective studs.

questions.explanation: While driving at night and even with the best headlights, it can be very difficult to see all the hazards that you might come across — for example, pedestrians wearing dark clothing. At night you should drive at a speed that will enable you to stop safely within the distance you can see to be clear ahead.

questions.text: What should a driver do when driving at night on an unlit road?

options.text: Watch out for stray animals or livestock.
Maintain their speed when meeting oncoming traffic.
Drive on the centre of the road.
Drive as close as possible to the line of reflective studs.

questions.explanation: While driving at night and even with the best headlights, it can be very difficult to see all the hazards that you might come across — for example, pedestrians wearing dark clothing. At night you should drive at a speed that will enable you to stop safely within the distance you can see to be clear ahead.

questions.text: What could happen if a driver parks on a footpath?

options.text: The suspension could be weakened.
The tyres could lose air pressure.
Traffic could be impeded.
Pedestrians could be impeded.

questions.explanation: You should never park on a footpath. Pedestrians (including people with young children in pushchairs and prams) might have to go onto the road to get around your car, and this could put them in danger.

questions.text: What should a driver do when driving along and there is a cyclist on the road up ahead?

options.text: Check the mirrors, indicate in good time and move out if it is safe to do so.
Indicate, check the mirror and move out.
Indicate, move out and check the mirror for following traffic.
Use your mirrors, and move out to overtake without indicating.

questions.explanation: You should overtake only when it is safe to do so. Give extra space to cyclists when you are overtaking them, as they may need to move out to avoid a pothole. or they could be blown into your path on windy days.

questions.text: If indicators are not fitted or are not working, how should signals be given?

options.text: It is not necessary to give signals provided you look around.
Your position on the road is a signal in itself.
By hand, clearly and in good time.
Verbally, out you window.

questions.explanation: If, for whatever reason, your vehicle does not have indicators or has indicators that are not working, you should know how to use the appropriate hand signals to alert other road users of your intention to change direction.

questions.text: What should a driver do when travelling on a country road with following traffic, and they meet pedestrians?

options.text: Flash their lights so that following traffic might see the pedestrian.
Leave a minimum safety clearance of 25 centimeters.
Signal to following traffic their intention to overtake the pedestrians.
Gesture to the pedestrian to move in off the road.

questions.explanation: When you are driving on a road without footpaths, you should take extra care when you come upon pedestrians on the road. If you have to move out to overtake and there is following traffic, check your mirrors and signal in good time to alert the drivers behind that there is a hazard ahead.
