questions.text: In relation to cyclists and pedestrians, what should a driver be aware of when driving on dark winter mornings and evenings on unlit country' roads?

options.text: Car has the correct tyre pressure.
They will always be wearing reflective clothing and lighting.
Cyclists are much more vulnerable in poor lighting conditions.
Cyclists are less vulnerable in poor lighting conditions.

questions.explanation: You should take extra care when driving on dark winter mornings and evenings — vulnerable road users such as cyclists and pedestrians (particularly schoolchildren) might not be so easy to see in low light conditions.

questions.text: In relation to cyclists and pedestrians, what should a driver be aware of when driving on dark winter mornings and evenings on unlit country' roads?

options.text: Car tyres have the correct tyre pressure.
Cyclist and pedestrians will always be visible.
A driver should take extra care for cyclists and pedestrians in the countryside as they may not be clearly visible.
Cyclists and pedestrians are less vulnerable in poor lighting conditions.

questions.explanation: You should take extra care when driving on dark winter mornings and evenings — vulnerable road users such as cyclists and pedestrians (particularly schoolchildren) might not be so easy to see in low light conditions.

questions.text: In relation to pedestrians, what should a driver be aware of when driving on dark winter mornings and evenings?

options.text: There will be no pedestrians on the road.
That there could be vulnerable pedestrians walking in the countryside.
Have no effect on your ability to see vulnerable pedestrians.
All pedestrians in the countryside will be wearing reflective armbands and bright clothing, and will be clearly visible to you.

questions.explanation: You should take extra care when driving on dark winter mornings and evenings — vulnerable road users such as cyclists and pedestrians (particularly schoolchildren) might not be so easy to see in low light conditions.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Railway crossing ahead.
Y-Junction ahead with roads of equal importance.
Major road ahead.
End of dual-carriageway.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a Y-junction ahead with a roads of equal importance. Approach such a junction with caution and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

questions.text: In relation to pedestrians, what should a driver be aware of when driving on dark winter mornings and evenings?

options.text: Stray animals may be on the road.
Schoolchildren are more vulnerable on unlit country roads on dark winter mornings and evenings.
You should drive with full headlights at all times in order to see pedestrians walking on unlit country roads.
You should anticipate that any pedestrians up ahead will be on a footpath and will be free from danger from your vehicle.

questions.explanation: You should take extra care when driving on dark winter mornings and evenings — vulnerable road users such as cyclists and pedestrians (particularly schoolchildren) might not be so easy to see in low light conditions.

questions.text: What drivers are required to display L-plates on their vehicle?

options.text: Learner drivers who are accompanied by the holder of a full licence in the relevant category.
Drivers who have less than two years driving experience.
Drivers on their second Learner Permit.
All learner permit holders except those driving agricultural tractors and works vehicles.

questions.explanation: All learner permit holders except those driving agricultural tractors or works vehicles are required to display L-plates on the front and rear of their vehicle. Learner permit holders in category Al. A and M are required to wear a yellow fluorescent tabard with an L-plate that is clearly visible on the front and back.

questions.text: What restriction will be noted on a driver’s full licence if they have passed their test on a vehicle with automatic transmission?

options.text: They may not tow a trailer.
They may not drive at speeds of more than 80 km/h.
They must continue to display 'L' plates.
They may not drive vehicles with manual transmission.

questions.explanation: If you pass your driving test in a vehicle fitted with automatic transmission, a code 78 will be noted on the full licence in the restrictions / information column.

questions.text: What roads are learner permit holders allowed to drive on?

options.text: All roads.
All roads except motorways and dual-carriageways.
All roads except motorways.
All roads except dual-carriageways.

questions.explanation: A learner permit holder must not drive on a motorway. It is a serious offence to do so.

questions.text: How should an L-plate be composed?

options.text: A white L on a yellow background.
A green L on a white background.
A red L on a transparent background.
A red L on a white background.

questions.explanation: L-plates should be displayed front and rear. The plates should be a red L on a white background and should be not less than 15cm high with a border of at least 2cm. A learner motorcyclist must wear a yellow tabard displaying L-plates front and rear. The L-plates must be not less than 15cm high on a white background.

questions.text: Which roads are Learner Permit holders not allowed to drive on?

options.text: They may not drive on dual-carriageways.
They may drive on all roads.
They may not drive on national primary roads.
They may not drive on motorways.

questions.explanation: A learner permit holder must not drive on a motorway. It is a serious offence to do so.

questions.text: Which learner permit holders are exempt from having to be accompanied by qualified drivers?

options.text: Learner permit holders in categories A, Al and M.
All Learner Permit holders in category B and W.
None.
All.

questions.explanation: Learner permit holders in categories A, Al and M do not have to be accompanied by qualified drivers. Learner permit holders in these categories must not carry a passenger.

questions.text: Where can drivers locate the Gross Vehicle Weight of their vehicle?

options.text: On a metal plate in the vehicle.
On the tachograph.
On the insurance disc.
On the Tax Disc.

questions.explanation: The plate displaying the Gross Vehicle Weight of a vehicle is normally located under the bonnet or in the passenger compartment. If you are not sure where it is located on your vehicle, check the drivers handbook supplied with the vehicle.

questions.text: Is it permitted to use a vehicle in a public place without a current tax disc displayed?

options.text: Yes, but for not more than one month after the expiry of the previous disc.
No. all motor vehicles must be taxed before the vehicle is taken on the road.
Yes, but for not more than 14 days after the expiry of the previous disc.
Yes, but for not more than 10 days after the expiry of the previous disc.

questions.explanation: A motor vehicle must be taxed and must display the up-to-date tax disk before it may be taken on the road.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Major road ahead.
T-junction ahead with road of greater importance.
Road passing under a bridge ahead.
Flyover ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a crossroads junction with a major road ahead. Be prepared to stop.

questions.text: If a driver wishes to drive a vehicle but the tax disc is expired, what should they do?

options.text: Notify the Gardai.
Drive it only in case of an emergency.
They should not drive it.
Renew it within 10 days or expiry.

questions.explanation: A motor vehicle must be taxed and must display the up-to-date tax disc before it may be taken on the road.

questions.text: If a driver wishes to drive another vehicle which is not currently taxed, would they be allowed to transfer the current tax disc from their own vehicle onto it?

options.text: Only when the proper form has been completed.
No. Tax discs are not transferable.
Yes, on a temporary basis.
Yes, provided your own vehicle is not being used at the same time.

questions.explanation: A motor vehicle must be taxed and must display its own up-to-date tax disc before it may be taken on the road. The tax disc includes information about the vehicle, including its make and model colour and registration number.

questions.text: When a vehicle is being driven by a person who is not its owner, who should ensure that the correct tax disc is displayed?

options.text: The driver, where not the owner.
The driver and the owner of the vehicle are equally responsible.
The owner, where not the driver.
The government.

questions.explanation: If you are the owner or the driver of a vehicle, you must ensure that it is not taxed and that it displays an up-to-date tax disc before you take it on the road.

questions.text: When must a current tax disc be displayed on a new vehicle on a public road?

options.text: At all times.
Not later than 3 months after registration.
Only when driving on motorways.
Not later than 6 months after registration.

questions.explanation: A motor vehicle must be taxed before it may be taken on the road, and it must always display an up-to-date tax disc.

questions.text: Who may demand to see a driver’s vehicle registration document/vehicle licensing certificate?

options.text: Any person with whom you are involved in an accident.
Any garda.
Anyone.
Any traffic Warden.

questions.explanation: A garda may demand to see your driving licence at anytime, and you should always carry this with you when driving. A garda may also examine your insurance disc, tax disc and NCT disc (if applicable). A garda may ask you to produce other documents (including the vehicle's registration document) at a named Garda station within 10 days.

questions.text: When a vehicle is being driven by a person who is not its owner but who has the owner’s consent, who should ensure that the vehicle is properly insured?

options.text: Both the driver and the vehicle owner.
The vehicle owner only.
The driver only.
The drivers closest relative.

questions.explanation: All drivers must have insurance covering them to drive a vehicle on a public road It is a serious offence to drive a vehicle that is not insured. It is also an offence to allow a vehicle that you own to be driven by an uninsured driver.

questions.text: Is a driver still insured to drive their vehicle after their insurance policy has expired?

options.text: No. the vehicle is not insured after the expiry of the policy.
Yes, up to 10 days after expiry.
Yes, up to 30 days after expiry.
Yes, up to 14 days after expiry.

questions.explanation: All drivers must have insurance covering them to drive a vehicle on a public road. The vehicle must display an up-to-date insurance disc. Insurance companies insist that the premium must be paid before the renewal date.

questions.text: If a driver wishes to drive another privately-owned vehicle but they are uncertain if they are insured to drive, what should they do?

options.text: Drive it provided the driver informs the insurance company within 10 days, and agree to pay any additional premium.
Drive if there is an insurance disc on the vehicle.
Transfer the insurance disc from their own vehicle .
A driver should contact their own insurer to confirm whether or not their insurance policy covers the driving of other vehicles.

questions.explanation: If you are in any doubt about your insurance cover, you should discuss the matter with your insurance company. It is a serious offence to drive a vehicle that is not insured.

questions.text: When a driver wishes to drive a vehicle and they are not sure if they are covered by insurance, what should they do?

options.text: They should not drive until cover is confirmed by their insurance company.
Check with their local Garda station.
Check with their local motor taxation office.
Only drive it for short distances.

questions.explanation: If you are in any doubt about your insurance cover, you should discuss the matter with your insurance company. It is a serious offence to drive a vehicle that is not insured.

questions.text: What is the minimum insurance cover which is required to drive a vehicle on a public road?

options.text: Personal accident.
Third Party, fire and theft.
Third Party.
Comprehensive.

questions.explanation: As a motorist must have a minimum of third party insurance. This indemnifies you against any claim made against you.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: T-junction ahead with a road of major importance.
Cul-de sac to the right.
Junction ahead with a road of minor importance.
Toll-roads ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a T-junction with a major road ahead. Be prepared to stop.

questions.text: What information must a driver give in order to obtain insurance cover on a vehicle?

options.text: Name, address, phone number and licence number.
All information relating to the previous 5 years.
Their age and details of their driving licence.
All information requested by the insurance company.

questions.explanation: All drivers must have insurance covering them to drive a vehicle on a public road. The law imposes a duty on drivers to give their insurance company any relevant information before driving a vehicle.

questions.text: If the owner of a vehicle has had the engine capacity of the vehicle altered, what should they do?

options.text: Inform their insurance company.
Inform their local motor taxation office and their insurance company.
Not exceed 50 km/h for the first 1,600 kilometers after having the alternation made.
Not exceed 80 km/h for the first 1,600 kilometers after having the alternation made.

questions.explanation: The law imposes a duty on drivers to give their insurance company any relevant information before driving a vehicle. This includes details of any modifications made to the vehicle. In the case of a change of engine capacity, you must inform the local Motor Taxation Office, as different rates of motor tax may apply.

questions.text: If a driver passes their test using a vehicle with automatic transmission, which vehicles are they licensed to drive?

options.text: Manual vehicles only.
All vehicles in the licence category, but only automatic vehicles on a motorway.
Automatic vehicles only.
All vehicles in the licence category.

questions.explanation: If you pass your driving test in an automatic or adapted vehicle. your full licence will apply to that type of vehicle only. A licence restricted to automatic vehicles will have a code 78 indicated in the restrictions / information column of the licence.

questions.text: How can a driver assist a motorcyclist who is in shock on the road following an incident?

options.text: Give the rider a hot drink.
Lie the rider on his side in the recovery position.
Move the rider to the side of the road.
Ensure the helmet is removed.

questions.explanation: If you arrive at the scene of a collision, always call the emergency services on 999 or 112. Only properly trained persons should assist victims at the scene of an incident. If a victim is conscious, you may help put them in the recovery position until the emergency services arrive. Never move a collision victim unless there is a danger of fire or of a vehicle turning over.

questions.text: What should a driver do when involved in an incident where nobody is injured but the vehicles are causing a danger or obstruction on the road?

options.text: Mark the position of the vehicles and move them off the road.
Move any passengers and display a red warning triangle on the vehicle.
Wait for the Gardai to arrive before moving the vehicles off the road.
Halt all other traffic until blame has been established and then move the vehicles.

questions.explanation: In a collision where nobody is injured and there is only minor damage to vehicles, the vehicles should be moved to the side of the road to ensure that they do not cause an obstruction or endanger other road users.

questions.text: What should a driver do if involved in an incident where they feel it was the fault of another driver?

options.text: Stop immediately and exchange particulars with the other person involved.
Carry on to the nearest Garda station and report it as soon as possible.
Carry on if you think there was no damage done to your vehicle.
Exchange licence details with the other driver.

questions.explanation: If you are involved in any sort of incident with another motorist you should always exchange insurance details with the other driver and take note of the other vehicle's make and model, colour and registration number. Report the incident to the Gardaí. In a collision where nobody is injured and there is only minor damage to vehicles, the vehicles should be moved to the side of the road to ensure that they do not cause an obstruction or endanger other road users.

questions.text: If a driver is involved in a collision, when should they inform their insurance company?

options.text: Only if a person has been injured.
Only when renewing their policy.
Only if they were at fault.
As soon as they possibly can.

questions.explanation: If you are involved in an incident with another vehicle, you should inform your insurance company as soon as possible. This will help with any claims that may be made by another party against your insurance company.

questions.text: What must a driver do when involved in a collision where there is minor damage done to the vehicles?

options.text: Must share the cost of any damage caused.
Stop their vehicle and exchange particulars with the driver of the other vehicle.
Must mark the position of the vehicles on the road and report to the Gardai.
Must report it to the Gardai.

questions.explanation: If you are involved in a collision you must exchange details with the other driver. no matter how minor the damage is. What may look like minor damage at the time may turn out to be more serious when the vehicles are being repaired. Report the incident to the Gardaí.

questions.text: What should a driver do if involved in an incident where there is damage to property only?

options.text: It is not necessary to report it to the Gardai provided it has been reported to the property owner.
Report the incident to the Gardai within 14 days.
Report the incident to the Gardai within 24 hours.
Report the incident to the Gardai within 10 days.

questions.explanation: If you are involved in an incident where the only damage is to property (for example, a garden wall or fence or a parked car), you must report it to the owner or to the person in charge of the property, or to the Gardai if nearby. If you cannot do this, you should report the incident to a Garda station as soon as possible.

questions.text: What should a driver do where a person has been injured in a collision?

options.text: Move the vehicles out of the way to avoid causing obstruction.
Move the victim.
Move the victim and the vehicles.
Move the victim only if there is a risk of fire or further injury.

questions.explanation: Never move an injured person at the scene of a collision unless there is a risk of fire or further injury. Moving an injured person could add to their injuries. Trained personnel know best how to attend to injured persons. Call the emergency services (on 999 and 112) or make sure that someone else has called them.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Two-way traffic ahead.
Level crossing ahead guarded by gates.
Unguarded level crossing ahead.
Crossroads with dual carriageway ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a crossroads junction with a dual carriageway ahead. Be prepared to stop and give way to other traffic.

questions.text: What type of drink should be given to a person who has been injured in a collision?

options.text: No drink should be given.
A hot drink.
A non-alcoholic drink.
A cold drink.

questions.explanation: A person who has been injured in a collision should not be given anything to drink, as this could cause them to choke. Only trained personnel should attend to an injured person. Call the emergency services (on 999 or 112) or make sure that someone else has called them.

questions.text: What should a driver do to assist a person who is unconscious following a collision?

options.text: Move the person to the nearest hospital.
Try to get the person to drink something warm.
Raise the person's head.
Loosen tight clothing around the neck and keep the person warm with a blanket or overcoat.

questions.explanation: If a person is unconscious following a collision, you should loosen tight clothing around the their neck and keep them warm with a blanket or overcoat until the emergency services arrive. Call the emergency services (on 999 or 112) or make sure that someone else has called them.

questions.text: What should a driver do if they arrive at the scene of a collision and a person is bleeding heavily?

options.text: Try to stop the bleeding by putting on a fight bandage.
Lie the person flat on the ground and prevent him/her from moving.
Raise the injured part of the body with as little movement as possible.
Keep the person warm and give him/her something to drink.

questions.explanation: If you arrive at the scene of a collision and someone is bleeding heavily, you can try to stop the flow of blood by putting on a fight bandage. Call the emergency services (on 999 or 112) or make sure that someone else has called them.

questions.text: What is the correct procedure where somebody has been injured in a collision?

options.text: Carry the person to the side of the road.
Do not move the person unless there is a danger of fire or of being hit by passing vehicles.
Have the person move various limbs to determine the extent of the injuries.
Keep the injured person calm and give them a cold drink.

questions.explanation: Never move an injured person at the scene of a collision unless there is a risk of fire or further injury. Moving an injured person could make their injuries worse. Call the emergency services (on 999 or 112) or make sure that someone else has called

questions.text: Who should first be contacted where a person has been injured in a collision?

options.text: The emergency services.
The person's relatives.
The injured person's insurance provider.
The injured person's solicitor.

questions.explanation: Where somebody has been injured in a collision, it is important to call the emergency services immediately on 999 or 112. Trained emergency services personnel know best how to attend to injured persons.

questions.text: Who should be contacted where a driver is involved in a collision where a person is injured?

options.text: The drivers relatives.
The emergency services.
The driver's insurance provider.
The injured person's solicitor.

questions.explanation: If you are involved in a collision where someone has been injured, contact the emergency services immediately on 999 or 112. Trained emergency services personnel know best how to attend to injured persons.

questions.text: What should a driver do if involved in a collision with another vehicle where nobody is injured?

options.text: Exchange all relevant details with the other driver and report it to the Gardai.
The driver should submit a report in written form to the Insurance Bureau of Ireland.
Report it to the Gardai.
The driver should give their name and address only.

questions.explanation: If a you are involved in a collision with another vehicle where nobody is injured. you should exchange all the relevant details with the other driver— including name, address, vehicle registration. make and model and all insurance details.

questions.text: If a driver is involved in a collision with an uninsured visiting motorist, where nobody is injured, who should it be reported to?

options.text: The Department of Foreign Affairs.
The Irish Insurance Federation and the driver's own insurance.
The driver's local motor taxation office.
The driver's insurance company and the Gardai.

questions.explanation: If you are involved in any type of collision, you should always report it to the Gardai and to your insurance company.

questions.text: What should a driver do if they arrive at the scene of a collision involving a vehicle carrying hazardous materials?

options.text: Wave a white cloth indicating hazardous materials present.
Try to establish the nature of the hazardous materials before raising the alarm.
Keep well clear and raise the alarm.
Try to move the vehicle to a safe place.

questions.explanation: If you arrive at the scene of a collision involving a vehicle carrying hazardous materials, you should keep well clear of the scene. Call the emergency services on 999 or 112 and give them as much information as you can about the marking labels on the vehicle. You should also warn other road users about the danger.

questions.text: What danger can arise if a driver has to brake suddenly?

options.text: Both the driver and passengers could be thrown forward.
The passengers could be thrown forward.
Both yourself and your passengers could be thrown backwards.
The passengers could be thrown backwards.

questions.explanation: When you brake suddenly, the balance of weight of the vehicle is shifted forward. and this may cause the occupants and any loose objects in the vehicle to be thrown forward.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: T-junction with dual-carriage way ahead.
Low bridge ahead.
Cul-de-sac ahead.
Speed ramps ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a T-junction with a dual carriageway ahead. Be prepared to stop and give way to other traffic.

questions.text: What should a driver do to avoid the need for harsh braking?

options.text: Look ahead and anticipate what others may do.
Drive with foot resting on the brake-pedal.
Drive with your foot resting on the clutch pedal.
Drive with cruise control engaged.

questions.explanation: You should know what speed you're travelling at and you should always drive at a speed that is appropriate to the conditions you are driving in. and you should be able to stop smoothly and safely within the distance you can see to be clear ahead.

questions.text: How does the driver know a vehicle’s total load-carrying capacity?

options.text: The size of the boot.
The horsepower of the engine.
The number of seats.
By referring to the vehicle manufacturer's specification.

questions.explanation: Design Gross Vehicle Weight is the term used by manufacturers for the weight of the vehicle together with the maximum load it is designed to carry. Drivers must understand the carrying capacity of their vehicle. Overloading your vehicle will make it more difficult to control, and it's an offence.

questions.text: What determines the maximum allowed towing capacity of a vehicle?

options.text: The manufacturer's specifications.
The strength of the hitch.
The size of the tyres on the vehicle.
The combined weight of both the vehicle and its trailer.

questions.explanation: The maximum weight that your vehicle can safely tow is specified by the manufacturer, and is usually set out in the drivers handbook for the vehicle, and in some cases on a plate attached to the vehicle. This is the safe towing limit for the vehicle and you should not exceed it.

questions.text: What effect does overloading a vehicle have on its road-holding?

options.text: The load can make the vehicle more difficult to control.
The load improves the stability of the vehicle provided the load is evenly distributed.
The load can make the vehicle more difficult to control only when reversing.
The load can make the vehicle more difficult to control only when going downhill.

questions.explanation: Overloading your vehicle will make it more difficult to control. Remember: its an offence to overload a vehicle.

questions.text: What would be the effect of overloading a vehicle with passengers or goods?

options.text: It could improve the vehicle's road-holding ability.
It would reduce the drivers ability to control the vehicle.
It would not have any effect provided you drive slowly.
It would improve the stopping distance.

questions.explanation: Overloading your vehicle will make it more difficult to control, and will increase the risk of a collision.

questions.text: What effect could an unevenly distributed load have on a vehicle?

options.text: It could make the vehicle unstable while turning a corner or braking.
It could cause the clutch to slip while accelerating.
It could cause the gearbox to overheat.
It could affect fuel consumption.

questions.explanation: When loading a vehicle you should ensure that the load is distributed evenly. An unevenly distributed load may change the vehicle's centre of gravity and this could affect the braking and steering.

questions.text: Why is it important to ensure that the vehicle headlights are correctly aligned?

options.text: To reduce battery consumption.
To enable the driver to see properly.
To enable the driver to drive faster in the dark.
To increase the life span of your headlights.

questions.explanation: You should ensure that your headlights are properly aligned and clean. When dipped, properly aligned headlights are less likely to dazzle oncoming traffic.

questions.text: In general, how frequently should a vehicle’s lights be checked?

options.text: Annualy.
When a serviced is performed.
Not Regularly.
Regularly.

questions.explanation: You are responsible for your vehicle's road worthiness and you should check it at regular intervals. Among the checks you should make are that all the lights are in working order.

questions.text: What effect can a broken lens have on a headlight?

options.text: It can cause the bulb to overheat.
It can reduce and distort the beam.
It can cause the bulb to blow if not fixed immediately.
It can increase the brightness of the beam.

questions.explanation: You are responsible for your vehicle's road worthiness and you should check it at regular intervals. Among the checks you should make are that all the lights are in working order. If you find defects in the lights, you should have them repaired as soon as possible.

questions.text: A driver wishes to drive at night, but their right-hand headlight bulb is blown. What should the driver do?

options.text: Not drive until the bulb is replaced.
Replace it temporarily with the brake-light bulb.
Replace it temporarily with the left-hand bulb.
Drive with the right-hand indicators on.

questions.explanation: You must not drive on the road unless your vehicle's headlights are in good working order and adjusted properly.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Junction ahead with road of minor importance.
Traffic from the left has priority.
Traffic merging from the left.
Road fencing in progress ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of traffic merging from the left ahead. You should expect vehicles to join from the left ahead and you may need to slow down to allow them to merge.

questions.text: Which of the following is a driver required to keep in good condition?

options.text: Upholstery.
Headlights.
Radio.
Airfreshener.

questions.explanation: You are responsible for your vehicle's road worthiness and you should check it at regular intervals. Among the checks you should make are that all the lights. (including the headlights) are in working order.

questions.text: Which of the following is a driver required to keep in good condition?

options.text: Radio.
Seatbelts.
Upholstery.
Airfreshener.

questions.explanation: You are responsible for your vehicle's road worthiness and you should check it at regular intervals. Among the checks you should make are that all the seatbelts (drivers and passengers') are in good working order.

questions.text: How would a driver know if a brake-light bulb was not working?

options.text: The remaining brake-light is brighter than normal.
The remaining brake-light is dimmer than normal.
The brake-pedal feels 'soft'.
By standing at the rear of the vehicle and checking as another person presses the brake pedal.

questions.explanation: To help you to be sure that the rear brake lights are working correctly, ask someone to stand outside the car and to check that the lights come on when you press the brake pedal.

questions.text: Is it permissible to drive a vehicle on a public road when the brake lights are not working?

options.text: Outside of lighting up time.
When driving slowly.
When driving in a built-up area.
No, the driver is never permitted to be driven.

questions.explanation: You must ensure that your vehicle's brake-lights are clean and working correctly before driving on a public road.

questions.text: What does this light mean?

options.text: The battery is not charging.
The gearbox is overheat.
Load insecure on trailer.
The engine is overheat.

questions.explanation: If the battery warning light comes on, it means there is some kind of problem with the electrical charging system of the vehicle and the battery isn't being charged properly.

questions.text: What does this light mean?

options.text: The headlights should be dipped.
The reversing light switched on.
A faulty number plate light.
The high-beam headlights are switched on.

questions.explanation: All vehicles are fitted with warning lights to alert you to different things. This light comes on when your full beam headlights are turned on.

questions.text: What does this light mean?

options.text: Low oil level.
Excessive level of battery fluid.
Low level of battery fluid.
Low level of brake fluid.

questions.explanation: If the oil pressure warning light comes on. it means that the oil pressure has dropped. You should not drive the vehicle until the problem is fixed.

questions.text: What does this light mean?

options.text: Brake-light bulb blown.
Directional indicator on.
Faulty indicator bulb.
Headlight bulb blown.

questions.explanation: All vehicles are fitted with warning lights to alert you to different things. This light tells you that the directional indicator is on.

questions.text: What should a driver do if a warning light starts flashing on the dashboard of their vehicle?

options.text: Continue for a distance to see if the light will go out.
Carry on and check the problem later.
Continue to drive and listen for any unusual sounds.
Stop and check the problem.

questions.explanation: If a warning light starts flashing while you are driving, you should stop in a safe place and investigate the problem before deciding what action to take.

questions.text: What should a driver do if a red warning light lights up on the dashboard of their vehicle?

options.text: Continue on and listen for any unusual sounds.
Stop and investigate the cause.
Continue on and see if it will go out.
Drive to the nearest garage and have it checked.

questions.explanation: If a warning light comes on while you are driving, you should stop in a safe place and investigate the problem before deciding what action to take.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Road narrows briefly.
Clearway at junction ahead.
Traffic merging/diverging ahead.
Yield to merging/diverging traffic.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of roads merging and diverging at the left ahead. You should be prepared for traffic changing direction ahead as vehicles may be entering or exiting at the junctions on the left.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the vehicle’s reflectors?

options.text: They warn pedestrians of your location.
They are a substitute in case of brake-light failure.
They warn the driver behind to switch to dipped headlights.
They reflect light at night to make other road users aware of the vehicle.

questions.explanation: Motor vehicles are fitted with reflectors to make it easier to be seen by other road users. Keep your reflectors clean to ensure they are most effective.

questions.text: When a driver operates the indicator switch and hears a more rapid clicking noise than normal, what could this mean?

options.text: The voltage regulator in your car is not functioning properly.
The front and rear indicators are not working in tandem.
The hazard warning lights are on.
An indicator bulb has blown.

questions.explanation: A rapid clicking noise when you turn on an indicator is usually a sign that one of the indicator bulbs has failed. You are responsible for making sure that your vehicle is roadworthy. This should include a regular check that all your lights, including indicators, are working properly.

questions.text: What does ABS do?

options.text: It deploys the airbags during a collision.
It locks the brakes to prevent skidding during harsh braking.
It prevents the wheels from locking under harsh braking conditions.
It displays the name of the radio station playing on the car radio.

questions.explanation: Anti-lock braking system (ABS) is a type of braking system found in most modern cars. It comes into play automatically when you brake harshly. In the wet it can help prevent the wheels from skidding so that you can continue to steer while braking. ABS does not reduce the braking distance.

questions.text: If the brake pedal of a vehicle feels soft or spongy when applied, what does this mean?

options.text: A fault in the brake fluid system.
Worn brake-pads.
Worn handbrake cable.
Over-heated brake-pads.

questions.explanation: If the brake pedal feels soft or spongy when you press it, it could indicate that the brake fluid level is low and there is a fault in the system.Each time you set out on a journey, test your brakes. Check the brake fluid level regularly.

questions.text: How would a driver know if the brake fluid in their vehicle is low?

options.text: Take longer than usual to release.
The brakes feel spongy and soft.
The brakes are unusally sharp.
The brakes feel hard to press.

questions.explanation: If the brake pedal feels soft or spongy when you press it. it could indicate that the brake fluid level is low and there is a fault in the system. Check the brake fluid level regularly, and test the brakes each time you set out on a journey.

questions.text: What is a possible consequence of driving a vehicle in which the brake fluid level is low?

options.text: The vehicle could fail to stop when the brakes are applied, leading to a collision.
The vehicle brakes would react better.
No consequence.
It may improve performance.

questions.explanation: For your brakes to work correctly, you need to make sure that the brake fluid is kept at the correct level. If the brake fluid is low, the brakes will feel spongy or soft, they won/ work as well as they should and this will increase your stopping distance. Low brake fluid could be the difference between stopping safely and having a collision.

questions.text: If a driver applies the foot brake and hears a scraping noise, what is the most likely cause?

options.text: The brake-pads are wet.
There is not enough oil on the brakes.
The brake linings or pads are worn.
There is too much oil on the brakes.

questions.explanation: You should test your brakes before setting out on a journey. If when driving you a scraping noise when you press the brake, the most likely reason is that the brake linings or pads are worn. In this case, your brakes won't work as well as they should. Have worn brake linings or pads replaced immediately.

questions.text: How does a driver know when there is a problem with the brakes in their vehicle?

options.text: The vehicle is sluggish when moving off.
The vehicle's suspension is affected.
The vehicle's stopping ability is affected.
The brake fluid level would be low.

questions.explanation: You should test your brakes before setting out on a journey. If when you are braking you notice that it takes longer than usual to bring the vehicle to a stop, you should have the brakes checked by a mechanic immediately.

questions.text: If driving a vehicle with automatic transmission, what in particular should a driver be aware of?

options.text: That engine braking power is reduced.
That Wheel-spin occurs more often.
That the gearbox may overheat while being driven in a low gear.
That an automatic transmission accelerates faster than a manual transmission.

questions.explanation: When you are driving an automatic vehicle and you release the accelerator, the vehicle will not slow at the same rate as a vehicle with a manual gearbox. You should be aware of this, as you may need to apply the brake earlier in order to stop where required.

questions.text: What effect does automatic transmission have on engine braking power?

options.text: It reduces it.
It transfers the braking ability to the handbrake.
It increases it.
It transfers the braking ability to all the wheels.

questions.explanation: When driving an automatic vehicle and you release the acceleration, the vehicle will not slow at the same rate as a vehicle with a manual gearbox. You should be aware of this, as you may need to apply the brake earlier in order to stop where required.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Roundabout ahead.
'U'-turn permitted ahead.
One-way street ahead.
'U'-turn prohibited ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a roundabout ahead. You must prepare to yield to vehicles already on the roundabout coming from the right.

questions.text: What does a rev counter provide information on?

options.text: Engine revolutions.
Temperature.
Speed.
Fuel level.

questions.explanation: The rev counter measures the speed of the engine. in 'revolutions per minute' Generally, the higher the revs, the more fuel the engine is using, so you should keep an eye on the rev counter to help you drive in a more eco-friendly manner.

questions.text: What does this dial provide information on?

options.text: Engine revolution.
Gearbox revolutions.
Air pressure.
Battery charge.

questions.explanation: The rev counter measures the speed of the engine. in 'revolutions per minute' Generally, the higher the revs, the more fuel the engine is using, so you should keep an eye on the rev counter to help you drive in a more eco-friendly manner.

questions.text: If, when driving along, the driver notices that the engine power is lower than normal, what should they do?

options.text: Have the vehicle checked by a competent mechanic.
Replace the oil filter.
Adjust the fuel mixture control mechanism.
Switch to a different fuel.

questions.explanation: If when driving you notice that the vehicle seems underpowered, you should have the it checked by a competent mechanic as soon as possible. This could be a symptom of one of a number of problems.

questions.text: If the oil gauge shows little or no pressure, what could the problem be?

options.text: The oil level is too low.
The oil level is too high.
The oil is too thin.
The oil is too thick.

questions.explanation: You should check the oil level in your vehicle regularly, and if it is low, top it up. If you find you have to top up very often, you should have the vehicle checked by a mechanic to see if there is a problem.

questions.text: What may happen if the vehicle’s engine oil is not changed regularly?

options.text: It causes excessive exhaust pollution.
It causes the engine to overheat.
It increases the amount of petrol required.
Parts of the engine may suffer increased wear.

questions.explanation: Engine oil becomes dirty over time and must be changed. The oil change is usually done when the vehicle is being serviced.

questions.text: If a vehicle is driven with low oil pressure, what effect does this have on its engine?

options.text: It increases fuel consumption only in wet weather.
It increases wear and tear on the engine.
It increases fuel consumption only in dry weather.
It increases fuel consumption.

questions.explanation: Low oil pressure is usually related to low oil level or to a faulty oil pump. You should check the oil level in your vehicle regularly, and if it is low, top it up. If you find you have to top up very often, you should have the vehicle checked by a mechanic to see if there is a problem.

questions.text: If the vehicle’s oil-pressure gauge is reading low or the red oil-pressure warning light comes on, what should a driver do?

options.text: Drive at lower speeds until the oil level is topped up.
Drive in a low gear and at lower speeds until the oil level is topped up.
Drive in a low gear until the oil level is topped up.
Drive to a safe place, stop the vehicle and check the oil level.

questions.explanation: Oil circulation is essential for the safe running of your vehicle's engine. If the warning lights or gauges tell you that the oil is low or the pressure is low, you should stop as soon as you can in safe place, check the oil level, and top up if necessary Continuing to drive may damage the engine. If the problem is not just related to the oil level, you should have the vehicle checked by a mechanic.

questions.text: What should someone do before checking the engine oil level on a vehicle?

options.text: Make sure that the engine is cold.
Make sure that the engine is running.
Make sure that the engine is hot.
Make sure that the engine is switched off.

questions.explanation: You should have a basic knowledge of the regular checks that should be carried out on your vehicle. Checking the engine oil level is important — do this with the engine switched off.

questions.text: What is the purpose of engine oil?

options.text: It lubricates the engine components.
It lubricates the steering components.
It lubricates the exhaust system.
It lubricates the bonnet.

questions.explanation: The purpose of engine oil is to lubricate and cool the moving parts of the engine.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: 'U'-turn permitted ahead.
Roadworks ahead, diversion in operation.
Mini-roundabout ahead.
'U'-turn prohibited ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a mini-roundabout ahead. You must prepare to yield to vehicles already on the roundabout coming from the right.

questions.text: What is the function of an engine oil filter?

options.text: It prevents the engine from being over filled.
It replenishes low oil level in the engine.
It prevents excessive wear on the crankshaft.
It prevents the circulation of sediment in the oil.

questions.explanation: The oil filter collects impurities and sediment from the oil and so helps to reduce damage and wear and tear on the engine. The oil filter must be changed regularly — this is usually done when the vehicle is being serviced.

questions.text: While driving, a driver notices a strong smell of fuel. What should they do?

options.text: Stop where safe and investigate.
Check the exhaust system.
Drive at a reduced speed.
Check that the fuel cap is secured properly.

questions.explanation: A strong smell of fuel is usually an indication that something is wrong. and you should stop and investigate as soon as possible. Leaking or spilling petrol can be dangerous because it is so combustible, and leaking diesel fuel can make the road very slippery.

questions.text: When is it recommended to use coolant or antifreeze?

options.text: Summer only.
All year round.
Winter only.
Only in petrol engine vehicles.

questions.explanation: The purpose of coolant is to keep the engine cool during operation. Coolant is usually a mixture of water and antifreeze —this ensures that the coolant does not freeze in very cold weather.

questions.text: What does the warning light and/or red zone on a fuel gauge mean?

options.text: The presence of leaded fuel.
A leak in the fuel system.
The level of fuel in the tank is low.
Overfilling.

questions.explanation: Many vehicles are fitted with various warning lights and gauges. A red zone or a warning light on a fuel gauge means the vehicle is low in fuel and should be re-fuelled as soon as possible.

questions.text: While driving, the driver notices the vehicle temperature gauge showing red. What should they do?

options.text: Drive on to the nearest service depot and fill up with water.
Stop in a safe place and have the problem investigated.
Remove filler cap from radiator and check for leakage.
Not drive until anti-waxing agent is added to the coolant.

questions.explanation: Many vehicles are fitted with various warning lights and gauges. A warning light or a red zone on a temperature gauge means the engine is starting to overheat and the vehicle should not be driven until the problem is rectified.

questions.text: What should a driver do if they notice steam rising from the engine compartment?

options.text: Not drive until anti-waxing agent is added to the coolant.
Drive on to the nearest service depot and fill up with water.
Remove filler cap from radiator and check for leakage.
Stop where safe and investigate the cause.

questions.explanation: When a vehicle shows signs of overheating, you should stop in a safe place and investigate the problem. Do not drive a vehicle whose engine is overheating, as this could damage the engine.

questions.text: If a driver notices that parts of their vehicle’s body have been affected by rust, what should they do?

options.text: Have paint sprayed over it of the same colour.
Treat the area with grease and paint over it.
Have it sandpapered and keep the affected area dry.
Have it repaired by a competent repair shop.

questions.explanation: Over time vehicles may become affected by rust to various degrees. You should inspect your vehicle's body periodically and if you find signs of rust you should have it assessed and repaired if necessary to prevent further deterioration.

questions.text: What effect can a worn shock absorber have on a vehicle?

options.text: It can increase fuel consumption.
It can release the airbags.
It can cause the vehicle to 'bounce in an unstable manner.
It can cause an electrical short circuit.

questions.explanation: A worn shock absorber can make a vehicle difficulty to control especially on uneven surfaces and it can increase stopping distance.

questions.text: What effect would a weakly charged battery have on a vehicle’s driving performance?

options.text: It would have no effect.
Uphill acceleration would be reduced.
The fuel would burn less efficiently.
It would improve performance.

questions.explanation: It might be difficult to start a car with a weak battery, but once the engine is running, it makes no difference. You should replace the battery before it runs out completely.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the battery fitted to a petrol - or diesel - powered motor vehicle?

options.text: Run the parking lights.
Turn the starter motor.
Provide heat to the passenger compartment.
To start the engine.

questions.explanation: The primary purpose of the battery is to start the engine. When the engine is running, it produces its own electricity to charge the battery and run the various electrical components, including lights, heating, radio and so on.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Straight ahead only.
Overtaking lane ahead.
Parking permitted from this point on.
One way street ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you that you must proceed straight ahead. This sign is usually displayed on the entry to a one-way street.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Dangerous bend ahead.
Junction to the left ahead.
One-way street ahead.
Dangerous corner ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a dangerous corner to the left. You should slow down and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

questions.text: What happens if the vehicle has a flat battery?

options.text: The engine will not start.
The battery will have to be replaced.
The battery will not work to full its full efficiency.
Smoke will rise from the vehicle.

questions.explanation: All motor vehicles have a battery to supply power. primarily to start the engine. If the battery is flat, you will not be able to start the engine in the normal way. When the engine is running, it produces its own electricity to recharge the battery and run the various electrical components, including lights, heating, the radio and so on.

questions.text: What should the driver be able to see in the vehicle mirrors when they have been properly adjusted?

options.text: The position of the left side wheels.
The area behind and to each side of the vehicle.
The position of all the wheels.
The passenger area of the vehicle.

questions.explanation: Your mirrors enable you to see the road behind and to the sides. This helps you to take into account what's happening behind you, so that you can make informed, correct and safe decisions.

questions.text: What should the driver be able to see in the exterior mirrors of a vehicle when they have been properly adjusted?

options.text: Be angled 60% to the car and 40% to the road.
The sides of the vehicle only.
The sides of the vehicle and the roads to the side.
Should not show the sides of the vehicle.

questions.explanation: Exterior mirrors enable you to see to the side of the vehicle, and to take into account all visible hazards and make correct and safe decisions.

questions.text: The vehicle’s exterior mirrors are covered by a film of mud and dust. What should the driver do?

options.text: Drive on as normal, as driving in the slipstream of other traffic will clean them eventually.
Angle them towards the front for a distance in order to clean them.
Clean them with a cloth or tissue before continuing on.
Just use the interior mirror.

questions.explanation: Keep your mirrors clean and properly adjusted, so that your view of the road to the rear and sides is clear and unhindered.

questions.text: When a driver is making a left-hand turn, what mirrors should they particularly concentrate on?

options.text: The interior and right mirror.
The interior mirror.
The interior and left exterior mirror.
The right-hand wing mirror.

questions.explanation: When you are turning left, you should be aware that cyclists and other vehicles may come up on your inside. For that reason it is particularly important to check your left exterior mirror and your internal mirror before turning. Always use the Mirror-signal-mirror (blind spots)-manoeuvre routine when you are turning and be extra careful if you have to cross a bus lane to make the turn.

questions.text: What effect can wet weather have on a vehicle’s exterior mirrors?

options.text: It can make reflected images appear closer than they really are.
It can cause a short circuit in electrically heated mirrors.
It can keep them clean.
Water droplets can obscure the reflected image.

questions.explanation: In rain and damp conditions, small water droplets can form on the glass of the exterior mirror s. This could make it more difficult to see the road behind and to the sides. Switch on the mirror demisters, if you have them.

questions.text: What does blue smoke coming from the vehicle’s exhaust mean?

options.text: The engine is burning oil.
The catalytic converter is worn out.
The engine is overheating.
The air filter needs to be replaced.

questions.explanation: As an engine gets old or if it is not properly maintained, it can ;burn oil' and give off ;blue smoke' from the exhaust This is harmful to the atmosphere and should be corrected.

questions.text: What is the effect of a worn exhaust?

options.text: Fuel efficiency is decreased.
The engine overheats.
Gear-changing is more difficult.
The filtering of fumes is reduced and engine noise is louder.

questions.explanation: A worn exhaust system can have a number of effects. including increased noise from the engine and more fumes (as they are not filtered properly).

questions.text: How can a faulty exhaust affect your vehicle?

options.text: It can increase the noise and pollution levels.
It can lessen the engine noise.
It can improve fuel consumption.
It can increase wear on the engine.

questions.explanation: A worn exhaust system can have a number of effects. including increased noise from the engine and more fumes (as they are not filtered properly).

questions.text: What is the purpose of a catalytic converter?

options.text: It decreases engine power.
It filters exhaust gases and reduces air pollution.
It allows the engine to quickly reach its normal operating temperature.
It increases engine power.

questions.explanation: The purpose of a catalytic converter (CAT) is to remove toxic or polluting gases such as carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxide and unburned hydrocarbons from the exhaust emissions.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: No left turn.
Dangerous corner ahead.
Turn left.
Dangerous bend ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a dangerous bend ahead. You should slow down and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

questions.text: What does the speed rating of a tyre indicate?

options.text: The maximum speed for which the tyre is designed.
The speed not to be exceeded at maximum loading of the vehicle.
The maximum speed which the tyre can take on a dry road.
The maximum speed the tyre can take when the vehicle is unladen.

questions.explanation: The speed rating of a tyre is the maximum speed for which the tyre is designed. This relates to the speed capability of the tyre. It does not relate to the speed at which the tyre should or could legally be driven.

questions.text: Why should the valve be replaced when having a tubeless tyre fitted?

options.text: To ensure that the wheel can be aligned correctly.
To ensure that the wheel nuts can be tightened correctly.
To ensure that the wheel can be balanced correctly.
To ensure the tyre will stay inflated.

questions.explanation: When fitting a new tubeless tyre to a vehicle it is a good idea to change the valve also, because it has presumably been on the wheel since the old tyre was fitted: and it could break down, leak and cause the air to escape.

questions.text: After changing a wheel on a vehicle, which of the following should be checked soon afterwards?

options.text: The brake-pad clearance.
Tyre tread depth.
Air valve.
The wheel nuts.

questions.explanation: A short period after you have changed a wheel on a vehicle, you should check- The type pressure, to make sure it is correct; and The wheel nuts, to ensure they are still properly secured.

questions.text: After changing a wheel on a vehicle, which of the following should be checked soon afterwards?

options.text: Air valve.
The tyre pressure.
The brake-pad clearance.
Tyre tread depth.

questions.explanation: A short period after you have changed a wheel on a vehicle, you should check- The type pressure, to make sure it is correct; and The wheel nuts, to ensure they are still properly secured.

questions.text: In general, how often should a driver check the tyre pressure of a vehicle?

options.text: Annualy.
Regularly.
Monthly.
Rarely.

questions.explanation: As a driver, it is your legal responsibility to make sure that your vehicle is roadworthy. To do this, you should carry out weekly and periodical checks, including a weekly tyre pressure check.

questions.text: Why should tyres be kept at the pressure specified by the manufacturer?

options.text: Stop the vehicle from sloping to the left.
To help provide optimum road holding.
In maintaining the correct ground clearance.
Reduce engine wear.

questions.explanation: The vehicle manufacturer specifies the pressure to which tyres on a vehicle should be inflated. This is the pressure that gives the best performance in road holding, efficient braking and fuel consumption. Most manufacturers specify different pressures for front or rear tyres.

questions.text: A fault in what component would lead to uneven or excessive tyre wear?

options.text: Gearbox.
Suspension.
Accelerator.
Engine.

questions.explanation: If a vehicle has a worn suspension it may lead to uneven or excessive tyre wear. If you notice that your tyres are unevenly worn, you should investigate the reason and have it repaired.

questions.text: What can be affected by driving on under-inflated tyres?

options.text: Fuel consumption.
The exhaust system.
Oil pressure.
Improve braking ability.

questions.explanation: Incorrect tyre pressure adversely affects many of the vehicles systems, including brakes, suspension and steering. In particular, under-inflated tyres can increase the vehicle's fuel consumption.

questions.text: What can be affected by driving on under-inflated tyres?

options.text: Oil pressure.
Braking ability.
The exhaust system.
Improve braking ability.

questions.explanation: Incorrect tyre pressure adversely affects many of a vehicle's systems including suspension, steering and fuel consumption. In particular, under-inflated tyres can affect the vehicle's braking ability.

questions.text: When should tyre pressure be checked?

options.text: When the tyres are cold.
When the vehicle is loaded.
When the vehicle is unladen.
When the tyres are hot.

questions.explanation: You should check the tyre pressure in your vehicle once a week. Do this when the tyres are cold, using a reliable gauge. Tyres should always be inflated according to the vehicles manufacture's guidelines.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Series of dangerous corners ahead.
Overhead electric cables.
Temporary surface ahead, keep left.
Slippery road ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a series of dangerous corners ahead. You should slow down and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

questions.text: What effect does low tyre-pressure have on a vehicle?

options.text: Braking and cornering are impaired.
The brakes can overheat.
Engine noise increases.
The vehicle accelerates faster.

questions.explanation: Incorrect tyre pressure adversely affects many of a vehicles systems, including suspension, steering and fuel consumption. In particular, under-inflated tyres can affect the vehicles braking ability and its effectiveness when cornering.

questions.text: During a weekly check, a driver notices a badly worn front tyre. What should they do?

options.text: Check the tyre pressure to ensure it remains constant.
Fit it on one of the rear wheels.
Reduce speed on wet roads.
Have the worn tyre replaced.

questions.explanation: The quality of the tyres on a vehicle is an important factor in the vehicle's road holding and braking ability. So if you notice that a tyre is badly worn, you should replace it as soon as possible. The minimum legal tread depth for tyres on most vehicles is 1.6mm, but you should replace a tyre before it becomes this worn.

questions.text: What effect could hitting or mounting the kerb have on a vehicle’s tyres?

options.text: It could put them off balance.
It could damage the sidewalls.
It could allow air to escape from them.
It could increase tyre pressure.

questions.explanation: If a vehicle hits or mounts the kerb it could damage the sidewall of the tyre. If that happens it could cause the tyre to 'blow-out' later. If this happens at high speed the vehicle could go out of control and crash.

questions.text: What does worn tread along the edge of a tyre suggest?

options.text: Driver is driving too fast around corners.
Air pressure is low.
Steering alignment may be faulty.
Air pressure is high.

questions.explanation: If you notice that a tyre on your vehicle is worn along its edge, this may indicate a problem with the steering alignment This is a potentially dangerous problem, and you should have it fixed as soon as possible.

questions.text: What effect would under-inflated tyres have on a vehicle’s transmission?

options.text: It would make it more difficult to change gears.
It would have no effect on it.
It would cause the clutch to overheat.
It would be easier to change gears.

questions.explanation: Incorrect tyre pressure adversely affects many of a vehicles systems, including braking, suspension, steering and fuel consumption. It does not, however, affect the engine transmission.

questions.text: What should a driver do before undertaking a long journey?

options.text: Check the tyres are inflated to normal air pressure.
Increase the air pressure in your tyres.
Reduce the air pressure in your tyres.
Eat a snack.

questions.explanation: It is important to check the tyre pressure before starting a long journey as incorrect air pressure can adversely affect many of the vehicles systems, including brakes, steering, suspension and fuel consumption.

questions.text: Under what circumstances should a driver increase the air pressure in the tyres before undertaking a long journey?

options.text: Only if high speeds are anticipated.
Always.
Only if the tread depth is below 1.6mm.
Never.

questions.explanation: Check the air pressure before you start a long journey, and when you inflate the tyres, make sure that you follow the vehicle manufacturers recommended tyre pressure This is the pressure that gives the best performance in road holding, efficient braking and fuel consumption.

questions.text: What is the effect of under-inflated tyres on a vehicle?

options.text: Increase the rate of wear on the vehicle's engine and transmission.
Impaired braking and steering.
Improved fuel economy and braking.
Improved braking and steering.

questions.explanation: Check the tyre pressure once a week. Incorrect tyre pressure adversely affects many of a vehicle's systems, including braking ability, suspension, steering and fuel consumption.

questions.text: What effect would coasting have on a vehicle’s tyres?

options.text: It would cause them to lose air pressure.
It would increase the rate of wear on them.
No effect.
It would increase the tyres pressure.

questions.explanation: Coasting is a bad practice that happens when a driver allows a vehicle to move by its own momentum (or by gravity — for example, down a hill) with the engine disengaged. This can be done in two ways: 1. By putting the car into neutral gear while moving; or 2. By keeping the clutch pedal pressed down to disengage the selected gear. If a vehicle is coasting, the driver has much less control, so you should never coast. However, it has no effect on tyres.

questions.text: What should the driver do to secure the vehicle when changing a wheel?

options.text: Point the front wheels towards the kerb.
Point the front wheels away from the kerb.
Ensure that the gear lever is in neutral.
Ensure that the vehicle cannot roll when jacked up.

questions.explanation: If you have to change a wheel, make sure you do it in a safe place on level ground. Also, apply the handbrake and engage a low gear to secure the vehicle before you jack it up.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Diversion ahead.
Slippery road ahead.
Series of dangerous bends ahead.
Steep climb ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a series of dangerous bends ahead. You should slow down and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

questions.text: While driving, what does a continuous vibration in the steering indicate?

options.text: The shock absorbers are worn.
The steering is out of alignment.
The wheel balance is uneven.
Weight distribution is uneven.

questions.explanation: If you feel a continuous vibration in the steering, particularly at higher speeds, this could indicate that the balance of the vehicle wheels is uneven. If this is the case, you should have it investigated by a mechanic.

questions.text: What can cause heavy steering?

options.text: Under-inflated tyres.
Badly worn brakes.
Poorly oiled steering.
Over-inflated tyres.

questions.explanation: Heavy steering is when you need to use more effort than usual to turn the steering wheel. You might experience this if the power-assisted steering system is not working properly, or more commonly, if the front tyres are under-inflated.

questions.text: When driving, where should a driver rest their left foot?

options.text: Under the brake-pedal.
On the floor or footrest.
Under the clutch pedal.
On the clutch pedal.

questions.explanation: The clutch is the connection between the engine and the gearbox. It enables the vehicle to move when a gear is engaged. You should not rest your foot on the clutch pedal because it may disengage the selected gear or damage the clutch mechanism.

questions.text: How does harsh acceleration affect fuel consumption?

options.text: Fuel consumption increases.
There is no effect provided the engine is properly tuned.
Fuel consumption decreases.
There is no effect, if a high gear is engaged.

questions.explanation: Harsh acceleration increases fuel consumption, and driving smoothly helps to reduce your fuel consumption and the emissions from your vehicle. Try not to over-rev the engine and use the appropriate gear for the speed of the vehicle. When slowing down, take your foot off the accelerator and allow the vehicle to slowly progressively before you brake.

questions.text: What should a driver do to minimise fuel consumption in their vehicle?

options.text: Use gently acceleration and braking.
Change rapidly up through the gears.
Drive with the choke out.
Drive in a low gear.

questions.explanation: Driving smoothly will help reduce your fuel consumption. Read the road ahead and adjust your speed in good time, and avoid harsh acceleration and late braking.

questions.text: How does continuous high-speed driving affect fuel consumption?

options.text: It reduces fuel consumption.
It increases fuel consumption only in wet weather.
It increases fuel consumption.
It reduces fuel consumption as long as the road is dry and straight.

questions.explanation: Driving at high speeds increases your fuel consumption. A vehicle travelling at 112km/h uses approximately 30% more fuel than one travelling at 80km/h.

questions.text: What should a driver do to ensure better fuel efficiency from their vehicle?

options.text: Ensure any load carried is equally distributed on the vehicle.
Ensure that the vehicle is regularly serviced.
Ensure that heavier items are carried at the rear of the vehicle.
Drive at higher speeds in order to reduce the time spent on the road.

questions.explanation: One of the keys to good fuel efficiency is making sure that your vehicle is well maintained. Servicing should be carried out as recommended by the manufacturer. Checking the tyre pressure regularly can also help ensure good fuel efficiency.

questions.text: How can fuel efficiency be improved?

options.text: By using gentle acceleration and making gear changes appropriate to speed.
Driving the vehicle in a lower gear for as long as possible.
Accelerating hard up through the gears to reach the desired speed as quickly as possible.
Only using an anti-waxing agent in freezing conditions.

questions.explanation: The way you drive can contribute to your vehicle's fuel efficiency: 1. Accelerate gently; 2. Use the highest available gear (without causing the engine to struggle): and 3. Drive smoothly—this also reduces wear and tear on a vehicle.

questions.text: What effect does a worn exhaust have on a vehicle?

options.text: It causes the water coolant to leak form the engine.
It causes oil to leak on to the road.
It causes noise and gas pollution levels to increase.
It increases fuel consumption.

questions.explanation: A vehicle with a worn exhaust will probably be noisier and will produce more polluting emissions. There are strict regulations governing the noise and emission levels of vehicles, and these are rigorously checked during a vehicle's NCT.

questions.text: When is the use of the horn prohibited?

options.text: Always, but only for momentary use.
Between 11:30pm and 7:00am in a built-up area.
Never.
Between 11:30pm and 7:00am.

questions.explanation: You are not allowed to use the horn in a built-up area between 11:30pm and 7:00am unless there is a traffic emergency. Only use a horn to warn other road users of oncoming danger or if you need to make them aware of your presence for safety reasons. Using the horn does not give you an automatic right of way. Never use the horn to provoke a reaction from or to rebuke another motorist.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Road closed - you must turn back.
Traffic from the left has priority.
Series of speed ramps ahead.
Sharp change of direction ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a sharp change of direction to your right. You should slow down as you approach the hazard.

questions.text: Under what circumstances is it permitted to replace the standard horn on a vehicle with a musical horn?

options.text: Never.
During an emergency situation.
When the vehicle is a service vehicle.
During daylight hours.

questions.explanation: A horn is designed to be an audible warning device. You should not make any technical modifications to the horn without professional advice as these may have legal and safety implications.

questions.text: Is a driver allowed to sound the horn while driving in a built-up area at night?

options.text: Yes, but between 11:30pm and 7:00am the horn may be sounded only in an emergency.
Yes, any time in a built-up area.
Yes, between 10.00 pm and 6.00 am in a built-up area.
No.

questions.explanation: You are not allowed to use the horn in a built-up area between 11:30pm and 7:00am unless there is a traffic emergency. Only use a horn to warn other road users of oncoming danger or if you need to make them aware of your presence for safety reasons. Using a horn does not give you an automatic right of way. Never use the horn to provoke a reaction from or to rebuke another motorist.

questions.text: What can be adversely affected by under-inflated tyres?

options.text: Parking.
Steering.
Changing gear.
Reversing.

questions.explanation: Under-inflated tyres can increase the effort required to steer the vehicle. Always make sure the tyres are properly inflated by checking the tyre pressures regularly. Incorrect tyre pressure adversely affects many of a vehicle's systems, including brakes, suspension and fuel consumption. in particular, under-inflated tyres can affect the vehicle's steering.

questions.text: In what way do motor vehicles harm the environment?

options.text: By increasing carbon monoxide levels.
By changing gears less.
No they actually reduced health risks.
By parking less.

questions.explanation: Carbon monoxide is a poisonous gas emitted by vehicle exhausts into the atmosphere. Driving economically and keeping a vehicle well maintained can reduce the level of carbon monoxide emissions.

questions.text: What can a driver do to help the environment?

options.text: Read the road and plan ahead.
Drive on under-inflated tyres.
Use the choke for as long as possible on a cold engine.
Brake as late as possible.

questions.explanation: Drivers should plan well ahead and avoid harsh acceleration and braking, both of which can waste fuel and increase pollution.

questions.text: What can a driver do to maximise fuel efficiency while driving?

options.text: Avoid carrying unnecessary weight.
Reducing your speed.
Using different brands of fuel.
Drive at a higher speed.

questions.explanation: The more extra weight is in your vehicle. the more fuel you use. Using a roof rack or a roof box increases wind resistance and this also increases fuel consumption — by as much as 15%. Remove roof racks and roof boxes when not in use.

questions.text: Which action is likely to cause an increase in fuel consumption?

options.text: Looking ahead and anticipating traffic flow.
Harsh acceleration.
Driving at a constant speed.
Driving at a lower speed.

questions.explanation: Harsh acceleration increases fuel consumption. Driving smoothly reduces wear and tear and also improves fuel consumption. Use the highest gear possible without causing the engine to labour.

questions.text: What alternatives can drivers take to help protect the environment?

options.text: Use public transport.
Accelerate rapidly and brake harshly when driving.
Don't use your indicators when turning.
Take longer routes to your destination.

questions.explanation: Using public transport helps to protect the environment. Buses. trams and trains are a more environmentally friendly way to move large numbers of people especially in urban areas. Consider using public transport where possible — not only is it more environmentally friendly, but it can also be more cost-effective when you take the cost of fuel and parking charges into account.

questions.text: What can drivers do to help protect the environment?

options.text: Accelerate rapidly and brake harshly when driving.
Car share.
Don't use your indicators when turning.
Take longer routes to your destination.

questions.explanation: Car sharing helps the environment. Drivers should consider car sharing for routine journeys to work or for the school run. This will reduce pollution and reduce traffic congestion at peak times.

questions.text: What can be achieved by the driving style known as ‘Eco-Driving’?

options.text: Reduced fuel consumption.
Increased speed.
Less use of indicators.
Less tyre wear.

questions.explanation: The advantages of 'eco-driving include improved road safety, improved fuel consumption and reduced emissions. The eco-conscious driver becomes a more efficient driver because they learn to read the road further ahead and display better anticipation skills. This reduces the need for harsh acceleration and braking which results in a more economical style of driving and a smoother drive.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Left-hand lane has an uneven surface.
You must overtake on the right only.
Merging traffic from the left.
Road narrows on the left.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning that the road narrows on the left ahead. You should show caution and prepare to move to the right.

questions.text: What can be achieved by the driving style known as ‘Eco-Driving’?

options.text: Increased speed.
Increased road safety.
Less use of indicators.
Less tyre wear.

questions.explanation: The advantages of 'eco-driving' include improved road safety, improved fuel consumption and reduced emissions. The eco-conscious driver becomes a more efficient driver because they learn to read the road further ahead and display better anticipation skills. This reduces the need for harsh acceleration and braking which results in a more economical style of driving and a smoother drive.

questions.text: What can be achieved by the driving style known as ‘Eco-Driving’?

options.text: Less use of indicators.
Increased speed.
Reduced emissions.
Less tyre wear.

questions.explanation: The advantages of 'eco-driving' include improved road safety, improved fuel consumption and reduced emissions. The eco-conscious driver becomes a more efficient driver because they learn to read the road further ahead and display better anticipation skills. This reduces the need for harsh acceleration and braking which results in a more economical style of driving and a smoother drive.

questions.text: Which action contributes to Eco-Driving?

options.text: Braking harshly.
Selecting a high gear as soon as possible.
Driving in a low gear at high speed.
Fast acceleration.

questions.explanation: 'Eco driving' contributes to road safety and also reduces fuel consumption and harmful emissions. Eco-conscious drivers read the road well road ahead and anticipate what is going to happen in front. This reduces the need for harsh acceleration and braking. Fuel consumption can be reduced by using the highest gear possible without causing the engine to labour.

questions.text: Which action contributes to Eco-Driving?

options.text: Braking harshly.
