Maintaining a steady speed.
Driving in a low gear at high speed.
Fast acceleration.

questions.explanation: 'Eco driving' contributes to road safety and also reduces fuel consumption and harmful emissions. Eco drivers will read the road well in advance and avoid harsh acceleration and late braking. Drive smoothly and maintaining a steady speed saves fuel and reduces wear and tear on vehicles.

questions.text: Which action contributes to Eco-Driving?

options.text: Driving in a low gear at high speed.
Braking harshly.
Looking ahead and anticipating.
Fast acceleration.

questions.explanation: 'Eco driving' contributes to road safety and also reduces fuel consumption and harmful emissions. Eco-conscious drivers read the road well road ahead and anticipate what is going to happen in front. This reduces the need for harsh acceleration and braking which results in a more comfortable and safer drive while saving fuel and reducing emissions.

questions.text: How can a driver help the environment?

options.text: By Reducing speed.
By accelerating harshly.
By braking suddenly.
By using your indicators sparingly.

questions.explanation: Drivers should plan well ahead, drive smoothly and avoid harsh acceleration and braking vehicles travelling 112km/h use up 30% more fuel than those travelling at 80km/h. However, you should not drive so slow as to inconvenience other road users.

questions.text: What can cause a vehicle to skid?

options.text: Not having enough pressure in the tyres.
The steering wheel being too free or pliable.
Using harsh acceleration.
Having too much pressure in the tyres.

questions.explanation: Using harsh acceleration at the wrong time can cause a vehicle to skid, especially if the road is wet

questions.text: What can cause a vehicle to skid?

options.text: The steering wheel being too free or pliable.
Excessively heavy braking.
Not having enough pressure in the tyres.
Having too much pressure in the tyres.

questions.explanation: Heavy braking can cause a vehicle to skid, particularly if the road surface is wet or uneven, or if the tyres are worn or incorrectly inflated. Read the road well ahead and try to avoid heavy braking, particularly in wet or slippery conditions.

questions.text: What can cause a vehicle to skid?

options.text: The steering wheel being too free or pliable.
Not having enough pressure in the tyres.
Excessive speed.
Having too much pressure in the tyres.

questions.explanation: Excessive speed can result in a vehicle going into a skid. You should always drive at a safe speed and never exceed the speed limit for the road you are on. Excessive speed is particularly dangerous in wet and slippery conditions.

questions.text: What should a driver do if a front tyre bursts?

options.text: Pull on the handbrake.
Brake as quickly as possible.
Grip the steering wheel firmly.
Continue on at a normal speed.

questions.explanation: If a front tyre bursts on a vehicle, the steering on the vehicle will become unstable. Don't panic— slow down gradually while keeping a firm hold on the steering wheel. Stop in a safe place to change the wheel, and alert other road users by switching

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Road narrows on both sides.
Dual-carriageway ahead.
Railway crossing ahead.
Tunnel ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning that the road is narrowing ahead. You should show caution and prepare to slow down.

questions.text: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets a puncture on a motorway?

options.text: Driver slowly to the next service area to get assistance.
Stop in your lane.
Pull in where safe on the hard shoulder and call for assistance.
Drive on to the nearest exit.

questions.explanation: Don't try to change a wheel on a motorway. as this could be very dangerous. Drive the car on to the hard shoulder, and when it is safe to do so, get out of the vehicle and move behind the barrier. Call for assistance from a motorway emergency phone or using a mobile phone (call the Gardaí).

questions.text: What precautions could a driver take against the risk of fire in their vehicle?

options.text: Keep water levels above the maximum mark.
Avoid driving with a full tank of petrol.
Use unleaded petrol.
Investigate strong fumes and carry a fire extinguisher.

questions.explanation: A strong smell of fuel is usually an indication that something is wrong, and you should stop and investigate as soon as possible. Leaking or spilling petrol can be dangerous because it is so combustible. It is good practice to carry a fire extinguisher in your vehicle, so that you can deal with any small fires

questions.text: When should a driver use hazard warning lights on a motorway?

options.text: When the vehicle has broken down.
Another vehicle is following too closely.
When the driver is towing another vehicle.
When driving on the hard shoulder.

questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on a motorway, drive it to the hard shoulder and switch on the hazard warning lights to warn following traffic. When it is safe to do so. get out of the vehicle and move behind the barrier. Call for assistance from a motorway emergency phone or using a mobile phone (call the Gardaí)

questions.text: What should a driver do if their vehicle is broken down and they are awaiting assistance?

options.text: Get out of the vehicle and wait at the rear of it.
Attempt to flag down drivers approaching from the rear.
Switch on the vehicle hazard warning lights, get out of the vehicle and stand to the side.
Direct traffic to pass your vehicle.

questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the road, always switch on the hazard warning lights and stand clear of the vehicle while awaiting assistance — this will warn other traffic that there is a vehicle stopped on the road.

questions.text: What action should a driver take when they notice flashing blue lights in the rear-view mirror?

options.text: Beckon the driver to overtake you.
Drive on more quickly to avoid causing obstruction.
Turn into the next available side-road.
Move to the left, reduce speed and allow the vehicle to pass.

questions.explanation: When you notice an emergency vehicle in the rear-view mirror, you should move into the left where it is safe and allow the vehicle to pass safely. Avoid stopping immediately as this could cause a greater obstruction to the emergency vehicle.

questions.text: What should a driver do when they see road works machinery with amber flashing lights up ahead?

options.text: Engage 1st gear immediately.
Slow down and prepare to stop if necessary.
Proceed at your normal speed.
Do 'U'-turn because the road is blocked.

questions.explanation: When you notice works vehicles ahead, slow down and be prepared to stop for the road works. Be extra careful driving through road works as the road surface could be uneven or slippery.

questions.text: What action should a driver take when they meet a vehicle with flashing blue lights?

options.text: Move to the left, reduce speed and stop if necessary.
Stop immediately.
Switch on your hazard warning lights.
Flash your headlights to acknowledge that you have seen it.

questions.explanation: When a driver notices an emergency vehicle approaching in the distance, they should check their mirror and move to the left to allow the vehicle to pass. On some occasions it may be necessary to stop.

questions.text: What should a driver do if an ambulance is stopped up ahead with its flashing blue lights on?

options.text: Reduce speed and prepare to stop if necessary.
Stop to see what's happening.
Stop to offer assistance.
Drive in the centre of the road to prevent other drivers from overtaking.

questions.explanation: When you come upon an emergency vehicle stopped on the road, you should slow down and be prepared to stop. Do not stop to see what is happening as this could be dangerous and you might cause an obstruction to the flow of traffic.

questions.text: How are emergency vehicles identified?

options.text: By flashing green lights.
By flashing red or blue lights.
By alternating flashing amber and white lights.
By continuously lit red lights.

questions.explanation: If you hear or see an emergency vehicle approaching sounding its siren or flashing lights, be extra careful and give way if it is safe to do so.

questions.text: Which vehicle is exempt from speed limits when being used in an emergency?

options.text: Fire brigade.
Doctor.
Mountain rescue.
Bus breakdown service.

questions.explanation: In the course of their duty Gardai, Fire Brigade and ambulance personnel are exempt from some traffic laws including speed limits, as long as they do not put other road users in danger. If you hear or see a Garda or emergency vehicle approaching under emergency conditions, be careful and give way, if it is safe to do so.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Lay-by ahead.
Road divides ahead.
Two lanes of oncoming traffic merge ahead.
Roundabout ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning that the road divides ahead. You should prepare to move to the left.

questions.text: Which vehicle is exempt from speed limits when being used in an emergency?

options.text: Doctor.
Ambulance.
Mountain rescue.
Bus breakdown service.

questions.explanation: In the course of their duty Gardai, Fire Brigade and ambulance personnel are exempt from some traffic laws including speed limits, as long as they do not put other road users in danger. If you hear or see a Garda or emergency vehicle approaching under emergency conditions, be careful and give way, if it is safe to do so.

questions.text: Which vehicle is exempt from speed limits when being used in an emergency?

options.text: Mountain rescue.
Doctor.
Bus breakdown service.
Garda.

questions.explanation: In the course of their duty Gardai, Fire Brigade and ambulance personnel are exempt from some traffic laws including speed limits, as long as they do not put other road users in danger. If you hear or see a Garda or emergency vehicle approaching under emergency conditions, be careful and give way, if it is safe to do so.

questions.text: What should a driver do when they want to use a mobile phone?

options.text: Reduce speed and be alert for other road users.
Pull in and stop in a safe place.
Allow a wider gap to open up with the vehicle in front and continue at normal speed.
Keep the conversation short.

questions.explanation: It is illegal to use a mobile phone while driving. Driving requires all of your attention, allot the time, so you should never use a mobile phone while on the road. If you want to use a mobile phone, you should find a safe place to stop.

questions.text: When parked on a busy road, what should the driver be aware of?

options.text: Before opening the door the driver should make sure it is safe to do so.
The handbrake is not applied.
The wheels of the vehicle are angles away from the kerb.
The gear lever is in the neutral position before getting out.

questions.explanation: When you park a vehicle on a busy road, make sure it is safe before opening the door, as there could be traffic passing close by.

questions.text: What should a driver be aware of when queuing where there are multiple lanes of traffic?

options.text: Motorcycles or bicycles may come up on either side.
Motorcycles or bicycles may come up on your right.
Motorcycles or bicycles may come up on either side only when there is a roundabout ahead.
Motorcycles or bicycles may come up on your left.

questions.explanation: When you are queuing in traffic, use your mirrors, and watch out for vulnerable road users such as motorcyclists and cyclists passing on either side.

questions.text: In this situation, what should the driver in the right-hand lane of the dual carriageway be aware of?

options.text: Crosswinds may blow the rider into their path.
Reduced visibility.
Oncoming traffic.
The motorcyclist may perform a 'U'-turn.

questions.explanation: In wet and windy conditions, watch out for vulnerable road users being blown into your path.

questions.text: What should a driver do before towing a caravan?

options.text: Carry all passengers in the caravan.
Switch on the hazard warning lights.
Have extended mirrors fitted to the towing vehicle and use them regularly.
Carry only adults in the caravan.

questions.explanation: If you intend towing a caravan that is wider than the vehicle that is towing it, you should fit extended mirrors to both sides of the towing vehicle, so that you will be able to assess the traffic situation behind and to the sides.

questions.text: What should a driver do before towing a wide-bodied trailer?

options.text: Drive with a red flag to the front right-hand side of the trailer.
Drive with full headlights on.
Drive with a red flag at the rear of the trailer.
Make use of extended mirrors to check for following traffic.

questions.explanation: If you intend towing a trailer that is wider or higher than the vehicle that is towing it, you should fit extended mirrors to both sides of the towing vehicle, so that you will be able to assess the traffic situation behind and to the sides.

questions.text: Why is it important to have clean, clear windows?

options.text: To enable other road users to see you.
To ensure good all round visibility from the vehicle.
To avoid condensation.
To improve the maintenance of windows.

questions.explanation: Make sure the windows of your vehicle are clear and clean at all times so that you can see road and traffic conditions around you. Dirty windows are particularly hazardous when the sun is low and at night.

questions.text: If the vehicle’s windows are covered with ice, what should the driver do before undertaking a journey?

options.text: Clear the ice from the windows before starting.
Clear enough space in the windscreen to be able to see ahead.
Use boiling water to clear the ice.
Drive slowly until the heater and demister have cleared the ice from the windows.

questions.explanation: Make sure the windows of your vehicle are clear and clean at all times so that you can see road and traffic conditions around you. This is especially important when driving in slippery conditions. It is good practice to carry a can of de-icer in the vehicle and if possible to fill the washer reservoir with a de-icing agent.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Tunnel ahead.
Dual-carriageway ends.
Oncoming traffic has priority.
Road narrows ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of the end of a dual carriageway. You will soon be entering a 2-way road.

questions.text: What should a driver do if the vehicle’s windows are covered in ice?

options.text: Switch on the heating system and use a scraper to clear the ice before driving.
Switch on the windscreen wipers.
Drive at a reduced speed until the heating system has cleared the ice.
Use boiling water with salt to clear the ice.

questions.explanation: Make sure the windows of your vehicle are clear and clean at all times so that you can see road and traffic conditions around you. This is especially important when driving in slippery conditions. It is good practice to carry a can of de-icer in the vehicle and if possible to fill the washer reservoir with a de-icing agent.

questions.text: What should a driver do if condensation is affecting the vehicle’s windows?

options.text: Close off the air vents.
Wipe the glass with the back of you hand.
Drive for a few kilometers with a window open.
Dry the windows with a cloth and then use the demister system.

questions.explanation: Make sure the windows of your vehicle are clear and clean at all times so that you can see road and traffic conditions around you. Condensation on the window can seriously impair your ability to make proper observations.

questions.text: How can sunlight affect visibility in a car with grimy windows?

options.text: It can create a mirror effect and reduce visibility.
It can enhance visibility.
It can cause objects to seem closer than they are.
It can cause objects to seem further away than they are.

questions.explanation: Make sure the windows of your vehicle are clear and clean at all times so that you can see road and traffic conditions around you. Dirty windows are a particular hazard when the sun is low in the sky and at night.

questions.text: What specific observations should a driver make before reversing their vehicle?

options.text: In the left-hand mirror.
Over your right shoulder.
Look over both shoulders and behind.
In the right hand mirror.

questions.explanation: Before reversing, look over both shoulders and to the rear to check that there are no children or other road users around the vehicle and that it is safe to reverse.

questions.text: What specific observations should a driver make before reversing a vehicle fitted with an audible warning device?

options.text: Should take observations only in the blindspots.
Observations should be made to the front sides and rear of the vehicle, including blind spots.
Need not take observations, as bystanders will be aware of you.
Check your hair in the mirror.

questions.explanation: Before reversing, make sure it is safe to do so by taking all appropriate observations to the front sides and rear of the vehicle, including the blind spots Never assume it is safe to reverse just because the vehicle has an audible warning device.

questions.text: What should a driver do when they intend to reverse onto a side road?

options.text: Turn on your hazard lights to signal your reverse direction.
Open the door fully to look behind.
Turn your steering fully and reverse quickly.
Check carefully all around before and during the reverse.

questions.explanation: Before reversing onto a side road, check all around to make sure it is safe and clear to carry out the manoeuvre, paying particular attention to pedestrians crossing behind the vehicle and any other approaching traffic.

questions.text: What should a driver do when they intend to reverse their vehicle on a busy street?

options.text: Reverse quickly to avoid delay.
Give a hand signal while reversing.
Sound the horn occasionally as you reverse.
Reverse slowly, checking all around for other road users.

questions.explanation: When reversing on a busy street. look all around and reverse slowly because there may be passing traffic and pedestrians attempting to cross the road.

questions.text: What should a driver do if they intend to reverse their vehicle into an area which they cannot see?

options.text: Open your window and look behind.
Open your door and look behind.
Look in the nearside mirror.
Ask someone to assist when reversing.

questions.explanation: Do not attempt to reverse into an area that you cannot see into properly, unless you get assistance from somebody who can advise you when it is safe to do so.

questions.text: What should a driver do when reversing a vehicle with a trailer attached?

options.text: Keep the front of trailer in view at all times.
Turn the steering in the direction in which you wish to reverse.
Look all around and use rear-view mirrors when reversing.
Sound the horn as a warning.

questions.explanation: When reversing a vehicle with a trailer attached, make sure it is safe by checking all around and using the vehicle's mirrors. Reversing a vehicle with a trailer attached requires a lot of concentration, so watch out for other road users in the vicinity.

questions.text: What should a driver do in order to keep alert during a long journey?

options.text: Increase the air circulation and make regular stops if necessary.
Drink tea or coffee or other hot drinks.
Keep the radio turned on.
Increase your speed to shorten the journey.

questions.explanation: While on a long journey, you should take regular rest breaks. A short walk and a caffeinated drink (tea or coffee) can help to revive you. Keep the vehicle cool and well ventilated with a steady flow of fresh air.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Dual-carriageway ahead.
Traffic may not stop.
One-way street.
Two-way traffic ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a two-way traffic ahead, with oncoming traffic in the opposite lane.

questions.text: What would be the effect of a warm vehicle interior on somebody driving at night?

options.text: It could tempt the driver to drive at increased speed.
It could increase the driver's sense of alertness.
It could make the driver feel drowsy.
It could reassure the driver that the engine is operating at normal temperatures.

questions.explanation: If you are driving at night in a vehicle with a high interior temperature, you can become drowsy. Keep the interior of the vehicle cool and well ventilated, and take regular breaks.

questions.text: What effect would exhaust gases leaking into a vehicle have on the driver?

options.text: The driver maybe enticed to drive faster than normal.
The driver may become drowsy or ill.
The driver may become more alert.
The driver maybe enticed to drive slower than normal.

questions.explanation: Exhaust gases leaking into a vehicle can make the driver drowsy or ill, and this can lead to a serious collision. If you suspect that exhaust gases are leaking into the vehicle, you should have it checked by a qualified person.

questions.text: What in particular should a driver be aware of when driving a high-powered vehicle?

options.text: It could make the driver feel they are driving slower than they actually are.
It could make the driver feel the brakes appear more powerful than they actually are.
It could make the driver think that the car is bigger than it actually is.
It could make the driver think that they are driving faster than they are actually driving.

questions.explanation: When driving a smooth, high-powered vehicle, you may have the impression that you are travelling slower than you actually are. You should always know the speed at which you are driving, and adjust it as necessary to suit the road and traffic conditions.

questions.text: When should the handbrake be used to bring a vehicle to a halt?

options.text: Only when going downhill.
Never.
Only at speeds below 10 km/h.
Occasionaly .

questions.explanation: The handbrake should never be used to bring a vehicle to a halt. This practice is potentially dangerous, as the rear wheels could lock up and the vehicle could skid out of control. In addition, using the handbrake does not operate the rear brake lights to warn following traffic.

questions.text: What is the danger associated with applying the handbrake at speed?

options.text: The A.B.S. could disconnect.
The vehicle will not skid.
The back wheels could lock and cause the vehicle to skid.
The engine will stall.

questions.explanation: The handbrake should never be used when travelling at speed. This practice is potentially dangerous, as the rear wheels could lock up and the vehicle could skid out of control.

questions.text: When should rear fog lights be used?

options.text: Only in light fog.
When the vehicle behind is too close.
Always when driving at night.
In dense fog or falling snow.

questions.explanation: You should use your rear fog lights only in fog or falling snow. Using fog lights in normal road and weather conditions can dazzle or blind following motorists. Also, fog lights may make your brake lights harder to see.

questions.text: When should high-intensity rear fog lights be used?

options.text: At dusk and dawn.
When the tail-light is broken.
When driving in fog or falling snow.
Never.

questions.explanation: You should use your rear fog lights only in fog or falling snow. Using fog lights in normal road and weather conditions can dazzle or blind following motorists. Also. fog lights may make your brake lights harder to see.

questions.text: What should a driver do if the right-hand headlight bulb fails when driving at night?

options.text: Replace it temporarily with the brake-light bulb.
Have the bulb replaced immediately.
Drive with the right hand indicators on.
Replace it temporarily with the left-hand bulb.

questions.explanation: Motor vehicles (except motorcycles) are required by law to have two headlights. Faulty lights should be repaired immediately. A vehicle with only one headlight could mistaken for a motorcycle.

questions.text: What should a driver do if dazzled by headlights reflecting in the rear-view mirror of their car?

options.text: Switch your lights off and on to remind the following driver to dip his lights.
Use the night driving mode on the mirror.
Adjust your mirror to reflect the light back towards the following driver.
Turn on your rear fog lights to signal to the following driver to turn off his headlights.

questions.explanation: If the lights of following traffic are dazzling you. adjust your rear-view mirror to the night driving mode. This will allow you to concentrate on the road ahead and not be distracted by lights from following traffic.

questions.text: What should a driver do if dazzled by lights reflecting in their exterior mirror?

options.text: Switch on your rear lights.
Temporarily adjust the angle of the mirror.
Adjust the mirror to reflect the light back to the following driver.
Switch on a reversing light.

questions.explanation: If the lights of following traffic reflecting in your exterior mirror are dazzling you, temporarily adjust the angle of the mirror to relieve the glare and allow you to drive without distraction.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Motorway to the left.
Diversion ahead to the left.
Traffic from the right has priority.
Turn Left Only.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you that you must turn left, its usually displayed at a junction where all traffic must turn left - for example, in a one way system that incorporates a junction.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Uneven road surface to the right.
Sharp descent ahead.
Sharp climb ahead.
River or unprotected quay ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a steep downward slope ahead. You should react accordingly by adjusting speed and selecting the appropiate gear.

questions.text: At night, what effect could driving with a single headlight have on oncoming drivers?

options.text: It could dazzle them.
This will have no effect on oncoming drivers.
They could mistake the vehicle for a motorcycle.
It could enable them to see your vehicle more clearly.

questions.explanation: Motor vehicles (except motorcycles) are required by law to have two headlights. A vehicle with only one headlight could be mistaken for a motorcycle and other road users could believe that it is in a different position on the road than it actually is. You must repair faulty lighting immediately.

questions.text: In slippery conditions, should the driver of a tractor use the grass verge to improve road holding?

options.text: Only when towing heavy loads.
No, using the grass verge should be avoided.
Only when towing a trailer.
Only when not towing a trailer.

questions.explanation: You should not use the grass verge to gain traction on slippery roads. Hidden gulleys in the verge could cause you to lose control.

questions.text: Why should a tractor be driven more slowly on uneven road surfaces?

options.text: To ensure that fuel does not spill from the tank.
To avoid reduced tyre pressure.
To reduce noise.
To avoid severe bouncing.

questions.explanation: Driving a tractor at speed on an uneven road surface could cause the vehicle or the trailer to become unstable and difficult to control.

questions.text: Generally, what lighting must a car, tractor or works vehicle have when driving at night?

options.text: Headlights, brake-lights and indicators.
Headlights only.
Headlights and a reversing light.
Headlights, front and rear side lights, rear number plate light, red rear reflectors. brake lights and indicators.

questions.explanation: Cars, tractors and works vehicles are required by law to have headlights, front and rear side lights, rear number plate light, rear reflectors, brake lights and indicators.

questions.text: What lights must be shown on a parked car, tractor or works vehicle at night on an unlit public road?

options.text: Tail lights only.
At least one side lamp front and rear on the side nearest the centre of the road.
Dipped head lights.
At least one side-lamp front and rear on the side nearest the kerb.

questions.explanation: When leaving a vehicle on an unlit public road at night you should leave side/parking lights on, so that your vehicle can be seen by other road users.

questions.text: What danger could be associated with driving a tractor and trailer over a humpbacked bridge?

options.text: The tractor's suspension will smooth out the bump.
Tail-swing.
The trailer could become detached.
The trailer brakes might engage.

questions.explanation: When towing a trailer, make sure that the tow hitch always has sufficient ground clearance. If this hits the road, for example when travelling over a humpbacked bridge, there is a danger that the trailer will become detached.

questions.text: What should a driver do before entering a tunnel?

options.text: Drive close to the vehicle in front to reduce congestion.
Drive in a lower gear than normal to reduce exhaust pollution.
Check that the height of the vehicle is suitable for the tunnel.
Carry the minimum amount of fuel in case of fire.

questions.explanation: You should know height of your vehicle and the load you are carrying, and plan your route accordingly. Always read the road ahead and watch for warning signs about height restrictions. These may relate to tunnels. low bridges or car park entrances.

questions.text: What should a driver do before starting a journey on which they will encounter a tunnel?

options.text: Check the tunnel height before starting the journey.
Check the tachograph to find out height of the vehicle.
Carry extra fuel containers in the cab.
Disengage the global positioning system.

questions.explanation: You should know height of your vehicle and the load you are carrying, and plan your route accordingly. Always read the road ahead and watch for warning signs about height restrictions. These may relate to tunnels, low bridges or car park entrances.

questions.text: Where should L-plates be displayed on cars?

options.text: On the rear only.
Both front and rear.
On the driver's side only.
On the front only.

questions.explanation: The holder of a learner permit must display L-plates on the front and rear of their car at all times when driving on public roads.

questions.text: When must the holder of a Learner Permit display L-plates on their car?

options.text: While driving unaccompanied by a qualified driver.
At all times when driving.
During the term of the driver's first provisional licence only.
Only during weekdays.

questions.explanation: The holder of a learner permit must display L-plates on the front and rear of their car at all times when driving on public roads.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Sharp ascent ahead.
Uneven road surface to the left.
Only ascending traffic ahead.
Hump-backed bridge ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a steep upward slope ahead. You should react accordingly by adjusting speed and selecting the appropiate gear.

questions.text: How would a driver calculate the maximum permitted weight of their vehicle?

options.text: Refers to the unladen weight of the vehicle.
By adding the unladen weight of the vehicle to the load permitted to be carried.
Refers to the unladen weight of the vehicle plus the weight of the fuel.
Refers to the weight of the load which may be carried.

questions.explanation: The maximum permitted weight of a vehicle is the sum of the unladen weight of the vehicle and the maximum load that may be carried in it. It is an offence to overload a vehicle, as it reduces your ability to control it effectively.

questions.text: What is the maximum gross weight of a vehicle that may be driven by the holder of a category B driving licence?

options.text: 4,750 kilograms.
4,500 kilograms.
2,500 kilograms.
3,500 kilograms.

questions.explanation: The holder of a category B driving licence is not permitted to drive a vehicle with a design gross vehicle weight of more than 3,500kgs. This restriction is noted on the licence.

questions.text: What is the maximum number of passengers that may be carried in a vehicle driven by the holder of a category B driving licence?

options.text: 8 passengers.
9 passengers.
5 passengers.
7 passengers.

questions.explanation: The holder of a category B driving licence is not permitted to drive a vehicle that has seating for more than 8 passengers excluding the driver.

questions.text: When can the holder of a Category W Learner Permit carry a passenger?

options.text: Only when such person holds a category W driving licence.
Only when such person holds a category M driving licence and the vehicle is constructed or adapted to carry a passenger.
Only when the passenger also holds a Category W driving licence and the vehicle is designed to take a passenger.
Never.

questions.explanation: The holder of a category W learner permit may carry a passenger in the vehicle only it the vehicle is designed to take a passenger, and the passenger has held a full driving licence in category W for two or more years.

questions.text: A driver has stalled in the middle of an unguarded level crossing and cannot restart the engine. The warning bell is ringing. What should the driver do?

options.text: Walk clear of the crossing and phone the signal operator so that trains can be stopped.
Push the vehicle clear of the crossing.
Try to restart the engine in first gear.
Stay at vehicle and warn the approaching train.

questions.explanation: In this situation, you and all passengers should get out of the vehicle and immediately use the emergency phone at the crossing to contact the signal operator so that trains can be stopped. If necessary, warn other motorists. Do not return to the vehicle until instructed by the signal operator or emergency services.

questions.text: Why is it dangerous to allow children to stand in the space between the front seats of a car?

options.text: They could become ill.
The could be thrown backwards if the brakes are applied suddenly.
They could distract the driver thus drawing attention away from the road.
They could be thrown forward if the brakes are applied suddenly.

questions.explanation: When carrying children in a car or goods vehicle, it is the drivers responsibility to make sure that they are suitably restrained.

questions.text: When are children allowed to stand with their heads up through an open sun roof?

options.text: Children are never allowed to do so.
When travelling at speeds below 50 km/h.
When they are wearing eye protection.
When they are aged more than 12 years.

questions.explanation: When carrying children in a car or goods vehicle, it is the drivers responsibility to make sure that they are suitably restrained.

questions.text: Are children allowed to be left unattended in a vehicle?

options.text: Only when the vehicle is not parked on a hill.
Only when the vehicle is parked in a supervised car park.
Children should never be left unattended in a vehicle.
Only when there is adequate ventilation.

questions.explanation: Children must not be left unattended in a vehicle, even for a short period of time. Children might interfere with the vehicle's controls, and would not be able to deal with an emergency situation, such as a fire or electrical malfunction which could result in serious injury or death.

questions.text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down on an automatic railway level crossing?

options.text: Turn on the warning bells at the crossing.
Get passengers clear of the crossing and phone the signal operator so that trains can be stopped.
Walk along the track to give warning to any approaching trains.
Try to push the vehicle clear of the crossing as soon as possible.

questions.explanation: In this situation, you and all passengers should get out of the vehicle and immediately use the emergency phone at the crossing to contact the signal operator so that trains can be stopped. If necessary, warn other motorists. Do not return to the vehicle until instructed by the signal operator or emergency services

questions.text: When should children be allowed to drive a tractor?

options.text: When it is being driven at very slow speeds and without a front loader.
When it is off public road.
Children should never be allowed to drive a tractor.
When it is being driven at very slow speeds and not towing a trailer.

questions.explanation: Persons under 16 years of age are not permitted to drive a tractor in a public place.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Restricted weight limit for road segment indicated.
Restricted road width ahead.
Road narrows ahead, maximum length of vehicle is as indicated.
Restricted headroom up ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning that you are approaching an area of restricted headroom, such as a low bridge.

questions.text: What is the immediate effect of a head-on collision between two cars at speed?

options.text: All persons in each vehicle are thrown violently forward.
All persons in the vehicles are thrown violently backward.
Only back seat belts will activate.
Only from seat belts will activate.

questions.explanation: In a head-on collision passengers in both vehicles are propelled forwards, and if they are not wearing seatbelts they may go through the windscreen. It is the drivers responsibility to ensure that all passengers under the age of 17 wear seatbelts. Older passengers are themselves responsible for wearing seatbelts.

questions.text: What danger can arise from the power take-off shaft of a tractor?

options.text: If it is not disengaged, it can cause the battery to short-circuit.
If it is not covered, clothing can get caught in it.
If it is not disengaged, it can cause the steering wheel to lock.
If it is not disengaged, it can cause the tractor to increase speed rapidly.

questions.explanation: If you are working at the rear of a tractor, you should bear in mind that if the power take-off shaft is not covered, loose clothing might get caught in it and lead to injury or death.

questions.text: When changing a wheel on a public road, what should a person do to ensure their own safety?

options.text: Place a red warning triangle to the left of the vehicle.
Wear reflective clothing and switch on the vehicle hazard warning lights.
Secure the handbrake and place a chock or small wooden block at the rear of the wheels.
Put the car in neutral.

questions.explanation: When changing a wheel at the side of the road, switch on the vehicle hazard warning lights, and wear reflective or light-coloured clothing. This will help other motorists to react and slow down when passing.

questions.text: When is a red flag a sufficient marker for a rear load overhang that exceeds one metre?

options.text: When glass or fragile material is overhanging.
Only during the day.
At all times.
Only at night.

questions.explanation: During daylight hours, you must use a red flag to mark any load that is protruding more than one metre. At night, you must use a red light.

questions.text: How should a driver negotiate a bend when driving a fully loaded vehicle?

options.text: At a faster speed than when empty.
At the same speed as when empty.
By following a wide arc along the centre of the road.
At a slower speed than when empty.

questions.explanation: Driving too fast on the approach to a bend and while driving through it with a fully loaded vehicle can lead to a loss of control. This can be prevented by driving in a safe and sensible manner and by reading the road ahead.

questions.text: When is a driver allowed to carry more passengers in a car than there are seat belts available?

options.text: When the passengers do not interfere with your visibility.
When you are carrying children.
It is never allowed.
When you have appropriate insurance cover.

questions.explanation: A driver must make sure that each passenger in the vehicle has a seatbelt. Failure to wear a seatbelt is an offence. It is the drivers responsibility to ensure that passengers under the age of 17 wear seatbelts. Older passengers are themselves responsible for wearing seatbelts.

questions.text: What should a driver do when requested to drive a vehicle that they feel is overloaded?

options.text: Ensure that the load is properly covered.
Drive at a slower speed than you normally would.
Advise the person who asked you that you will not be held responsible if an accident occurs.
Refuse to drive the vehicle.

questions.explanation: You should not take a vehicle that you believe to be overloaded onto a public road. Overloading is dangerous, as it affects the stability and braking capabilities of the vehicle.

questions.text: How could towing an overloaded trailer affect a vehicle?

options.text: It can improve breaking ability when going downhill.
It could improve road holding on bends.
It could impair the vehicle's steering and braking.
It could improve the vehicle's fuel consumption.

questions.explanation: You should not take an overloaded trailer onto a public road. An overloaded trailer impairs the stability, steering and braking of the towing vehicle.

questions.text: At what point is a vehicle load more likely to shift?

options.text: When driving on a motorway.
When cornering.
When taking off.
When parking.

questions.explanation: It is the drivers responsibility to ensure that the load is properly secured and evenly distributed. so that the vehicle can be properly controlled when changing direction and when braking.

questions.text: When attaching a trailer to their vehicle, what should a driver check?

options.text: That the load is positioned to the front of the trailer and the trailer pin is tightly secured.
That the trailer has a spare wheel.
That the load is evenly spread.
That the trailer springs are well greased.

questions.explanation: Proper weight distribution helps to ensure the stability of both the towing vehicle and the trailer. In the trailer, the bulk of the load should be over the axles. If a heavy load is positioned at the front of the trailer, this will result in too much 'nose weight' on the hitch of the towing vehicle and make it difficult to steer. If a heavy load is positioned at the rear of the trailer, this will result in reduced weight on the rear axle of the towing vehicle, which will make it more unstable.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Radio transmission mast ahead.
Sharp corners ahead.
Overhead electric cables.
Crosswinds ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of electric cables overhead. Drivers with a high load should be particularly careful.

questions.text: When attaching a trailer to their vehicle, what should a driver check?

options.text: That the load is positioned to the front of the trailer and that the trailer pen is tightly secured.
That the trailer springs are well greased.
That the trailer coupling is attached securely.
That the trailer has a spare wheel.

questions.explanation: Before towing a trailer or a caravan, check that the towbar is securely attached to the towing vehicle, that the trailer coupling is properly attached to the towbar and locked in place, and that the breakaway cable is properly connected.

questions.text: What should a driver do to secure the towing vehicle before unhitching a trailer?

options.text: Apply the handbrake, lower the jockey wheel and switch off the engine.
Lower the jockey wheel and then switch off the ignition.
Disconnect the electrical supply to the trailer lights and lower the jockey wheel.
Apply the handbrake. switch off the ignition and engage a low gear.

questions.explanation: Before unhitching a trailer, apply the handbrake, switch off the ignition and engage a lower gear, so that the towing vehicle does not move while you are unhitching the trailer.

questions.text: When is it permissible for a driver to carry a passenger on a trailer drawbar?

options.text: When the person has a category B driving licence.
When towing a trailer off-road.
Never.
When towing a trailer off-road and the person has a category B driving licence.

questions.explanation: You must never carry a passenger on a trailer drawbar because of the danger of the passenger falling between the vehicle and the trailer and being seriously injured or killed.

questions.text: When is a tractor most likely to overturn?

options.text: When speeding uphill.
When turning sharply.
When speeding on the flat.
When speeding downhill.

questions.explanation: Tractors are less stable than other vehicles as they have no suspension and the extra height and uneven positioning of the wheel adds to the instability. When you are driving a tractor, you should take these factors into account and take extra care when maneuvering.

questions.text: When driving a tractor and trailer, what should the driver do on entering a roundabout to avoid possible roll-over?

options.text: Increase speed.
Reduce speed.
Engage the parking brake.
Drive in a high gear.

questions.explanation: When you are driving a tractor with a trailer, you need to take extra care because of the vehicle's instability. Always drive at a safe speed, in particular when changing direction, such as on a roundabout.

questions.text: What is jack-knifing?

options.text: When the jack is not strong enough to lift an axle.
When the trailer is too heavy to be drawing by the vehicle.
When the trailer is travelling faster than the drawing vehicle.
When the vehicle slides due to ice or water on the road.

questions.explanation: Towing a trailer or caravan dramatically reduces the stability of the towing vehicle. If a driver brakes sharply or slows down quickly, the trailer may pivot around the tow hitch coupling, causing both vehicles to go off course, and possibly overturn.

questions.text: When is jack-knifing most likely to occur?

options.text: When trying to reduce speed sharply while travelling downhill.
When the trailer springs are over greased.
When travelling uphill.
When travelling sideways across a slope.

questions.explanation: Towing a trailer or caravan dramatically reduces the stability of the towing vehicle If a driver brakes sharply or slows down quickly, the trailer may pivot around the tow hitch coupling, causing both vehicles to go off course, and possibly overturn.

questions.text: The driver of a tractor pulling a wide load that blocks their view to the rear wishes to turn right. What should they do?

options.text: Dismount and check for following traffic before turning.
Have another person advise of following traffic while the driver checks for oncoming traffic.
Complete the turn if there is no traffic coming towards you.
Have a person stop following traffic while you complete the turn.

questions.explanation: If you are driving a vehicle with a wide load that blocks your view of the road to the rear, and you need to turn right, you should get someone else to look out to the rear and advise you when it is safe to make the turn.

questions.text: When should a driver use the vehicle side lights?

options.text: Driving in fog.
Driving at more than 50 km/h.
Driving in an unlit area at night.
When parking on an unlit road.

questions.explanation: You should use the side lights of your vehicle when parking on an unlit road at night. so that the vehicle can be easily seen by other road users.

questions.text: How does a driver know if the bulb in a side light has failed?

options.text: A warning buzzer sounds when the sidelights are switched on.
None of the lights operate when switched on.
By checking the side lights when they are switched on.
By checking the sidelights when reversing the vehicle.

questions.explanation: You must ensure that the lights in your vehicle are working properly before driving on the road. Check all the vehicle lights regularly by switching them on and Getting Out of a Vehicle to see if they are working, or by getting someone else to check

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Level crossing ahead unguarded by gates or barriers.
Major roadworks ahead.
Machinery crossing ahead.
End of major roadworks.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of an unguarded level crossing ahead. This is a crossing without gates or barriers and you should cross it with extreme caution.

questions.text: On a motorway, when should a driver use the hazard warning lights?

options.text: A vehicle is following too closely.
Driving on the hard shoulder.
When slowing down quickly because of danger ahead.
You are towing another vehicle.

questions.explanation: Use hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, you can use the hazards warning lights to warn following vehicles of your presence in these situations: 1. If you have to slow sharply - for example, because of a buil

questions.text: What effect do the hazard warning lights have on the brake lights?

options.text: It causes them to flash repeatedly.
They have no effect.
It causes the left and right brake-lights to flash alternately.
They will shine brighter.

questions.explanation: Use hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, you can use the hazards warning lights to warn following vehicles of your presence in these situations: 1. If you have to slow sharply - for example, because of a buil

questions.text: On a motorway, when should a driver use the hazard warning lights?

options.text: When the vehicle has broken down.
When the brake-lights are not working.
When parking for a short period on a single yellow line.
When about to pull in and stop.

questions.explanation: Use hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, you can use the hazards warning lights to warn following vehicles of your presence in these situations: 1. If you have to slow sharply - for example, because of a buil

questions.text: What does using the vehicle’s hazard warning lights allow a driver to do?

options.text: To warn other road users when parking on double yellow lines.
To warn other road users when parking on the brow of a hill.
To warn other road users when making a delivery.
To warn other road users that the vehicle is broken down.

questions.explanation: Use hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, you can use the hazards warning lights to warn following vehicles of your presence in these situations: 1. If you have to slow sharply - for example, because of a buil

questions.text: When should a driver use their vehicle’s hazard warning lights?

options.text: When the driver is double-parking.
When the brake-lights are not working.
When the vehicle has broken down.
To show your irritation at other drivers.

questions.explanation: Use hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, you can use the hazards warning lights to warn following vehicles of your presence in these situations: 1. If you have to slow sharply - for example, because of a buil

questions.text: When should a driver use their vehicle’s hazard warning lights?

options.text: When reversing into a narrow road.
When parked at a bend or corner.
When causing an unavoidable obstruction.
When moving slowly.

questions.explanation: Use hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, you can use the hazards warning lights to warn following vehicles of your presence in these situations: 1. If you have to slow sharply - for example, because of a buil

questions.text: What lighting should be on a car-trailer?

options.text: Indicators, brake lights. rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights.
Indicators and rear number plate light only.
Brake-lights and indicators only.
Reversing light.

questions.explanation: All vehicles, including trailers, must have rear indicators, brake lights, a rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights.

questions.text: What lighting should be on a tractor-trailer during lighting-up hours?

options.text: An unloading light.
Indicators, brake lights, rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights.
Indicators and rear number plate light only.
Brake-lights and indicators only.

questions.explanation: All vehicles, including trailers, must have rear indicators, brake lights, a rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights.

questions.text: What does this warning light indicate?

options.text: Low level of water coolant.
Low oil pressure.
A fault in the braking system.
Defective indicator bulb.

questions.explanation: If the brake warning light is on. there is a problem with the braking system in the vehicle or the handbrake is on. You should not drive the vehicle until the problem has been rectified.

questions.text: The handbrake generally works on which wheels?

options.text: The rear right-hand wheel.
All the wheels.
The front wheels.
The rear wheels.

questions.explanation: The function of the handbrake (or 'parking brake') is to stop the vehicle from moving when it is parked or when it is stopped on a hill. You normally use the handbrake when the vehicle is already stationary — you don't use it to stop the vehicle. In

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Road fencing ahead.
Farm machinery crossing ahead.
Private grounds - no entry.
Level crossing ahead guarded by gates or barriers.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a railway crossing ahead that is protected by gates or lifting barriers. You should be prepared to stop and follow the required procedure.

questions.text: In general, above what gross vehicle weight must a trailer have brakes fitted?
questions.explanation: Brakes must be fitted to a trailer if its gross vehicle weight exceeding 750kg or half the weight of the towing vehicle.

questions.text: What is the recommended method of driving a vehicle with automatic transmission?

options.text: Use the handbrake to bring the vehicle to a halt.
Operate the accelerator and brake with the left foot.
Operate the accelerator and brake with the right foot.
Operate the accelerator with the right foot and the brake with the left foot.

questions.explanation: When driving an automatic vehicle, you should use the right foot to operate both the accelerator and the brake, just as in vehicles with a manual gear box.

questions.text: When driving a vehicle with a diesel engine in freezing weather, what should a driver ensure?

options.text: That the driver uses a diesel with a high sulphur content.
That the fuel level in the tank does not drop below quarter full.
That the fuel filter is drained.
That the fuel is treated with an anti-waxing agent.

questions.explanation: Road diesel is supplied with an anti-waxing agent added to it. This generally prevents the fuel from freezing at temperatures as low as -15°C.

questions.text: What is a possible effect of over-filling the engine with oil?

options.text: It could burst the oil filter.
It could damage the catalytic converter.
It could reduce oil pressure.
It could damage the oil pump.

questions.explanation: Catalytic converters are part of most vehicles' exhaust system. They remove up to 75% of the carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxide and hydrocarbons from the vehicles' exhaust. Catalytic converters can be permanently damaged if. for example, the car is fill

questions.text: What should a driver do if the fuel system becomes air-locked?

options.text: Tighten the injector pipes.
Increase the air pressure.
Bleed the air out of the fuel system.
Drain the fuel filter.

questions.explanation: The fuel system can become air-locked if you let the fuel get too low or if there is a leak in the system. You should have the problem corrected before driving. The solution may be as simple as bleeding the fuel system to release the air.

questions.text: Is a driver allowed to use rebated (green) diesel fuel in a car on a public road?

options.text: Green diesel may never be used in a car.
Green diesel may be used in a car only if the car is a taxi.
Green diesel may be used in a car only in winter months.
Green diesel may be used in a car only in summer months.

questions.explanation: If, in its normal use, a vehicle is used on a public road, it must use unmarked (white) diesel, as the appropriate excise duties are included in the purchase price. You can be prosecuted for using green diesel in a vehicle on a public road.

questions.text: What should a driver do to reduce the risk of neck injury in a rear-end collision?

options.text: If airbags are not fitted, use a properly adjusted head restraint.
Use a properly adjusted head restraint.
Ensure the vehicle has anti-lock brakes.
Ensure the vehicle has a rear spoiler.

questions.explanation: Head restraints are designed to protect the neck and spine in a collision and thus prevent or reduce whiplash. They should be properly adjusted for both the driver and the passengers.

questions.text: When must a tractor or works vehicle be fitted with a rear-view mirror?

options.text: A rear-view mirror must always be fitted.
Only when towing a trailer over eight meters long.
Only when towing a trailer.
It is not required.

questions.explanation: All vehicles used on a public road must have a rear-view mirror to enable the driver to see road and traffic conditions behind and to each side.

questions.text: What is the minimum legal tread depth for tyres on cars?

options.text: 0.8 millimeters.
1.6 millimeters.
1 millimeters.
1.8 millimeters.

questions.explanation: All road vehicles, except motorcycles and vintage vehicles, must have a minimum tyre tread depth of 1.6mm over the main tread. However, for safety reasons, you should replace the vehicle's tyres before they become this worn.

questions.text: What does the load index of a tyre indicate?

options.text: The maximum air pressure of the tyre.
The maximum load a tyre can carry.
The maximum load of the vehicle.
The maximum load per axle.

questions.explanation: The load index indicates the maximum weight that a tyre can support safely. When replacing a tyre on your vehicle, you should make sure that the new tyre maintains the proper load index for the vehicle.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Do not stop on railway crossing.
Railway bridge ahead.
Railway station ahead.
Level crossing ahead with lights and barriers.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a railway level crossing ahead with lights and barriers. You should be prepared to stop.

questions.text: Under what circumstances could both cross-ply and radial tyres be fitted to a vehicle?

options.text: When towing a trailer in snow.
In icy or slippery road conditions.
When each type is fitted on a different axle.
When heavy loads are being carried.

questions.explanation: In general, you should fit the same type of tyres all round the vehicle. However if you need to fit a mix of cross-ply and radials. the tyres on any axle should be of the same type.

questions.text: What is the effect of resting the foot on the clutch pedal?

options.text: It allows corners to be taken without reducing speed.
It facilitates quicker gear changes.
It allows downhill speeds to be controlled more effectively.
It wears out the clutch more quickly than normal.

questions.explanation: The clutch is the connection between the engine and the gearbox. It enables the vehicle to move when a gear is engaged. When driving, you should not rest your foot on the clutch pedal, because it might disengage the selected gear and/or damage the cl

questions.text: When the fluid reservoir is full to the mark, how would a driver check that the power-assisted steering is working effectively?

options.text: Turn the steering with the brake-pedal fully pressed.
Turn the steering from lock to lock with the engine switched off.
Turn the steering with the brake-pedal lightly pressed.
Turn the steering wheel from lock to lock with the engine running.

questions.explanation: Before starting a journey, check that the PAS (power-assisted steering) is working by starting the engine and turning the steering wheel from full left lock to full right lock to see that it operates smoothly and effectively.

questions.text: What should the driver of a vehicle with power-assisted steering (PAS) do if steering becomes more difficult as they are driving?

options.text: Drive in a higher gear with reduced engine revs.
Drive in a lower gear with increased engine revs.
Increase the front tyre pressure.
Stop. check the level of the fluid and top up if necessary.

questions.explanation: Most modern vehicles have power-assisted steering (PAS). PAS requires less effort and feels lighter, especially when carrying out manoeuvres such as parking. U-turns and reversing. You should be aware that it is easy to oversteer with PAS.

questions.text: What is the effect of an incorrectly adjusted driver’s seat?

options.text: Offers the driver a better view in the rear-view mirror.
It can delay the driver from operating a control.
It can enable the driver to relax more on a long journey.
It can improve the drivers vision.

questions.explanation: Before starting a journey, you should adopt a suitable and comfortable driving position by adjusting the drivers seat to a position where all the vehicle controls can be operated efficiently.

questions.text: While driving in rain, a driver notices that the wiper blades are worn. What should they do?

options.text: Roll down the window and drive slowly.
Stop and wipe the windscreen with newspaper.
Use the windscreen washer system all the time while it rains.
Have the blades replaced as soon as possible.

questions.explanation: Use the windscreen wipers to keep the windscreen clear of rain, spray, snow or fog. Check them regularly to ensure that they are in good working order, and replace them when they become worn, before they become ineffective.

questions.text: If the wiper blades are frozen to the windscreen, what should the driver do?

options.text: Roll down the window and drive slowly with your head out the window.
Switch the wipers to high speed to free them.
Defrost the windscreen before switching on the wipers.
Pull the wipers free before switching them on.

questions.explanation: Before starting a journey in icy weather, make sure that the windows are clear. Use the demister to clear the windows and defrost the wipers so that they can be used to clear the windscreen.

questions.text: What problem is indicated when wipers suddenly cease to function?

options.text: A fuse has blown.
The windscreen washer reservoir is dry.
The wiper blades need to be replaced.
The alternator is faulty.

questions.explanation: Check the vehicle's windscreen wipers regularly to ensure the blades are in good condition, and check that there is water in the washer bottle. If the wipers stop working suddenly, the most likely cause is a blown fuse.

questions.text: What should a driver add to windscreen washer fluid in freezing weather?

options.text: Have hot water added.
Be diluted with methylated spirits.
An extra detergent for windows.
A mild anti-freezing agent for windows.

questions.explanation: In cold weather, use an anti-freezing agent in the windscreen washer fluid, so that the windscreen can be cleared if required.

questions.text: What should a driver do when the wiper blade on the driver’s side is partly worn?

options.text: Switch the driver and passenger wiper blades.
Repair it with sticky tape.
Have the worn blade replaced with a new one.
Stop driving during wet weather.

questions.explanation: Use the windscreen wipers to keep the windscreen clear of rain, spray, snow or fog. Check them regularly to ensure that they are in good working order, and replace them when they become worn, before they become ineffective.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Emerging vehicles have priority. You must stop if necessary.
The driver must stop when red lights show.
Stop, and wait for green light before proceeding.
You must stop when you see brake-lights ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning that you must stop when red lights show. This sign may be displayed at railway level crossing.

questions.text: Why is a windscreen laminated?

options.text: Blocks the harmful rays coming from the sun.
Shatters into large fragments when struck by an object.
Is glass which has the registration number of the vehicle etched on to it.
So as not to shatter into large fragments when struck by an object.

questions.explanation: A laminated windscreen (a plastic film sandwiched between two layers of glass) is designed not to break into large fragments when struck by an object. This is to prevent serious injury to the driver and passengers.

questions.text: When changing a wheel on their vehicle on a public road, what should a person do?

options.text: Turn on the hazard warning lights.
Ask a passenger to stand on the road to warn other traffic.
Place a red warning triangle to the left side at the rear of the vehicle.
Turn on the full beam headlights.

questions.explanation: When changing a wheel on a public road. make yourself as visible as possible Wear high-visibility outer clothing. turn on the hazard warning lights. and place a red warning triangle to the rear of the vehicle on the right-hand side.

questions.text: When changing a wheel on their vehicle on a public road what should a person do?

options.text: Turn on the full beam headlights.
Place a red warning triangle to the right side at the rear of the vehicle.
Place a red warning triangle to the left side at the rear of the vehicle.
Ask a passenger to stand on the road to warn other traffic.

questions.explanation: When changing a wheel on a public road, make yourself as visible as possible. Wear high-visibility outer clothing, turn on the hazard warning lights, and place a red warning triangle to the rear of the vehicle on the right-hand side.

questions.text: When changing a wheel on their vehicle on a public road what should a person do?

options.text: Turn on the full beam headlights.
Ask a passenger to stand on the road to warn other traffic.
Wear reflective clothing if available.
Place a red warning triangle to the left side at the rear of the vehicle.

questions.explanation: When changing a wheel on a public road, make yourself as visible as possible Wear high-visibility outer clothing, turn on the hazard warning lights. and place a red warning triangle to the rear of the vehicle on the right-hand side.

questions.text: What should a driver do in order to avoid excessive exhaust pollution from their vehicle?

options.text: Use a fuel additive to increase the fuel octane rating.
Drive at a higher speed in order to reduce the time spent on the road.
Have the vehicle's air filters changed regularly.
Use a lower octane rated fuel.

questions.explanation: You should have your vehicle serviced regularly in accordance with the manufacturers guidelines. A vehicle that is poorly tuned uses more fuel and creates more exhaust pollution. Air filters should be changed as part of normal servicing. If a vehicle is used in dusty conditions, the air filter may need to be changed more often. More information is available in the vehicle's handbook.

questions.text: How regularly should a vehicle be serviced?

options.text: Every year.
Every 30,000 kilometers.
As often as indicated in the manufacturer's specification.
Every 60 months.

questions.explanation: You should have your vehicle serviced regularly in accordance with the manufacturer's guidelines. This helps the vehicle to perform properly, thus saving fuel and reducing emissions. You should also carry out your own daily and weekly checks on fluid levels and tyres.

questions.text: What is the purpose of a catalytic converter?

options.text: To curb exhaust noise levels only on diesel vehicles.
To reduce harmful exhaust emissions.
To allow the exhaust system to be reconditioned.
To curb exhaust noise levels.

questions.explanation: Catalytic converters are part of most vehicles' exhaust system. They remove up to 75% of the carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxide and hydrocarbons from the vehicles' exhaust.

questions.text: What type of noise might fast cornering create?

options.text: Engine whine.
Brake squeal.
Exhaust backfire.
Tyre squeal.

questions.explanation: If you drive around a corner too fast, the tyres begin to lose contact with the surface of the road, and this causes a squealing sound. If you continue driving in this way, you can lose control of the vehicle.

questions.text: What should a driver do before getting out of the vehicle?

options.text: Open the door part way and then look behind.
Check their side mirror and look behind before opening the door.
Check the interior mirror before opening the door.
Open the door and exit the vehicle without delay.

questions.explanation: Before opening any door, check for other road users passing, and in particular look out for pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists. Exit the vehicle only when it is safe to do so, and close the door as soon as possible. Passengers should exit on the side nearest the kerb wherever possible.

questions.text: How should a driver secure their vehicle before getting out of it?

options.text: Angle the wheels away from the kerb and stop the engine.
Engage a low gear and stop the engine.
Angle the wheels towards the kerb and stop the engine.
Apply the parking brake, stop the engine and engage a low gear.

questions.explanation: Before leaving your vehicle, apply the handbrake, switch off the engine and engage low engage a low gear. If the vehicles if fitted with automatic transmission, select 'P' (park).

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Automatic level crossing ahead.
Bridge may be raised ahead.
Pelican crossing ahead.
Traffic lights may be activated by passing traffic.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of an automatic level crossing ahead. Prepare to stop.

questions.text: What precaution should a driver take when getting out of their vehicle?

options.text: Ensure the gear lever is in neutral.
Ensure all valuables are secure and out of sight.
Open the door and try to get out as speedily as possible.
Check all around for approaching traffic and pedestrians before opening the door.

questions.explanation: Before opening any door, check for other road users passing, and in particular look out for pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists. Exit the vehicle only when it is safe to do so, and close the door as soon as possible. Passengers should exit on the side nearest  the kerb wherever possible.

questions.text: On a busy road, how should a driver allow passengers out of a vehicle?

options.text: Stop and allow them to get out on the side nearest the kerb.
Stop and allow them to get out from whichever side of the vehicle they are sitting.
Stop and ask them to get out as quickly as possible.
Signal to following traffic to overtake before allowing the passengers to get out.

questions.explanation: Before allowing any door to be opened, check for other road users passing, and in particular look out for pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists. Passengers should exit on the side nearest the kerb, without getting in the way of pedestrians.

questions.text: What cars are required to have rear seat belts fitted?

options.text: Cars first registered prior to 1st January 1992.
All cars.
Cars first registered after 1st January 1992.
Cars first registered prior to 1st January 1995.

questions.explanation: Rear seat belts are compulsory on all cars registered after 1st January 1992.

questions.text: Where seat belts are fitted to a car when must adult occupants wear them?

options.text: For all journeys exceeding 10 kilometers.
On long journeys only.
At all times.
Except in built-up areas.

questions.explanation: The driver and all passengers in a car must wear a seatbelt or, in the case of a child, a suitable restraint system.

questions.text: What is the purpose of a seatbelt?

options.text: To prevent the wearer from being thrown backwards in the event of an crash.
To keep the seat upright in the event of an crash.
To prevent the wearer from being thrown forward in the event of a crash or abrupt deceleration.
To prevent the seat from moving forward when the brakes are applied.

questions.explanation: Seatbelts save lives and reduce the risk of injury by restraining the occupants of a vehicle in the event of a crash or sudden deceleration.

questions.text: When should a driver put on their safety belt?

options.text: Not later than the time they engage top gear.
When driving outside an urban area.
Once their speed has exceeded 50 km/h.
Before they move off.

questions.explanation: Before moving off, put on your seatbelt and make sure that all your passengers also have theirs on.

questions.text: Who is responsible for ensuring that a passenger over 17 years of age is wearing a seat belt while travelling in a car?

options.text: The driver when the passenger is in the front seat.
The passengers only.
The driver only.
Both the driver and the passengers.

questions.explanation: If the passenger is over the age of 17. it is their responsibility to comply with the seat belt regulations. Below that age, it is the drivers responsibility.

questions.text: Who is responsible for ensuring that a passenger under 17 years of age is wearing a seat belt while travelling in a car?

options.text: The passengers' parents.
The passengers themselves.
The driver.
The driver, when the passenger is in the front seat.

questions.explanation: If the passenger is over the age of 17, it is their responsibility to comply with the seat belt regulations. Below that age, it is the drivers responsibility.

questions.text: In general, how should infants be secured in a vehicle?

options.text: They should always be secured in a child restraint system.
They should always be placed in the front passenger seat.
They should always be placed in the front passenger seat wearing a seat-belt.
They should always be carried on an adults lap.

questions.explanation: As safety belts are designed mainly for adults and older children, infants and small children must be restrained in an appropriate child restraint system.

questions.text: Should an infant who is not secured in a child restraint system be carried in the front passenger seat?

options.text: Yes.
No, an infant must always be restrained in a correct child seat.
Yes, only if the vehicle is fitted with airbags.
Yes if held by an adult.

questions.explanation: Infants and small children must be restrained in an appropriate child restraint system.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Series of bumps or hollows ahead.
Road falls from center to left and right.
Road reflective studs ahead.
Sharp rise in the road ahead - for example, a hump-back bridge.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a hump in the road. You should adjust your speed accordingly.

questions.text: How should a child restraint system be secured in a vehicle?

options.text: It should be placed on a normal passenger seat.
It should be placed on the floor.
It should be secured with seat belts or ISOFIX fittings.
It should be left unsecured.

questions.explanation: A child restraint system should be secured in the vehicle either with the seatbelts of the car or with approved fixings. Always use a restraint system that is appropriate for the age, height and weight of the child, and follow the manufacturers instr

questions.text: What should a driver do when driving a vehicle with young children as passengers?

options.text: Make certain that an older passenger is sitting next to them.
Make sure each child is wearing a seat belt or using an appropriate restraint system.
Check in your rear-view mirror to ensure the children seated in the back seat are safe.
Make sure the eldest children are seated in the back seat.

questions.explanation: If the passenger is over the age of 17. it is their responsibility to comply with the seatbelt regulations. Below that age. it is the drivers responsibility.

questions.text: What is the purpose of side-impact protection bars?

options.text: To protect the doors from becoming damaged in the event of a crash.
To make sure that the vehicle cannot be overturned when hit from the side.
To increase the weight of the vehicle thereby improving its grip on the road.
To protect the occupants when the vehicle is hit from the side.

questions.explanation: Side-impact protection bars are fitted to some vehicles to protect the occupants of the vehicle in the event of a collision from the side.

questions.text: What should a driver do if a tyre bursts on the vehicle they are driving?

options.text: Hold the steering wheel firmly and pull in on the side of the road.
Pull on the handbrake.
Brake as quickly as possible.
Continue on at a normal speed.

questions.explanation: If a tyre bursts on your vehicle, keep a firm hold of the steering, slow down gradually and stop where it is safe to do so. Switch on the hazard warning lights.

questions.text: How should a driver use the brakes if the vehicle is fitted with anti-lock brakes (ABS)?

options.text: Press the brake-pedal only lightly.
Press and release the brake at slow intervals.
Press and release the brake at rapid intervals.
Press the brake pedal firmly and hold.

questions.explanation: If your vehicle is fitted with ABS. brake firmly. ABS will not stop the vehicle more quickly, it will only prevent the wheels from locking. This helps you to maintain control of the vehicle.

questions.text: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets into a front-wheel sideways skid?

options.text: Release the accelerator.
Press the footbrake.
Continue to accelerate.
Apply the handbrake.

questions.explanation: If your vehicle goes into a front-wheel sideways skid, release the accelerator and do not try to steer until the tyres regain some grip on the road.

questions.text: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets into a four-wheel sideways skid?

options.text: Push in the clutch and apply the handbrake to bring the car to a halt.
Turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the skid and ease off the accelerator.
Apply the footbrake strongly.
Turn the steering wheel in the same direction and apply the handbrake to bring the car to a halt.

questions.explanation: If your vehicle goes into a four-wheel skid, turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the skid and ease off the accelerator. This should help to bring the wheels back into line and allow you to regain control.

questions.text: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets into a rear-wheel sideways skid?

options.text: Apply the footbrake strongly to bring the car to a halt.
Turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the rear wheels are heading.
Turn the steering wheel in the opposite direction in which the front wheels are heading.
Turn the steering wheel in the same direction in which the front wheels are heading.

questions.explanation: If your vehicle goes into a rear-wheel sideways skid, turn the steering in the direction the rear wheels are heading. This should be done very gradually, as too much steering could cause the vehicle to skid in the opposite direction.

questions.text: How should a driver in a vehicle without anti-lock brakes (ABS) deal with a front-wheel straight-line skid?

options.text: Turn the steering gently left or right.
