Push in the clutch and take your foot off the accelerator.
Apply the footbrake strongly.
Press and release the footbrake at rapid intervals.

questions.explanation: If your vehicle does not have ABS and it goes into a straight-line front-wheel skid due to braking. press and release the brake pedal repeatedly and rapidly. This will help to restore tyre grip and enable you to regain control.

questions.text: What should a driver do if they get a tyre blow-out on the road?

options.text: Switch off the engine ignition to help bring the vehicle to a halt.
Apply the handbrake immediately to help bring the vehicle to a halt.
Apply the footbrake gently and bring the vehicle to a halt.
Apply the footbrake firmly.

questions.explanation: If a tyre on the vehicle you are driving blows out, slow down gradually and find a safe and suitable place to stop. Switch on your hazard warning lights and change the wheel or call for assistance.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Overtake only on the right
Diversion ahead to the right.
Turn right only.
Major road joining from the left.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you that you must turn right, its usually displayed at a junction where all traffic must turn right - for example, in a one way system that incorporates a junction.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Road divides ahead - pass left or right.
Road damage ahead.
Low bridge ahead.
Sharp depression or dip ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a dip or depression in the road ahead. You should reduce your speed accordingly.

questions.text: What effect could a front-tyre blow-out have on a vehicle?

options.text: The vehicle to pull to the rear away from the front blow-out.
The steering wheel will pull to one side.
The wheels to lock.
The vehicle will become easier to control.

questions.explanation: If a front tyre on the vehicle you are driving blows out, you will feel the effect of it through the steering wheel. The wheel will generally pull to the side of the blown-out tyre.

questions.text: What effect could a rear-tyre blow-out have on a vehicle?

options.text: It could cause the vehicle wheels to lock.
It could cause the vehicle to sway from side to side.
It could cause the vehicle to pull towards the side with the blow-out.
It could cause the vehicle to pull away from the side with the blow-out.

questions.explanation: If a rear tyre on the vehicle you are driving blows out the vehicle may sway from side to side, and this will affect its stability. Slow down, pull in where it is safe to do so. and switch on the hazard warning lights. Change the wheel or call for assistance.

questions.text: What action should a driver take if the engine in their vehicle cuts out suddenly when they are driving along?

options.text: Check that the handbrake is fully off.
Signal and steer the car to the side of the road.
Engage a lower gear.
Depress the accelerator and then release it.

questions.explanation: If the engine in the vehicle you are driving cuts out signal and steer to the side of the road. Switch on the hazard warning lights and contact the relevant breakdown service to get assistance.

questions.text: How would hydraulic power steering be affected if an engine stalled in slow-moving traffic?

options.text: The steering becomes easier to operate.
The steering would become heavy and difficult to operate.
The vehicle would not move.
The vehicle would move faster.

questions.explanation: Hydraulic power steering is operated by a pump which is driven by the engine. If the engine stalls, the pump stops working, and the steering becomes heavy and requires much more effort to turn.

questions.text: What should a driver do if the accelerator jams when they are driving along?

options.text: Engage a low gear and depress the clutch.
Leave the vehicle in gear and apply the brakes.
Try and flick the accelerator and the brakes with your foot.
Engage a neutral gear and apply the brakes.

questions.explanation: If the accelerator on the vehicle you are driving jams, select neutral and use the brakes to bring the vehicle to a safe halt. Switch off the engine as soon as the vehicle has stopped. Get the vehicle checked out before attempting to drive again.

questions.text: When driving on the road, what should a driver do if the brakes on their vehicle fail?

options.text: Check that the handbrake if fully off.
Engage neutral gear.
Engage a lower gear.
Engage a higher gear.

questions.explanation: If the brakes on the vehicle you are driving fade or fail, select a lower gear to slow the vehicle down and move to the left to come to a halt. You can also try to regain some braking by pumping the footbrake. This may help you the vehicle to a safe

questions.text: When driving on the road, what should a driver do if the brakes on their vehicle fail?

options.text: Press the footbrake firmly then release it.
Pump the brake pedal rapidly.
Signal to following traffic to overtake you.
Use a hand signal to following traffic that you intend to slow down or stop.

questions.explanation: If the brakes on the vehicle you are driving fade or fail, select a lower gear to slow the vehicle down and move to the left to come to a halt. You can also try to regain some braking by pumping the footbrake. This may help you the vehicle to a safe

questions.text: When driving along, a driver feels that the oncoming car may crash into their vehicle. What should they do?

options.text: Apply the footbrake gently to bring the vehicle to a halt.
Flash the headlights and sound the horn to attract the attention of the other driver.
Apply the handbrake immediately to help bring the car to a halt.
Switch off the engine ignition to help bring the vehicle to a halt.

questions.explanation: If there is an oncoming vehicle in your path, flash your lights and sound your horn to alert the other driver. Bring your vehicle to a halt immediately.

questions.text: When driving along and confronted by an obstacle, what should a driver do?

options.text: Apply the footbrake and switch off the ignition.
Apply the handbrake and the footbrake together.
Switch off the ignition.
Apply the footbrake firmly.

questions.explanation: To stop your vehicle in an emergency. apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping. Vehicles are fitted with braking systems to stop the vehicle.

questions.text: When driving along and required to stop suddenly, what should a driver do?

options.text: Steer sharply to one side and apply the handbrake.
Depress the clutch and apply the footbrake.
Apply the footbrake firmly.
Apply the handbrake and footbrake.

questions.explanation: To stop your vehicle in an emergency. apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping. Vehicles are fitted with braking systems to stop the vehicle.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Series of bumps or hollows ahead.
Rumble strips ahead.
Industrial estate ahead.
Steep hills ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a series of bumps or hollows ahead. You should reduce your speed accordingly.

questions.text: When required to stop in an emergency, what should a driver do?

options.text: Press and release the footbrake.
Maintain firm pressure on the footbrake.
Maintain a frim grip on the steering and depress both the clutch and footbrake.
Flash the headlights and the brake-lights.

questions.explanation: To stop your vehicle in an emergency. apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping. Vehicles are fitted with braking systems to stop the vehicle.

questions.text: When required to stop in an emergency. what should a driver do?

options.text: Switch off the A.B.S system.
Press the footbrake and engage a higher gear.
Depress the clutch pedal and engage a lower gear.
Press the footbrake firmly.

questions.explanation: To stop your vehicle in an emergency. apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping. Vehicles are fitted with braking systems to stop the vehicle.

questions.text: What should a driver do to avoid having to make an emergency stop?

options.text: Drive with your left foot covering the brake-pedal.
Drive with your left foot covering the clutch pedal.
Keep your left-hand available to apply the handbrake.
Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front.

questions.explanation: When driving in traffic, read the road ahead and keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front Use the two-second rule to determine your safe distance from the vehicle in front.

questions.text: What should a driver do to avoid having to make an emergency stop?

options.text: Drive with your left foot covering the brake-pedal.
Scan the road well ahead.
Drive with your left foot covering the clutch pedal.
Keep your left-hand available to apply the handbrake.

questions.explanation: When driving in traffic, read the road ahead and keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front Use the two-second rule to determine your safe distance from the vehicle in front.

questions.text: What does a white line in the centre of the road mean?

options.text: Vehicles may cross the line for a short time.
Vehicles may park during daylight hours only.
Vehicles may not cross or straddle the line.
Vehicles may perform a U-turn.

questions.explanation: You must not not cross or straddle a continuous white line in the center of the road unless you wish to enter land or premises and it is safe to do so.

questions.text: What does a continuous white line along the centre of the road mean?

options.text: No U-turn allowed.
Motorcyclists can overtake.
Parking allowed during business hours.
U-turn allowed during daylight hours.

questions.explanation: You must never do a U-turn on any stretch of road with a continuous white line along its centre. The restricted vision at such places would make doing a U-turn very unsafe.

questions.text: What should a driver do at an amber traffic light?

options.text: Continue only if sure that the junction is clear of pedestrians.
Make sure to pass the lights before they turn red.
Continue as there is not traffic at the junction.
Stop at the line unless it is not safe to do so.

questions.explanation: By law you must stop at an amber traffic light if it is safe to do.

questions.text: When driving on a road with tram lines why should a driver take extra care?

options.text: Driving on tracks can improve braking.
Driving on tracks can improve steering
Driving on tracks can reduce tyre grip.
Driving on tracks can improve tyre grid.

questions.explanation: Different surfaces can affect your vehicle's grid on the road and its stopping distances. You should be aware of this when driving on different surfaces.

questions.text: What must a driver be aware of before entering a roundabout?

options.text: Traffic coming from behind - how fast it's travelling and how close it is.
The traffic to the right - how fast it's travelling and how close it is.
The traffic coming from the left - how fast it's travelling and how close it is.
The traffic ahead - how fast it's travelling and how close it is.

questions.explanation: When you enter a roundabout, you must give way to traffic already on the roundabout approaching from your right. Do not enter a roundabout if by doing so you would force another vehicle to slow down or stop.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Steep hill ahead.
Crosswinds ahead.
Series of bends ahead.
Slippery stretch of road ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there might be a danger of skidding because of an uncertain road surface ahead.

questions.text: When a driver is driving in a line of traffic and does not intend to overtake, what should the driver do?

options.text: Beckon to the following traffic to overtake.
Drive close to the vehicle in front.
Stay back and leave a gap for other drivers to overtake.
indicate left as a signal to the following traffic to overtake.

questions.explanation: You should always allow sufficient distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front. This will enable you so stop safely if necessary, and it will give overtaking vehicles enough room to pull in safely to the left after they have passed you.

questions.text: How does wet weather affect a vehicle’s engine performance?

options.text: It causes the engine to run at a higher temperature.
It has not affect on power output.
It causes the engine to run at a lower temperature.
It reduces the power output.

questions.explanation: Wet weather does not affect the performance of the vehicle's engine. It does, however, affect the vehicle's road holding and braking distances. It can also affect a driver's observations.

questions.text: What should a driver do where a section of road ahead has a shallow flooded area?

options.text: Use a high gear and maintain the same speed.
Use a low gear and maintain the same speed.
Increase speed and use a higher gear.
Reduce speed and use a lower gear.

questions.explanation: When you approach a stretch of road with shallow flooding, you should reduce your speed and assess the area for any danger. As you drive through surface water, you should think of pedestrians and cyclists and try not splash them as you pass.

questions.text: What should a driver do when driving on a wide road behind a vehicle that has signalled to turn right ahead?

options.text: Overtake on the left-hand side and carry on.
Overtake on the right-hand side and carry on.
Overtake on the left, but only if turning left a short distance ahead.
Stay behind and tap the brakes to signal other drivers to slow down.

questions.explanation: You may overtake on the left when the driver in front has moved out and signalled their intent to turn right and you are going straight ahead - provided there is enough room to do so safely and and your path will not be obstructed by the swing of a large vehicle turning right.

questions.text: What does this road marking mean?

options.text: Drivers must keep left of the continuous white line.
Drivers may cross the line to overtake.
Only motorcyclists may cross the lines to overtake.
Oncoming traffic may cross the line to overtake.

questions.explanation: A single continuous white line along the centre of the road means all traffic must keep to the left of the line. You are not permitted to overtake or perform a U-turn on this section of road.

questions.text: What can cause a vehicle to skid?

options.text: Using harsh acceleration.
Stopping the vehicle in third gear.
Steering wheel too free.
Low tyre pressure.

questions.explanation: Using harsh acceleration at the wrong time can cause a vehicle to skid, especially if the road is wet.

questions.text: At traffic lights a driver should take particular care for which road users coming up on the left?

options.text: Vans.
Motorcyclists.
Cars.
Trucks.

questions.explanation: Before moving off at traffic lights you should be aware of cyclists and motorcyclists coming up on the left - in particular where there is an advanced stop line for cyclists ahead of that for other road users.

questions.text: What should a driver be aware of when making a left-hand turn?

options.text: Following traffic must have room to overtake.
To approach with the nearside wheels brushing against the kerb.
Cyclists might come up on the outside.
Cyclists might come up on the inside.

questions.explanation: When you are turning left, you should be aware that cyclists and pedestrians may come up on your inside. Always check to your left before you make a left turn.

questions.text: When may the holder of a Category W Learner Permit carry a passenger on a tractor or works vehicle?

options.text: When the passenger has personal insurance cover.
When there is a need for their assistance.
When the passenger holds a full category M license and has personal insurance cover.
When there is proper passenger seating and the passenger holds a full category W license.

questions.explanation: The holder of a category W license may carry a passenger in the vehicle only if: 1. The vehicle is designed to take a passenger, and 2. the passenger has held a full driving license in category W for two or more years.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Railway crossing ahead.
Crossroads ahead with roads of equal importance.
Major road ahead.
Crossroads ahead with roads of less importance.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a junction with roads of equal importance ahead. At this type of junction you should yield to traffic approaching from the right and traffic already turning.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Road liable to flooding.
Steep descent ahead.
Unprotected quay, canal, or river ahead.
Slippery road ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of an open water area ahead. You should show caution in this situation.

questions.text: What does this sign mean when displayed on approach to a motorway?

options.text: Coin basket on this lane
Ticket dispenser in this lane.
Leisure area on the left.
Cashier in this lane.

questions.explanation: This sign is used at motorway toll plazas to direct traffic into a lane where the toll charge may be paid by putting the exact change into a coin basket. This lane usually has a height barrier fitted to prevent large vehicle using it. This lane is generally a quicker way through the toll plaza than the cashier lane. No change is given at such lanes.

questions.text: What does this sign mean when displayed on the approach to a motorway?

options.text: Payment in euros only in this lane.
Electronic toll out of order in this lane.
Electronic toll not accepted in this lane.
Electronic toll in this lane.

questions.explanation: This sign is used at motorway toll plazas to direct traffic into a lane where the toll charge is collected electronically. When the vehicle passes through the plaza it is identified by means of an electronic tag fitted to the front windscreen. Payment will be collected via the user's account. Only vehicles fitted with the tags are allowed to use those lanes.

questions.text: What kind of vehicles are not prohibited by this sign?

options.text: Motor Homes.
Slow Vehicles.
Invalid carriages.
Learner Drivers.

questions.explanation: Motor homes are not on the list of vehicles which are prohibited by law from entering a motorway.

questions.text: Why is a windscreen laminated?

options.text: So the glass shatters into large fragments when struck by an object.
To block the harmful rays coming from the sun.
So the glass can have the registration number etched on to it.
So as not to shatter into large fragments when struck by an object.

questions.explanation: A laminated windscreen (a plastic film sandwiched between two layers of glass) is designed not to break into large fragments when struck by an object. This is to prevent serious injury to the driver and passengers.

questions.text: What should a driver add to windscreen washer fluid in freezing weather?

options.text: Methylated spirits.
A mild anti-freezing agent for windows.
Extra detergent.
Hot water.

questions.explanation: In cold weather, use an anti-freezing agent in the windscreen washer fluid, so that the windscreen can be cleared if required.

questions.text: When the fluid reservoir is full to the mark, how would a driver check that the power-assisted steering is working effectively?

options.text: Turn the steering wheel from lock to lock with the engine running.
Turn the steering wheel with the brake-pedal fully pressed.
Turn the steering wheel with the brake-pedal lightly pressed.
Turn the steering wheel from lock to lock with the engine switched off.

questions.explanation: Before starting a journey, check that the PAS (power-assisted steering) is working by the starting the engine and turning the sterring whell from full left lock to full right lock, to see that it operated smoothly and effectively.

questions.text: What is the effect of an incorrectly adjusted driver’s seat?

options.text: It can delay the driver from operating a control.
It enables the driver to relax more on a long journey.
It gives the driver a better view in the rear-view mirror.
It improves the driver’s ability to operate the clutch.

questions.explanation: Before starting a journey, you should adopt a suitable and comfortable driving position by adjusting the driver's seat to a position where all the vehicle controls can be operated efficiently.

questions.text: What should a driver do to reduce the risk of neck injury in a rear-end collision?

options.text: Ensure the vehicle has anti-lock brakes
Use a properly adjusted seat belt.
Use a properly adjusted head restraint.
Ensure the vehicle has a rear spoiler.

questions.explanation: Head restraints are designed to protect the neck and spine in a collision and thus prevent or reduce whiplash. They should be properly adjusted for both the driver and the passengers.

questions.text: What should a driver do if the fuel system becomes air-locked?

options.text: Loosen the fuel pump
Drain the fuel filter.
Tighten the injector pipes.
Bleed the air out of the fuel system.

questions.explanation: The fuel system can become air-locked if you let the fuel get too low or if there is a leak in the system. You should have the problem corrected before driving. The solution may be as simple as bleeding the fuel system to release the air.

questions.text: When driving a vehicle with a diesel engine in freezing weather, what should a driver ensure?

options.text: That the fuel level in the tank does not drop below quarter full.
That the fuel has a high sulphur content.
That the fuel is treated with an anti-waxing agent.
That the fuel filter is drained.

questions.explanation: Road diesel is supplied with an anti-waxing agent added to it. This is generally prevents the fuel from freezing at temperatures as low as -15°C.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Advance warning for school children crossing ahead.
Railway level crossing ahead.
Stop at pedestrian crossing.
Traffic signals ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a traffic light controlled junction ahead where drivers might not see the lights in good time - for example, following a bend in the road.

questions.text: When should a driver use their hazard warning lights?

options.text: When parking for a short time on a single yellow line.
When the vehicle has broken down.
When about to pull in and stop.
When the brake lights are not working

questions.explanation: Use the hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, if your vehicle has broken and is stopped on the hard shoulder, you can use the hazard warning lights to warn following vehicles of your presence.

questions.text: When should a driver use the vehicle side lights?

options.text: When parking at all times.
When driving in an unlit area at night.
When parking on an unlit road.
When driving in foggy conditions.

questions.explanation: You should use the side lights of your vehicle when parking on an unlit road at night, so that the vehicle can be easily seen by other road users.

questions.text: What is the effect of resting the foot on the clutch pedal?

options.text: It wears out the clutch more quickly than normal?
It allows corners to be taken without reducing speed.
It facilitates quicker gear changes.
It allows downhill speeds to be controlled more effectively.

questions.explanation: The clutch is the connection between the engine the gearbox. It enables the vehicle to move when a gear is engaged. When driving, you should not rest your foot on the clutch pedal, because it might disengage the selected gear and/or damage the clutch mechanism.

questions.text: What is the minimum legal tread depth for tyres on cars?

options.text: 0.6 millimetres.
1 millimetre.
1.6 millimetres.
2.6 millimetres.

questions.explanation: All road vehicles, except motorcycles and vintage vehicles, must have a minimum tyre tread depth of 1.6mm over the main tread. However, for safety reasons, you should replace the vehicle's tyres before they become this worn.

questions.text: In general, above what gross vehicle weight must be a trailer have brakes fitted?
questions.explanation: Brakes must be fitted to a trailer if its gross vehicle weight exceeding 750kg or half the weight of the towing vehicle.

questions.text: While driving in rain, a driver notices that the wiper blades are worn. What should they do?

options.text: Use the windscreen washer system while it is raining.
Stop and wipe the windscreen with newspaper.
Roll down the window and drive slowly.
Have the blades replaced as soon as possible.

questions.explanation: Use the windscreen wipers to keep the windscreen clear of rain, spray, snow or fog. Check them regularly to ensure that they are in good working order, and replace them when they become worn, before they become ineffective.

questions.text: What does using the vehicle’s hazard warning lights allow a driver to do?

options.text: To double-park when making a delivery
To park on a double-yellow line.
To warn other road users that the vehicle is broken down.
To stop on a clearway to let out a passenger.

questions.explanation: Use the hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead, when your vehicle is broken down and causing an obstruction, or when you needs to slow down sharply on a motorway.

questions.text: What is a possible effect of over-filling the engine with oil?

options.text: It could damage the catalytic converter.
It could reduce the oil pressure.
It could damage the oil pump.
It could burst the oil filter.

questions.explanation: Catalytic converters are part of most vehicles exhaust system. They remove up to 75% of the carbon monoxide, nitrogen and hydrocarbons from the vehicles exhaust. Catalytic converters can be permanently damaged if, for example, the car is filled with leaded petrol rather than unleaded, or if the engine is over-filled with oil.

questions.text: What should a driver do when the wiper blade on the driver’s side is partly worn?

options.text: Apply a light film of oil to the blade.
Swap the blade on the driver’s side with the one on the passenger side.
Have the worn blade replaced with a new one.
Swap the worn blade with the one on the rear window.

questions.explanation: Use the windscreen wipers to keep the windscreen clear of rain, spray, snow or fog. Check them regularly to ensure that they are in good working order, and replace them when they become worn, before they become ineffective.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: School ahead.
Pedestrian crossing ahead - prepare to stop.
Children's play area ahead.
Recreation area ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a school ahead. You should adjust your speed accordingly as there may be children in the area.

questions.text: What should a driver check regularly to ensure they have will have a good clear view of the road when driving?

options.text: There is enough fluid in the windscreen washer reservoir.
The internal lights are all working correctly.
The upholstery is clean.
The rev counter is working correctly.

questions.explanation: Check the vehicles windscreen wipers regularly to ensure the blades are in good condition, and check that there is water in the washer bottle.

questions.text: When replacing a wheel, in what order should wheel nuts be tightened?

options.text: Tighten nuts in clockwise sequence.
Tighten nuts in anti-clockwise sequence.
Tighten diagonally opposite nuts first.
Tighten nuts starting with the nuts at the bottom.

questions.explanation: When fitting a wheel to your vehicle, tighten the nuts gradually and evenly by tightening them 'diagonally'. For example, if the wheel has four nuts, first tighten the two nuts along one diagonal, then the nuts on the other diagonal. If the wheels has five nuts, tighten each alternate nut until all are tightened. All nuts should be tightened be the manufacturer's recommended torque.

questions.text: If the wiper blades are frozen to the windscreen, what should the driver do?

options.text: Switch the wipers on at high speed to free them.
Roll down the window and drive slowly with your head out the window.
Pull the wipers free before switching them on.
Defrost the windscreen before switching on the wipers.

questions.explanation: Before starting a journey in icy weather, make sure that the windows are clear. Use the demister to clear the windows and defrost the wipers so that they can be used to clear the windscreen.

questions.text: What is the purpose of side-impact protection bars?

options.text: To increase the weight of the vehicle thereby improving its grip on the road.
To make sure the vehicle cannot be overturned when hit from the side.
To protect the doors from becoming damaged in the event of a crash.
To protect the occupants when the vehicle is hit from the side.

questions.explanation: Side-impact protection bars are fitted to some vehicles to protect the occupants of the vehicle in the event of a collision from the side.

questions.text: What problem is indicated when wipers suddenly cease to function?

options.text: The windscreen washer reservoir is dry.
A fuse is blown
The alternator is faulty.
The wiper blades need to be replaced.

questions.explanation: Check the vehicles windscreen wipers regularly to ensure the blades are in good condition, and check that there is water in the washer bottle. If the wipers stop working suddenly, the most likely cause is a blown fuse.

questions.text: Is a driver allowed to use rebated (green) diesel fuel in a car on a public road?

options.text: Green diesel may be used in a car only in winter months.
Green diesel may be used in a car only in summer months.
Green diesel may never be used in a car
Green diesel may be used in a car only if the car is a taxis.

questions.explanation: If, in its normal use, a vehicle is used on a public road, it must use unmarked (white) diesel, as the appropriate excise duties are included in the purchase price. You can be prosecuted for using green diesel in a vehicle on a public road.

questions.text: What should the driver of a vehicle with power-assisted steering (PAS) do if steering become more difficult as they are driving?

options.text: Stop, check the level of the fluid and top up if necessary.
Drive in a lower gear with increased engine revs.
Increase the vehicle’s front tyre pressure.
Drive in a higher gear with reduced engine revs.

questions.explanation: Most modern vehicles have power-assisted steering (PAS). PAS requires less effort and feels lighter, especially when carrying out manoeuvres such as parking, U-turns and reversing. You should be aware that is is easy to oversteer with PAS.

questions.text: Which part of the vehicle must be maintained in good condition?

options.text: Upholstery.
Headlights.
Radio
Paintwork

questions.explanation: You are responsible for your vehicle's roadworthiness and you should check it at regular intervals. Among the checks you should make are that all the lights, (including the headlights) are in working order.

questions.text: How would a driver know if a brake-light bulb was not working?

options.text: By standing at the rear of the vehicle and getting another person to turn on side lights.
They would notice the brake pedal become firmer under pressure.
By Standing at the rear of the vehicle and checking as another person presses the brake pedal.
They would notice the brake pedal getting softer under pressure.

questions.explanation: To Help you to be sure that the rear brake lights are working correctly, ask someone to stand outside the car and to check that the lights come on when you press the brake pedal.

questions.text: When a wiper blade fails to clear the windscreen what should the driver do?

options.text: Have the blades replaced as soon as possible.
Apply a light film of oil to the blade.
Bend the wiper arm.
Switch the wipers to the highest speed.

questions.explanation: Use the windscreen wipers to keep the windscreen clear of rain, spray, snow or fog. Check them regularly to ensure that they are in good working order, and replace them when they become worn, before they become ineffective.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Picnic area ahead.
School children crossing ahead.
Level crossing ahead with pedestrian walkway.
Playground ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be school children crossing the road ahead, and you should be prepared to stop.

questions.text: What should a driver do if they get a tyre blow-out on the road?

options.text: Continue driving until they reach a garage.
Switch off the engine ignition to bring the vehicle to a ha
Apply the handbrake immediately to bring the vehicle to a halt.
Apply the footbrake gently and bring the vehicle to a halt.

questions.explanation: If a tyre on the vehicle you are driving blows out, slow down gradually and find and suitable place to stop. Switch on your hazard warning lights and change the wheel or call the assistance.

questions.text: What does the load index of a tyre indicate?

options.text: The maximum load of the vehicle.
The maximum load per axle.
The maximum load a tyre can carry.
The maximum air pressure of the tyre.

questions.explanation: The load index indicated the maximum weight that a tyre can support safely. When replacing a tyre on your vehicle, you should make sure that the new tyre maintains the proper load index for the vehicle.

questions.text: What should a driver check regularly to ensure they have a good clear view of the road when driving?

options.text: The windscreen wipers are working correctly.
The upholstery is clean.
The rev counter is working correctly.
The internal lights are all working correctly.

questions.explanation: Use the windscreen wipers to keep the windscreen clear of rain, spray, snow or fog. Check them regularly to ensure that they are in good working order, and replace them when they become worn, before they become ineffective.

questions.text: The handbrake generally works on which wheels?

options.text: The front wheels.
The rear wheels.
All the wheels.
The rear right-hand wheel.

questions.explanation: The function of the handbrake (or 'parking brake') is to stop the vehicle from moving when it is parked or when it is stopped on a hill. You normal use the handbrake when the vehicle is already stationary - you don't use it to stop the vehicle. It is even more important to use the handbrake when parked on a hill or when stationary in a vehicle with automatic transmission to prevent "creep". In most vehicles, the handbrake operates on the rear wheels only.

questions.text: What is the recommended method of driving a vehicle with automatic transmission?

options.text: Operate the accelerator and brake with the left foot.
Operate the accelerator with the right foot and the brake with the left foot.
Operate the accelerator and brake with the right foot.
Use the handbrake to bring the vehicle to a halt.

questions.explanation: If a tyre on the vehicle you are driving blows out, slow down gradually and find and suitable place to stop. Switch on your hazard warning lights and change the wheel or call the assistance.

questions.text: What lights should be on a car-trailer?

options.text: Brake lights and indicators only.
Indicators and rear number plate lights only.
Indicators, brake lights, rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights
Rear tail lights.

questions.explanation: All vehicles, including trailers, must have rear indicators, brake lights, a rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights.

questions.text: According to the Pre-Crash Report, which gender was more likely to drink and drive and be involved a fatal collision?

options.text: Females
Males and females drink drive equally
Neither males nor females drink and drive
Males

questions.explanation: The pre-crash Report found that more male than female drivers drink and drive and are involved in a fatal collision in Ireland. This means you need to be careful who you accept a lift from – can you be certain that your friend has not been drinking before they met up with you? Be sensible and say no to a lift if you suspect your friend has been drinking and plans to drive. If in doubt, make other arrangements for getting home.

questions.text: According to the Pre-Crash Report, what type of vehicle were the majority of people driving when they had consumed alcohol and caused a fatal collision?

options.text: Tractor
Private car
Motorcycle
Van

questions.explanation: The pre-crash Report found that more private car drivers take alcohol than drivers of any other type of vehicle before being involved in a crash. This means that if you arrange a lift home in a car, after socialising where drink was available, you are more likely to have a driver who has taken alcohol. That means you cannot take your safety for granted. Do what you can to protect yourself and other friends – including the driver.

questions.text: According to the Pre-Crash Report, what type of fatal collision was a person more likely to be involved in when drink driving?

options.text: Single-vehicle collision
Pedestrian Collision
Cyclist Collision
Multi-Vehicle Collision

questions.explanation: The pre-crash Report found that the most common type of crash where alcohol is a factor is a single vehicle collision.

questions.text: According to the Pre-Crash Report, which days of the week were people more likely to drink and drive and cause a fatal collision?

options.text: Friday and Saturday
Thursday and Friday
Saturday and Sunday
Sunday and Monday

questions.explanation: The pre-crash Report found that more alcohol related collisions occur on Saturday and Sunday compared to other days of the week.

questions.text: What do these signs together mean?

options.text: Slippery road, children may fall.
Beware of children crossing.
People jogging have right of way.
Loose chippings ahead on the road.

questions.explanation: These signs are usually displayed in residential areas, and they give advance waning that children might be crossing ahead. You should drive with extra caution.

questions.text: According to the Pre-Crash Report, how did the use of alcohol affect a person’s decision to use a seatbelt?

options.text: Drivers and passengers were more likely to wear a seatbelt.
There was no effect on a driver's decision whether to wear a seatbelt or not.
There was no effect on a passenger's decision whether to wear a seatbelt or not.
Drivers and passengers were less likely to wear a seatbelt.

questions.explanation: The law sets different drink driving limits according to various categories of driver, with Blood Alcohol Concentration levels ranging from 20mg to 80mg. Learner or novice drivers are subject to the lowest drink driving limit.

questions.text: What is the minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) level at which a learner or a novice driver is committing an offence?

options.text: 100mg
20mg
80mg
10mg

questions.explanation: The law sets different drink driving limits according to various categories of driver, with Blood Alcohol Concentration levels ranging from 20mg to 80mg. Learner or novice drivers are subject to the lowest drink driving limit.

questions.text: What is the maximum disqualification period imposed in court where the learner driver has a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) level in excess of 80 mg?

options.text: Two years
One year
Six years
Four years

questions.explanation: When a learner driver is tested and has a Blood Alcohol Concentration level of over 80mg they face a driving ban of up to six years. So, think about that for a moment. How much do you depend on your car? Do you drive to work? Do family members depend on you for lifts? This can be all affected by you having a drink and then getting behind the wheel of a car.

questions.text: According to the Pre-Crash Report, which age group had the highest number of drivers causing fatal collisions where alcohol was a factor?

options.text: 35 to 49 years
50 to 64 years
16 to 24 years

questions.explanation: The pre-crash Report found that drivers aged 16-24 years were more likely to drink and drive and cause a fatal collision. However, drinking and driving at any age is dangerous. Researchers believe younger drivers are more likely to drink and drive because they are likely to socialise late at night and then drive, or have friends in their car who will distract them, or both. Sometimes a crash happens when a driver tries to prove to themselves or to their passengers how well they can control a vehicle at higher speeds. They are more likely to do this after drinking.

questions.text: According to the Pre-Crash Report, how many people were killed by a driver who had consumed alcohol?

options.text: Less than 100
More than 251
Between 201 and 250
Between 101 and 220

questions.explanation: The pre-crash Report found that between 2008 and 2012, at least 286 people were killed on our roads as a result of a driver who had consumed alcohol. Sadly, drivers still drink and drive. You can decide yourself or, better still, with your friends to never drink and drive. You can also decide to be careful about not distracting the driver while they are driving. It sounds simple – everyone should be able to do it. Discuss the issue and the consequences of drink driving when you are not out drinking. You owe it to yourselves, your friends and your families.

questions.text: A driver is automatically disqualified from driving for how long if, on a first offence, they refused to provide a member of An Garda Síochána with a sample of blood, urine or breath?

options.text: 1 Year
4 years
3 Years
2 Years

questions.explanation: Drivers who refuse to provide a Garda with a breath, blood or urine sample can, for a first offence, be disqualified from driving for four years. But you don’t need to be afraid of providing a sample if you have not been drinking. Please take time to consider the effect on your life and on your friends and family if you are banned from driving for any length of time.

questions.text: Which of the following is a possible consequence for a learner driver if they drive after drinking as little as just one unit of alcohol?

options.text: A three month disqualification from driving
a €60 fine
A six month disqualification from driving
a €90 fine

questions.explanation: Even if you are within the legal limit for drinking, your driving will be affected. The safest approach is to never drink and drive. In some cases, one drink may push a learner driver over the reduced Blood Alcohol Concentration (BAC) level and lead to a three month disqualification from driving.

questions.text: According to the Pre-Crash Report, out of 867 fatal collisions, how many had alcohol as a contributory factor?

options.text: Less than 100

questions.explanation: Drink driving is a killer behaviour. 330 collisions involved a driver, cyclist, motorcyclist and pedestrian who had consumed alcohol. The pre-crash Report found that the most common collision type – where alcohol is a factor – is a single vehicle collision. This suggests that a number of friends can add to the danger of distracted driving. Conversations going on in the car can distract the driver and affect everybody’s safety. The RSA recommend that you discuss the dangers associated with distracting the driver when you and your friends are not out drinking. That way you can have a sensible discussion with your friends. You may find that they share your concerns and want to get home safely

questions.text: According to the Pre-Crash Report, what age group had the highest number of passenger deaths in collisions where alcohol was a factor?

options.text: 17-24 years
50 to 65 years
10 to 16 years
25 to 34 years

questions.explanation: The pre-crash Report found that passengers in the 17-24 age group are at the highest risk for drinking and driving and being involved in a fatal collision. All drinking and driving is dangerous but this age group is the most likely one to risk this behaviour. Researchers believe this risk is related to group pressure to behave in a certain way. Some of the factors that lead to a crash are:> Late night socializing then driving > Distracted driving due to a peer group in the car. Sometimes, a passenger will try to prove themselves to the others in a car, distracting the driver and putting everybody at risk.

questions.text: According to the Pre-Crash Report, how many passengers were killed in a collision where alcohol was a known factor?

options.text: between 36 and 70
less than 35
more than 91

questions.explanation: The pre-crash Report found that 83 passengers were killed in an alcohol related collision where a driver or motorcyclist had been drinking between 2008 and 2012. In addition, passengers who have been drinking may contribute to crashes, sometimes distracting the driver. Safe and socially responsible road use goes beyond the drivers themselves. If you want to stay safe, you must take responsibility for your own actions, especially as to how they might affect drivers and other road users.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Entrance to horse riding school.
Racecourse ahead.
Riding path - no vehicles allowed.
Accompanied horses and ponies ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be horses on the road ahead. You should show due regard for horses and their riders.

questions.text: According to the Pre-Crash Report, what percentage of the 169 drivers killed in an alcohol related collision had consumed alcohol?
questions.explanation: The figures speak for themselves: The pre-crash Report found that nine out of 10 drink drivers were killed when involved in a fatal collision. Drivers are affected by drinking even small amounts of alcohol. Alcohol affects your judgement, vision, co-ordination and reaction time, which in turn lead to serious driving errors.

questions.text: According to the Pre-Crash Report, how many pedestrians were killed where alcohol consumption by the pedestrian was a factor?

options.text: Between 20 and 40
Less than 10
Between 41 and 90
More than 100

questions.explanation: Alcohol affects everybody who takes it. The pre-crash Report found that 81 pedestrians killed during 2008-2012 had consumed alcohol. This shows us that no matter what kind of road user you are, you need to take care and avoid using the roads when you have been drinking.

questions.text: According to the Pre-Crash Report, in how many fatal collisions was alcohol a contributory factor?

options.text: 1 out of 10
6 out of 10
2 out of 10
4 out of 10

questions.explanation: The pre-crash Report found that the number of fatal collisions where alcohol was a factor was about four out of every 10. Drink driving is a killer behaviour. Drivers take the risk despite the high death rates. The RSA believes that some drivers are not considering the consequences. Otherwise, they would never ever drink and drive. Alcohol affects your judgment. Even one drink, where you may still be below the legal limit, will alter your behaviour. There is no safe limit.

questions.text: Which of the following checks should a driver perform on their vehicle before moving off?

options.text: Ensure that the hazard warning lights are on.
Ensure that the interior of the vehicle is clean.
Ensure that all doors are properly secured.
Ensure that the windows are closed.

questions.explanation: Before moving off it is advised to perform the ‘Safety Checks’ which includes the checking that all doors are safely closed.

questions.text: What advice should a driver give to passengers before opening doors?

options.text: Check all around and open door with caution.
Make sure that you have proper clothing protection on.
Remove seat belt and exit vehicle immediately.
Leave windows slightly open to allow circulation of air.

questions.explanation: Before opening any doors, check for other road users nearby, in particular motorcyclists and pedestrians.

questions.text: How do you make sure your vehicle is parked safely?

options.text: Don’t park it where it may endanger other road users.
Park your vehicle opposite another vehicle on a narrow road.
Avoid reversing your vehicle into a space.
Drive into parking space as quickly as possible.

questions.explanation: When parking make sure you do not interfere with normal traffic flow and that your vehicle does not disturb, block or endanger other road users.

questions.text: What should be considered when reversing out of a parking space?

options.text: Always reverse quickly to get out of space.
Avoid switching on your rear wiper.
Check behind using interior rear view mirror only.
Check for pedestrians and vehicles all around.

questions.explanation: Some car parks are designed for you to park forwards to make it easier to load shopping. In these cases take extra care as you reverse out of the parking space because pedestrians and vehicles may pass behind you.

questions.text: During what time periods can a driver be tested for drugs at a road side checkpoint?

options.text: Only during daylight hours.
Anytime of day or night.
Only during night time hours.
Only after an accident.

questions.explanation: The law allows for a driver to be tested at any time for drugs after a crash, if you have committed a driving offence or if a Garda forms the opinion that you have consumed an intoxicant such as alcohol or certain drugs. The time of day has no bearing on what test can take place and it is an offence to refuse to perform impairment tests.

questions.text: Which statement is true about tyre pressure and driving on a motorway?

options.text: The driver should increase tyre pressure in order to cope with sustained high speed.
The driver should reduce tyre pressure because high speeds will cause them to heat up.
The driver should ensure that tyre pressure is normal.
The driver should increase the front tyre pressure.

questions.explanation: You should ensure that the tyre pressure of your vehicle is correct at all times. Correct tyre pressure is especially important when travelling long distances, on motorways and at speed.

questions.text: What is the maximum permissible speed of a car towing a trailer on national primary roads?

options.text: 80 km/h.
60 km/h.

questions.explanation: When towing a trailer on a national primary road, it is illegal to exceed 80 km/h — exceeding this speed will make the vehicle unstable.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Livestock mart ahead.
Veterinary station ahead.
Cattle grid ahead.
Possibility of cattle or farm animals ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be cattle or other farm animals on the road ahead.

questions.text: What is the maximum permissible speed of a car towing a trailer on a motorway?

options.text: 60 km/h.
80 km/h.

questions.explanation: When towing a trailer on a motorway it is illegal to exceed 80 km/h — excessive speed will make such a vehicle unstable.

questions.text: When is it recommended to use coolant?

options.text: Summer only.
Winter only.
All year round.
In petrol engines only.

questions.explanation: The purpose of coolant is to keep the engine cool during operation. Coolant is usually a mixture of water and anti-freeze — this ensures that the coolant does not freeze in very cold weather.

questions.text: What effect could incorrectly aligned headlights have?

options.text: They could reduce battery life.
They could cause a fire.
They could dazzle oncoming drivers.
They could wear out the bulbs prematurely.

questions.explanation: A driver should ensure their headlights are properly aligned so as not to dazzle oncoming drivers and also to see properly themselves.

questions.text: What traffic may drive along on a cycle lane accompanied by a continuous white line?

options.text: Cyclists and taxis.
Cyclists and motorised wheelchairs.
Buses and cyclists.
Cyclists and motorcyclists.

questions.explanation: A cycle track is for the use of cyclists and motorised wheelchairs. No other vehicles may cross into or over a mandatory cycle track unless this is necessary in order to leave a side road or a property adjacent to the cycle track.

questions.text: When turning left into a side road, what should a driver do?

options.text: Ensure that following traffic has room to overtake if necessary.
Check for pedestrians or cyclists who may have come up on the ‘inside’.
Expect that traffic coming out of the other road will stay back and allow you space.
Approach the junction with the nearside wheels brushing against the kerb.

questions.explanation: When you are turning left, you should be aware that cyclists and pedestrians may come up on your inside. Always check to your left before you make a left turn.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Diversion to the left ahead.
Turn left ahead.
One-way traffic to the left.
Parking area to the left ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign tells you that you must turn left. It is usually displayed on the approach to a one-way system.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: No animals permitted ahead.
Sheep market ahead.
Abattoir ahead.
Possibility of sheep ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be sheep on the road ahead.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: No hunting ahead.
Possibility of deer or wild animals up ahead.
Wildlife reserve - no stopping.
Stag-hunting ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be deer or other wild animals coming onto the roadway.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Nature reserve. Do not litter.
Airport ahead.
Crosswinds.
Golf course ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be crosswinds ahead. Crosswinds can affect the stability of your vehicle on the road.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Lane reserved for pedestrians.
Jogging lane ahead.
Beware of pedestrians at night.
Pedestrian crossing ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a pedestrian crossing ahead. You should show caution and be prepared to stop.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Turning bay for heavy goods vehicles ahead.
Tunnel ahead.
Cathedral or church ahead.
Historic site ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a tunnel ahead. You should be aware of the procedures to follow when entering a tunned - such as turning on headlights.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Road uneven, beware of unsecured loads on high-sided vehicles.
Danger of falling rocks ahead.
Possibility of falling leaves.
Rugged coast ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there is a danger of rocks and other debris falling onto the road.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Direction of prevailing wind.
Traffic merging/diverging ahead.
Airport ahead.
Possibility of low flying aircraft.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be low-flying aircraft in the area.Low-flying aircraft can make a loud noise

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: A driver must maintain sufficient distance from the vehicle ahead of you.
A driver must drive on the left-hand side.
A driver may not park.
A driver may not overtake.

questions.explanation: The sign is generally in areas where tourists might be travelling and reminds motorists to drive on the left.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Tramway crossing ahead.
Overhead electric cables.
Railway station.
Level crossing ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives advance warning sign of tram crossing ahead.You should be prepared to stop and yield to the tram,if required.

questions.text: What does this sign mean?

options.text: Railway station ahead.
Tramway crossing ahead.
Guarded level crossing ahead.
Unguarded level crossing ahead.

questions.explanation: This sign gives pedestrians advance warning of a tram crossing where they shouldlook both ways before crossing the road.
